number of helpful: 80 of 133 people (60%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												Boy, oh boy. How I usually avoid writing these kind of things.So you know, whether or not this 'review' has a thumbs down is completely irrelevant.I have a fond place in my memories for this game and it will always sit there, regardless of this ports overall quality.It's by far and wide not my favourite of the series, but it sits high on the list.That said, this is a passable port at best. At it's worst it's an OLD port of the original PC release.The music, while seemingly a huge issue for some didn't even register with me.The needless always online DRM for a game I've been playing since 1998 is also not a selling point, but once you've signed up for an account, it just becomes a minor hurdle to get into your game (not wholly unlike the Steam service itself). It's more a mark of the times in which we live than an actual mark against the game.At face value, all of what made Final Fantasy VII such a fan favourite is still very much present in this port.But recently sitting down to an in-depth playthrough (My first actual playthrough since buying the game on Steam) has brought some... Light issues to my attention.- Graphics:No, no. This isn't a "Man, why do all the characters look like Popeye?" kind of graphical issue, this is more of a "Why update the models but not their faces?" issue.As mentioned the models are updated, looking smoother with less pixelation on the edges, the characters really stand out against the background (sometimes they even stand out against the foreground for no reason) and it runs beautifully smooth, rarely any sign of frame lag. But as I said, the faces for the characters seem to have been lifted straight from the Playstation version and then plastered onto the new models.Beyond that there are a couple of fascinating new gltiches/oversights that I've noticed. First of which being the gaped, open-mouth vacant look most characters seem to have. The most hilarious example being Sephiroth. Man, is it hard to take Aeris' death seriously when Sephiroth is standing over her the whole time with his mouth wide open THE WHOLE TIME.The second facial issue I noticed while inside the HoneyBee Inn's Group Room.Obviously, there are some copy-pasted dudes in that room, that's no secret, but did you noticed the black guys have blonde eyebrows whenever they blink? It's not even limited to them...Remember the scene where Barret and Dyne lose their arms? Well the moment where Barret recoils from being shot in the wrist there's a fabulous close up of his face, blone eyebrows and all.- Controls:If you're playing using your Keyboard, congratulations, you're clearly more patient than most of us...If you're playing using a Gamepad... Again, You're probably more patient than any of us.The button configuration for this game is a logistical nightmare and the games outirght refusal to relay meaningful information about what the buttons actually do is a hurdle I certainly could have done without.This is a complaint from someone who is admittedly not a "seasoned PC gamer". So I'm not all too familiar with the buttons on my keyboard that don't type words or relate to something in photoshop. Nor do I know which button is "button 4" or whatever on my wired 360 controller. So that is on me. I'll freely accept that I could be better informed in this instance.However, if I plug my controller in to play a pre-analog game from 1997 and for reasons never explained there is no D-Pad support what-so-ever, then yes. I'd call that an issue.If I have to run Joy-To-Key in the background of a port of Final Fantasy VII so that I don't have to manipulate menus with an analog stick then someone in the process of this port wasn't working hard enough.I will say though, once I got Joy-To-Key worked into the equation, navigating the world with the analog and switching to D-Pad for battle menu navigation felt so much better than the original experience on the Playstation. So, analog support is a pro, but no D-Pad option negates it entirely.For some people I understand that this won't sound like a big problem "Oh boo-hoo! You had to configure the buttons to your liking on a PC game!" And normally, those people would be right... Kind of.But with a port of a Playstation game, that is as much-beloved as this one I'd like to imagine that maintaining as much of the original experience as possible would be the most important thing to the developer.Making the controls wonky to the point of needing outside assistance to work is counter-active to that goal.And if you can't have fun controlling a game, then it's hardly an experience worth paying for in my opinion.So all together, there are some minor and now I think about it, really funny graphical glitches and the controls are so poorly handled that chances are you'll spend more time trying to work out how to make it all go then you ever will saving the world from slack jawed Sephiroth.The game as is, isn't the most offensive port I've ever played but it's a ways off being one of the best. Like I said at the start, at best it's passable, at worst it's old and nothing learned from the years before this release was ever implemented.My verdict? Well chances are if you liked this game already then you've likely bought it before even reading this. If not, I'd suggest buying the PSN port instead if you can, as it's essentially a 1 to 1 version of the original Playstation and requires less set-up and is no where near as fiddly controller-wise.

												Overall Score: 9.85/10       ---------------------------------------Concept: 10The story is great, the characters are interesting and fun, Open world exploration and at some parts a little linearity (is that a word?). Not too much to say about it.---------------------------------------Graphics: 9.75Graphics are... ok for its time i guess. Many people would have liked to seen an HD remake of this game, but what we got was just a little polished version of the ps1 version, but for its time the game looked pretty solid!----------------------------------------Sound: 10Amazing music. just... just amazing. Beautiful. Catchy. Awesome. so much variety in the music styles seen in the game as well. Perfect 10.----------------------------------------Playability: 9.75Only Playability problem with this game is the controller support. The game supports controllers, and a good amount of them, but it would be nice if the game maybe said "press A" or "press Y" for my Xbox 360 controller instead of "press BUTTON12" because I sure as heck don't remember the numbers for all the buttons, and at certain times this led me to pressing random buttons until it works.----------------------------------------Entertainment: 9.75Very entertaining game, you get really involved into the story and the characters, alot of variety, fun, and exploration. Only minus was at certain times having no clue where to go, with no objective marker or mission status telling you where, which left you wondering around an open world for a good while wondering where to go (but some people like doing this)

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												I can't tell you how many times I have played Final Fantasy VII. It is perhaps my favorite Final Fantasy ever, and I know many will agree with me. There is a reason why they made several other games and a movie based on the Final Fantasy VII universe.Positive:- Cut-scenes still look good- Game-play still great- Story still holds up (it still excites me even though I know what will happen)- Oh my God, the music- The materia system is so incredible. It is so fun and rewarding to experiment with different materia combinations. It is by far my favorite magic/equip system of all Final Fantasies- Plenty of side-quests, side-stories, mini-games, and collectables- Some extremely challenging boss-fights Negative:- Plenty of little glitches (none that are game breaking from what I know)- All those polygons (old graphics)- Turn based battle system - don't get me wrong, I really enjoy the system to this day. However, many magic/skill animations (especially summons) take a lot of time, are unskippable and ruin the flow of battle. - Some battle abilities take so long to complete (especially summons)- Damage cap at 9999- It can be difficult for new playersConclusion:I understand that it can be difficult to convince someone to buy Final Fantasy VII. For me, it's main selling point is the nostalgia. If you have no emotional ties to this game, it's basically an old game with a dated turn-based battling system. However, if you are willing to give Final Fantasy VII a shot, you will not regret it. The story is captivating, the battles are exciting, the world is vast, and the materia system is magnificent. I guarantee over 30 hours of old-school goodness.

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												Final Fantasy VII is easily one of my favourite games of all time. In fact, I'd go as far as calling it a contender for my favourite game full stop. Whilst its age is shown in its graphics, it still holds a prime place in my heart after playing it over and over for many years, and it will continue to do so for the rest of my days.Obviously, the game isn't without its flaws. No game is. However, FFVII has few of them. The main flaw is its plot holes during some of the flashback sequences. However, these are mostly due to translation errors and censored content outside of Japan, so that's not really the game's fault. However, a vast majority of these relate more to the lore of the world rather than the events of this game in particular, and are explored in more detail throughout the other games in the FFVII collection. The very few that apply to this game in particular can be found within the game, but through optional quests, which isn't too bad. The other big flaw is the occasional use of compulsory, story related minigames that tend to break the pacing a bit. However, it could be much worse, as many games of the time were, when it comes to pacing, as a vast majority of the rest of the game deals with pacing in a relatively superior manner.Of course, to be a game that many gamers consider the most influential and most iconic JRPG of all time, as well as one of the top 3 PS1 games of all time (according to a poll that PlayStation ran, alongside Crash Bandicoot and Metal Gear Solid), it must do a lot of stuff right, right? That is indeed the case. Here's a list of things that are done really nicely.-Story - The story is among the best throughout all of gaming history. It's powerful, it's moving, it makes you think... You'll be hard-pushed to find a video game with a better story, even today.-The characters - The characters are amazing. The main party members are all likeable in their own way, and they are all relatable too. The bad guys are the kind of bad guys that people love to hate, which is why they are popular, and actually good villains. The chemistry between characters is well done too. -The music - FFVII has a phenomenal soundtrack. The music always matches the mood of the current location and event. The battle themes make the battles feel action packed, especially the boss themes which add tension to the fights. There are also multiple tunes in the game that are moving, and they are used to set the mood beautifully.-The gameplay - Unlike XIII, this Final Fantasy is not a corridor. Whilst it tells you where to go next, it doesn't force it upon you. It allows you to explore, finding new items and equipment, and even two extra characters. There are also numerous sidequests which you can do, should you fancy a break from the story. The battles are also fun. The battles are turn based, which some might consider a bad thing outside of Pokémon these days. However, in 1997, most RPGs were turn based, with FFVII being no exception, and FFVII has a really good battle system. It's also mildly customisable. You can make it easier and more casual by setting the game to wait for you to make your choices in your turns before attacking you, or you can make it harder by letting CPUs take their turns whilst you select, meaning you have to be faster in making your choices. As well as this, it has a wonderful ability system in the form of Materia, which allows you to customise your characters' abilities easily.Overall, this game is a masterpiece. This game proves that video games could be considered an art form when done well. With the remake around the corner, I highly recommend this masterpiece so you can see where the worldwide love for Final Fantasy VII first began. The remake will likely be an amazing game, but it won't necessarily have the charm that the original does. Play this game. If JRPGs, or story driven games in general, are your thing, I promise you that you will not be disappointed by this timeless classic.

content:
Posted: March 5
FINAL FANTASY 7Reviewed by someone who's not a fanboyOpening Case:Starting about 2 years ago I decided to pickup and play every single main Final Fantasy games, I and II were lame, but cool as in: they laid the ground for other FF games, III introduced interesting mechanics, IV and V are really good even by today's standards and VI is one of the best games I've ever played, so I was a little skeptical about playing 7, I'm not much into the current/futuristic fantasy, the trend started with 7 and was only left out of 9 and 11 as far as I know, bias apart I was surprised with how many things 7 does right, changing the gameplay with minigames throughout the whole game, with a whole plaza full of them, they make a great change of pace from the repetitive gameplay, music is done spendidly with tracks ranging from smooth jazzy sounds of Midgar to hard rock battle and bosses themes.Well, that's good enough for an introduction, so here we go:Combat"But it's turned based, that's all I need to know", says the one which all FF expiriences comes from X and on.Combat is always a big part of FF, with lots of equipment, weapons, magics, summons, skills and items. I hate to start off with a big let down however the combat is incredibly lackluster for most of the game, I got through CD1 and almost all CD2 only attacking and healing my party when battling random encounters(never needing to grind), most enemies are damage sponges, never representing any challenge at all, although that's not something I can say about the bosses, with a few exceptions every one got me exited and actually fighting against it, managing items, health, magic, summons, skills and everything that should be on most fights, even early bosses are fun to battle against using those damage items that are really crappy after 6 hours in the game; only by 2/3 og the game the battles start to become fun, by then you'll have the material necessary to battle against anything that isn't immune to stop, slow, and with your whole party on (cocaine and cannabis) haste and regen.I've got to talk a bit about summons one on one with you dear reader, they are so cool... the first two times you use them, most have a half-minute unskippeable cutscenes, and if you're up to do some good damage on bosses you'll be spamming these every big battle, and don't get me wrong the cutscenes are amazingly well made for the time, especially for the first time 3D final fantasy, but when your battle takes 13 minutes you watching the same summons only to die at the last hit and have to re-watch every single summon again is so infuriating.Graphics"But they're ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and the same as the PS1 version, I'll wait for the awesome graphics from the remake", Says the console peasant who is unaware of mods.Well, while it is true I can count the polygons on a model with my fingers I used a mod which changes every model to a hi-resolution with more polygons one, and I must give credit where credit is due, what an amazing job the folk that worked on The Reunion mod[forums.qhimm.com] did, here's what the game looks after the mod, there's more to the mod then just this, so I'll link the mod at the end of the reviewMinigamesThere's around 20 of these beautiful thingymajigs spreaded across the whole game, most of them are really fun and surprised me when I actually played a section that I thought it be only a FMV,  they all come with rewards depending on your performance at 'em, they provide a fun alternative to the rather repetitive gameplay.Music"The quality is awful, it's all compressed and is ♥♥♥♥♥♥ to listen on my $800 razor headset", and for that my reply is: FOR ♥♥♥♥ SAKE MAN, SHUT UP!Can't say much on the original soundtrack quality, but I'll be damned if not to say FF7 has one of the best soundtracks of any FF I've played, I'd say only losing to FF tactics advanced, to enjoy the whole thing at it's best quality I highly recommend(again) the The Reunion mod[forums.qhimm.com], to fully apreciate every track.Character Development"They're not even rea-" ARGH! GET OUT!Look, here's where the game disappoints me the most, is the character development bad? No...Yes...Kind of(?), look, it really depends on who you refer to, Cloud, Tifa, Barret, and although short lived(*), Aerith's character arch are amazing, and they all are really well presented and developed, the rest of the crew really seems as if they're only there to be part of one or two importante dialogs and then thrown to the corner never to be used again, not even used on gameplay, as no character really is unique, everyone has the same basic attacks and the only difference between them is limit techniques, no one has an unique skill or ability, wich makes everyone the most blend combat characters, the good part is that one is blend and you can play with any party without having any downsides.(*)see what I did there? short lived hehe...Should you buy it? try FF 6, not the steam version, emulate it get it through legitimately means and if you really like it then I'd say yes.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												What can you say about Final Fantasy VII that hasn't already been said?  It's one of the best Final Fantasy games to date, which is easily said due to all of it's spinoffs like the absolutely thrilling Dirge of Cerbeus, the wonderful prequil Chrisis Core, and the ever popular movie Advent Children (just to name a few).That said, there are some good and bad with this Steam version of Final Fantasy VII, so lets get the list going;CONS:- Requires you to be online and sign in via Square Enix before playing.- Cloud saving is slow (2-5 min pause) and you can't Save/Load until it's ready.- No additional content added.- Subtitles have been censored, which actually removes a bit of character emotion.PROS:- Final Fantasy VII- Graphical Enhancements (allowing high resolutions).- Video and Overlayed characters are better synced.- Music has been updated (uses the higher-quality playstation audio tracks)- Subtitles have been "repaired" to remove "engrish" language.- Fully mapable keys & controller support.- Ability to disable cloud saving.So is the game something I would recommend?  Of course it is!  It's Final Fantasy 7 for cryin out loud!  But...  If you already own a copy of Final Fantasy VII on a console than there is no real reason to get this one.  There isn't any new content, just updating for modern PC technology.  That said, if you have the older PC version (and love it) then replacing it with this one might be a good idea.As far as the price, I don't actually believe this game is worth $17.  I'm willing to bet most individuals who are looking to purchase this game are doing so because they already have Final Fantasy VII and are simply looking to update it...  I purchased it during a 50% off sale for $8.49, which I consider a decent price.All in all I'm giving this a NOT recommended.  Shocked?  Well it's true that I love Final Fantasy VII but Square Enix screwed up with a few things.  First, this is a single-player only game so an internet account should NOT be a requirement.  Second, the regular price is a little high for a game that is almost 20 years old (no matter how good it is).  Third, the Cloud Save feature (which is the only real reason for being online) is so horribly slow you'd be better off going back to CD swapping.So as much as I'd love to give this a thumbs up, because I really love this game, I simply can't.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
The Highest Rated JRPG


YouTube™ Video: Final Fantasy VII || The Highest Rated JRPG / Guard Scorpion Boss || Part 1 

			Views: 167		

			#FinalFantasy http://store.steampowered.com/app/39140/ ♦Add me on Steam: http://steamcommunity.com/id/desolater_iv/ ♦Twitter: https://twitter.com/DESOLATER_IV		

I played through the entire game in 2016, so my thoughts may be different from those who played it back in 1997 when it was first released+ The gameplay is great, and generally focuses on combat with an active time turn-based battle system. This system rewards you for thinking fast, while punishing you for taking too long to choose an attack.  The mechanics can get deep later in the game as you have many skills and items to sort through and use in time sensitive situations.+ A HUGE variety of very unique and interesting creatures throughout the entire game. Every area has new enemies to face which are almost entirely different from one another. This made the game very exciting as you never knew what to expect next.+ TONS of fantastic bosses to defeat which is where I personally had the most fun. Every boss is challenging, and you really have to prepare and devise a strategy for each one or you may find yourself overwhelmed. Every boss is also very interesting visually with some being absolutely ginourmous  in size.+ The "Materia" system is fantastic once you learn how to use it. Basically, every weapon and armor has a number of slots that can be filled with "Materia" which are basically skills. These skills can be leveled up indivually to increase their power and even linked together in chains with added benefits. You can remove materia and give them to other characters at any time without losing progress. This makes all characters able to play any role at any point in the game.+ You can summon a huge variety of creatures who all have their own epic cutscenes. They are all a lot of fun to watch and are rather strong to use.+ A LARGE amount of content! A full playthrough can easily take 35hours+ + Tons of unique environments, towns, and areas to explore. It will feel as if you are traveling the world meeting new people and cultures.+ Very mature themes and language througout the game that is borderline shocking to see in a video game. Things like suicide, domestic abuse, vulgur language, and a lot of death. In one part although not technically married, Cid treats a girl named Shera like complete crap and orders her around like she's lower than dirt, and in another part Cloud (under control by Sephiroth) beats the living hell out of Aeris+ Lots of interesting characters with unique personalities and backgrounds. + Many mini-game sections that dramatically change the gameplay. One part you are riding motorcycles trying to knock down enemies, another part you are racing chocobos, while another part you are snowboarding down  a mountain. There are many more, which do a nice job of breaking up the game and keeping things from getting monotonous.+ Great ending+ Loved the soundtrack. You will end up having some songs embedded into your brain.- The story was extremely confusing, vague, and a bit hard to follow at times. Near the end a lot of questions are cleared up, but you will be scratching your head throughout most of the game trying to figure out what is happening. Even at the end you will likely have a lot of questions...- The first part of the game (while you are in Midgar) is extremely slow-paced and boring in my opinion as it tries to introduce characters and the plot without much combat or action. Honestly, the game did not peak my interest until after leaving Midgar, when able to travel around the world.- This may just be a personal thing, but I had a hard time connecting to the characters. It may have just been because I'm used to voice-acted characters, and reading through dialogue was a bit dry. This especially held true for me with Aeris.- Throughout many sections of the game you will be forced to use other characters you don't use normally or have no desire in using. This wouldn't be bad in itself, but you are forced to spend a considerable amount of time removing and re-equipping materia and equipment.- The game does not hold your hand and it can be very difficult to figure out what to do, where to go, or how to progress. To avoid frustration I would say using a guide is almost mandatory.- This is a minor note, but there are addional sidequests and optional bosses you can complete near the end of the game. Unfortunetely, there are no save points leading up to the final battle / story ending so you can't go back to do these opional bosses afterward which can be annoying.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												I have barely made it halfway through the main campaign and I already have over 90HRS of playtime! This is an excellent title by Square Enix and in my personal opinion, one of the best Final Fantasy games I have ever played! To define and enhance the defition of a(n) RPG is what Square Enix set out to do in 1997 and not only did they succeed but they re-shaped the entire existence of a Role Playing Game! Getting into the actual gameplay of FF7 the charcters and world are designed in a blocky format however the worlds and characters are still quite detailed and an enjoyable sight.It's up to you whether or not you enjoy this element of the gameplay. The storyline is detailed and fits quite well into the previous and post franchise story line of the Final Fantasy franchise. As for the combat system it's a mix between turn-based and real-time-stratagy that combines all you may love or hate, tbh I would have preferred if it was one or the other for the combat but either way it's a simple system that i don't believe anyone can truely "hate". When it comes to negativity about the game there isn't much I can say however it gets quite grindy at certain parts of the story and if you're planning to enter the game blind then you should know that sometimes it leaves you with no idea of where to go and you may have to search for up to 1/2 an hour to check out every single place on the map you may need to go to.Personally I love the FF franchise and of course this game, therefore I would strongly advise you get the game and if you're sitting on a fence, check it out rather I hope this helps someone decide whether or not they should buy FFVII and thx for reading! :)

content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												*SPOILER-FREE*so, this might be my favorite game of all time, if not its a definite contender for. the materia system is definately my favorite magic/skill mechanic of any game, although not everyone seems to like it: basically your magics level independently from the characters, and can be reassigned to different people on a whim (outside combat anyway). the story, oohh the plot... i heard once that they ran short on time, and ended up making a change to the plot so they could release the game on time (actually there is other evidence that the game was never actually finished, but ill come back to that later) and that plot change is, i think, the most critical thing that has made this game as great as it is. instead of following a more traditional storyline, something i think very cliche, as they origionally intended, they did something that, when playing it for the first time, my friends actually cried. had i not been watching them i would have too. im trying REALLY hard not to spoil anything, so ill end with previously mentioned evidence of it being unfinished: there are 3 elements that dont have a magic/materia for players, but enemies can do some of them, debug room contains 3 blank materia, magic labels are things like fire2, cure3 instead of thier traditional fira, curage, etc. and some other stuff in the debug room that i cant remember.

												One factor that everybody fails to mention in their review, is the fact that once you finaly register with Square Enix you can't log in to the game till you have link steam to your new profile on the Square Enix website. Once this is done you don't have to worry about the log in at the start of Final Fantasy VII ever again. For those that are queries, just follow these simple steps.;1.) once you have finaly gotten your e-mail verify2.) while logged in on Square Enix's website click on your account name in the top right corner 3.) choose User Settings4.) click on Link Account5.) click on the link button next to steam6.) Follow directions from steam to allow the Link7.) Enjoy Final Fantasy VII

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Final Fantasy VII is one of those games that everyone knows. It was revolutionary when it first came out for the PS1, and was one of the best selling games of 1997. The PC port is amazing. The original soundtrack was replaced with a newer soundtrack, and the graphics were also dramatically improved. I, personally, did not enjoy the music that was put into the PC port of this. However, with the aid of mods, I was able to replace the PC soundtrack with the classic PS1 soundtrack.  The PC port also offers 3 different graphics choices, depending on the preferences of the user. The user can choose between the PS1 graphics, or the PC graphics, as well as a mod that gives combat 3D graphics. One downside of this game, is the fact that you have to create a Square Enix account to play. This was a disappointment for me, but not enough to keep me from playing it. Aside from the technical aspects of this game, the gameplay is amazing. This is by far, the best game I have ever owned, because of the great story, the great soundtrack, the amazing combat, and the replayability. After spending over 500 hours on this game over three different game systems, I won't be stopping any time soon. I highly recommend FFVII, and honestly, this game is worth much more than $11.99.

												Maybe it's just the time that I live in. The game's good and the music's cool and everything, but... Did people really care that much for these emotionless-looking blocks of people that consisted of two 3D polygons? Also the backgrounds are in really bad resolution and the game feels pretty slow... Especially in battles where there actually appears to be lag! Was this seriously  what the original game was like?!Look, being faithful to the original release of a game is good. I love originals more than remakes most of the time! But there are some games that are better when they're remade, such as Pokemon HeartGold and SoulSilver. I think Final Fantasy 7 should have an HD version by now or something? I don't know, but this original PS1 version here just isn't drawing me in as much as I thought it would. It's NOT keeping my attention... Maybe I didn't give it enough of a chance? Still...EDIT: ARG! How could I forget that whole... What do you call it? DRM? Why would you do that for a game that supports no multiplayer in anyway?! And don't give me an argument involving updates... That's Steam's deal, not yours Square Enix! People hated the Xbone for pulling the very stunt you're trying to pull on me now! I have half a mind to rush over to your site and delete my account because I don't want to ever support that!!Not only that, but I hear bad rumors... Apparently the music I'm hearing is actually a low-quality version of the original? For real? Is this fixed or now? As a newbie I can't tell. But based on how you later treated FF8's Steam release... I'm starting to get the sense that I should never trust you, Square Enix.I mean, I was dissatisfied with the game already when I thought I was playing the original game! Now that I am hearing these rumors and have been reminded of this DRM horror... Which I feel SUCKERED into...What happened? Why are you doing this? I thought you were supposed to be one of the top game companies around! Don't tell me you're getting greedy and selfish too, like Microsoft is becoming and Capcom is (I hope) recovering from. It feels like these days I can only trust Nintendo and Valve to CARE for us...!

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Before you vote this review unhelpful solely due to the thumbs down, please read this: I recommend Final Fantasy VII! I highly recommend it. It's one of my favorite games of all-time. However, I do NOT recommend that anyone play this port! Please read on for details...Final Fantasy VII is acclaimed as one of the high-water marks of the role-playing genre. Many gamers, particularly RPG fans, have played through this game not once but a multitude of times. I downloaded the new Steam version and played through it one more time on my PC to assess how the game has aged.The very first thing that I noticed about the game was the chasm between how well the audio design and soundtrack have aged versus how poorly the graphics have. It becomes clearly apparent that sprites have aged far better than polygonal characters when comparing this game to an older, sprite-based games in the series such as Final Fantasy VI. Sprites carried a certain charm to them, and remain tolerable despite their lack of beauty. Polygons, for lack of a better description, just look strange and ugly. Their blockiness represents a human character far more poorly than even a sprite can. To compare it to Hollywood, sprites are like Disney cartoon of the '70s, while polygons are like the bad special effects of the '80s. The audio, however, has aged gracefully. Nobuo Uematsu's score has always been perfect for the game, and I remembered how fond I was of it the first time around immediately upon starting the game again.Final Fantasy VII, to me, was the beginning of Square's "hit-or-miss" character design specifically regarding western gamers. As a western gamer, I just can't see the appeal in a character like Cait Sith. While the majority of the characters still have good levels of depth and development, Cait Sith is a worthless entity who brings absolutely nothing to the game. He's a quirky stuffed toy injected into the game to please a culture that I just can't understand. Square Enix has continued down this path even further in future games, particularly in Final Fantasy XII, which saw two cherubic children as the main protagonists. Yuck. But there are some game-savers here. Cloud is such a deep and human character that it's worth playing through the game just to witness his growth. Sephiroth's villainy hasn't shown age, either. He's still one of the best gaming villains in history, a title well earned.It's obvious what to expect from the gameplay. This game is purely old school JRPG. It doesn't bother me, as it's a type of game that I once had a huge affinity for. I can jump back into the more slowly-paced, active turn-based battle systems any time and still enjoy it. To others, it may be a bit more tedious. This is especially true regarding random battles. As an old-school JRPG player, random battles are familiar to me and sort of a necessary evil. To others, the tedium may be intolerable. It's difficult for me to be objective enough to say.I've always loved the materia system. It's my favorite form of character development in any Final Fantasy game, and it holds up. Growing your materia through the management of your weapons is so much fun, and the high-level materia such as Slash-All and Double Cut really make you feel all-powerful toward the end portion of the game..The main complaint that I have about the game is an issue that never seemed to bother me before. The control of Cloud through the various pre-rendered areas is absolutely atrocious. Pressing up on the directional pad will sometimes cause him to go left or right, and pressing right or left on the pad will sometimes cause him to go down. There's no clear indication of when this will happen -- It's unique to each area. This becomes particularly annoying in areas where random battles occur. Very often I'd find myself doubling back due to this, and fighting far more random battles than I actually had to.I wouldn't be able to conclude this without mentioning the cutscenes and minigames. The idea of rewarding players with a CGI cutscene during certain parts of the game was a fresh, new concept at the time of the game's release. Seeing the devs at Square flaunt their graphical prowess was mind-blowing, and the cutscenes were unlike anything in video games at the time. They truly were rewarding, and I remember being so impressed as a 12-year old first playing this game that I recorded them on a VHS tape for later playback. The minigames were also groundbreaking, but have aged poorly. Bad control plagues many of them, specifically the motorcycle and snowboarding games. But the inclusion of these changed the genre for years; the lack of minigames in a post-Final Fantasy VII JRPG would be a strange omission for a later title.Final Fantasy VII has got its problems. In some cases, it's aged beautifully and become the historically powerful title that gamers expected it to be upon its release. Final Fantasy VII brought RPGs as a whole into the mainstream. Without Final Fantasy VII, games like Mass Effect 2 and Fallout 3 may never have been developed at all. The graphics and control, however, will be nearly unbearable to any gamer going back in time to play this game for the first time.As far as the Steam specific port that I'm reviewing here? Unfortunately... It's total trashEvery resolution that isn't 640x480 windowed looks terrible. They've upped the resolution on the characters and NPCs, but the pre-rendered backgrounds are the same so they look awful in any other resolution. And don't even think about going to 16:9. All it does is stretch the picture to fit the screen. Barf.There's also a persistent black bar along the bottom of the screen that is only ever filled in when accessing the menu. Imagine you're watching a film in letterbox, except that there's only one black bar on the bottom of the screen and no matching bar on the top. Just awful.On top of the graphical issues, Square's ridiculous DRM is present. You must log into Square Enix when you first start the game. People already hate Uplay. Why would Square do this? It's an idiotic move.I'm a die-hard PC gamer, but even I have to say that the best way to play this game in the modern day is to download the PSone port from the Playstation Store and play it on a PSP or a Vita. I wouldn't recommend the PC port to anybody that isn't looking to modify it heavily, as mods are basically the only reason to purchase the PC rerelease.People have also mentioned the music quality being subpar compared to the PS1 version, but it honestly didn't affects my experience at all. I've played through the game probably a dozen times since 1997 at this point, and while I definitely noticed the music being different, it didn't seem any worse than the original game.In conclusion, this game still remains a must-play for anyone who liked the original or any gamer looking for a history lesson. Like an old painting, Final Fantasy VII continues to be historically relevant and is worth seeing and experiencing if only to recognize the influence it had on present day gaming. But the paint has aged, and the artwork is unfortunately not quite as vibrant and stunning as it once was.Just don't play the newly released PC port. It's a bad.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
ENGLISH and Italian Review Recensione Inglese ed ITALIANA English:Where do i start? You're going to jump in a long and fantastic adventure, in a fantasy world, populated by crazy creatures and wonderful, charismatic and lovable characters. Be aware though, "fantasy world" doesen't necessarily means "perfect, colored and happy". No. In this world there are death, pain, depression, corruption, broken hearts and broken dreams, avarice, homicide... This list could continue. Yes, you live in this kind of world, but you don't care at all, you're interested only in your profit. Oh, but things will change. Soon you'll rediscover emotions, passion, you'll rediscover life. You'll rediscover details of your life that will remember you that you used to be real. You used to be alive. And you can be once again. Learning the values of llove, friendship, sacrifice. When you will be called, along with your bizarre, imperfect but tight-knit group to save humanity. If this isn't enough, you got a serious problem. I shouldn't even talk about graphics or gameplay, here they doesen't count. But some people is just obsessed, so... It's a classic turn based RPG well structured, with an open world exploration outside the battles. The graphics are not new, but is remastered, pleasant for the eyes compared to the PS1 version. The difficulty is hard, the asked efforts are many. Is this not enough? Come back to Call Of Duty then. This game is effort. This game is emotion. This game is life.                     (Sorry for my bad english.)Italiano:Da dove comincio? Stai per tuffarti in una lunga e fantastica avventura in un mondo di fantasia, popolato da creature pazzesche e personaggi stupendi, carismatici amabili e ben caratterizzati. Ma attenzione, "mondo di fantasia" non significa necessariamente che sia un mondo perfetto, felice e colorato. No. In questo mondo esistono morte, dolore, depressione, corruzione, sogni e cuori infranti, avarizia, omicidio... La lista continuerebbe ancora. Si, tu vivi in questo tipo di mondo, ma non ti interessa particolarmente, sei interessato solo al tuo tornaconto. Oh, ma le cose cambieranno. Ben presto riscoprirai le emozioni, la passione, riscoprirai la vita. Riscoprirai particolari della tua esistenza che ti ricorderanno che una volta eri vero, una volta eri vivo. E puoi esserlo ancora. Imparando i valori dell'amore, dell'amicizia, dell sacrificio.  Quando verrai chiamato, assieme al tuo bizzarro, imperfetto, ma affiatato gruppo a salvare l'umanità. Se questo non è abbastanza, hai un serio problema. Non ci dovrebbe essere nemmeno bisogno di parlare di gameplay e grafica, qui non contano. Ma certa gente è ossessionata da cose del genere, dunque vi accontento. Il gameplay è il classico RPG a turni ben strutturato, con esplorazione open world fuori dalle battaglie. La grafica non è moderna, ma è rimasterizzata, resa piacevole agli occhi rispetto a quella per PS1. La difficoltà è alta, l'impegno richiesto è molto. Non basta ancora? Allora torna pure a giocare a Call Of Duty. Questo gioco è impegno. Questo gioco è emozione. Questo gioco è vita.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												There is a reason many people consider this game to be one of the best games ever made is because of the gameplay and story. Final Fantasy VII starts the player off in Midgar, a city that uses the Planet's energy to use everyday tools such as electricity. A terrorist group called AVALANCHE plan on destroying the complany thats pretty much in charge of the world, Shinra Inc. Now what does this have to do with ur character? Well Cloud used to work for the company as a First Class SOLDIER but he eventually left and is now fighting with AVALANCHE to destroy Shinra. There is another plot in the story besides taking down Shinra which is killing Sephiroth. Im gonna let the players discover how big of a role almost every character is in this game no, series. Final Fantasy VII's story is so big and explained that there are 3 parts of it. Crisis Core is before the events of Final Fantasy VII and Advent Children which is a movie which takes place 2 years after Final Fantasy VII.The presentation is simply amazing. Even though this game was first made on the Playstation 1 in 1997, the graphics still look amazing to this day. Almost everything is hand drawn such as the background but when ur enterting a train for example, the whole screen changes just to make the train move and than go back to the hand drawn background. The only reason y every character is almost entirely made out of polygons is because of the size of the game. For those who dont know, This game came with 3 discs on the PS1 so it makes sense for characters to be polygons. The gameplay is awesome and theres 2 types of it. The first type of gaming is just roaming around in the world map and through villages/towns. The second type is the Role playing. You must wait till ur time gauge fills up in order to choose wat to attack. There are diffrent kinds of magic in this game and when you level up ur materia (items to improve ur characters) u may get increased damage as well as new spells such as using Cure3 when leveling up ur materia. You not only earn EXP but u also earn AP for materia. There are also Summons in the game like in almost every Final Fantasy game. Even though u ccant skip any cutscenes of summon cutscenes, its always nice to watch some animations such as Knights of the Round (Best Summon) and Bahamut ZERO's cutscenes.I give this game a 10 out of 10 because even though this may not be acceptable graphics for this generation (2015). it still shows that u can break the limits of a PS1 by simply using more discs.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												Final Fantasy VII - The game that defined an era.One of the greatest games, arguably on any console from any time. Final Fantasy VII is another epic installment from the Final Fantasy franchise, which needs no introduction. Released well over a decade ago, Final Fantasy VII still lives on in the memories of almost every RPG fan. Wether you played it when it was first released, or you are just trying it for the first time today, be prepared for a journey like no other. Join Cloud Strife, a seemingly selfish, arrogant mercenary as he fights at first for himself, but as the story progresses, maybe there is more to Cloud than you might think.With an entire host of unforgettable characters, journey through a mass world, visiting huge cities, quiet coastal towns, beach resorts and much more, all backed with an incredible soundtrack by the legendary Nobuo Uematsu, this is a game that will not let you down, not the first time, not the tenth time. Final Fantasy VII truely is, one of a kind.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												I know the actual game-play of this game is good, because I own the game on the PlayStation. I bought this PC game to  support the future development of Final Fantasy games on the PC platform, however if this is the way Square Enix plans to treat the PC platform they just shouldn't support it at all.I was aware of the DRM when buying. Having a single Square account seemed easy enough to handle and I was craving some nostalgia. So I created a Square account, but apparently it takes a while for the game to register an account creation because it didn't immediately register that my account was valid. I tried logging in on the opening screen for thirty minutes to no avail, but when I came back two hours later Square was finally ready to let me play my game. But when I started playing, I found myself in a fresh new nightmare.The controls are atrocious with a keyboard. To keep things short, in order to interact with people, doors, and items in the game the character must be facing the object. The buttons are too sensitive and if I don't take my fingers off the movement keys at exactly the same time the character moves to face which ever key I take my finger off last, even if it's last by less than a millisecond, making the character turn in a direction the item is not in. It is infuriating to try to talk to people or open doors because of this sensitivity. I found my self trying many times just to interact with characters.In order to not deal with this issue, I tried plugging in a controller- and the controller just as bad as the keyboard; the only way to move a character using a 360 controller is with the joy stick, the game IGNORES the directional pads altogether. It feels so wrong using the joystick in this game. Complaining about feeling may be nit-picky to some, but after spending so much time playing the original FFVII using the directional pad and playing all the other FF games using a directional pad, I have the question why Square willfully made this game ignore them. The PS3 and PSP versions of this game do not force players to use the joysticks, why do PC players, who normally enjoy the freedom of choice, get the short end of the stick with this game? I bought the game for nostalgia, and without good controls there is definitely no nostalgia.At every turn, even from first booting it up, it seems Square Enix did not want me to play the game. So I have not played this game. I'll probably come back to it when I'm less infuriated, but ,if you buy it, do know this game comes with issues that Square Enix willfully put in the game.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2016
												Oh well...here goes the two cents from someone who didn't play it when it was originally released by the PSX, and for how long have I regretted it. Finally, Square gave us the pleasure of delivering it to Steam and despite some of the aspects of the game haven't actually aged that well (the first 10hrs of gameplay or so do get a bit tedious) the fun suddenly snowballs and I've ended up enjoying this game a lot. It certainly lived up to the expectations I had on it and that's saying a lot.The active turn battle and the Materia system open the field for a lot of variations in your strategy, which you will have to adjust to each boss (until you get a certain Summon who is just plain broken -you know who I'm talking about-).The story of the game is certainly a thumbs up, there's a large enough variety of playable characters that you can follow up their stories and see how they grow and change without it being too tedious.Superbosses make for an incredible challenge in this game and you'll have to do your grinding before facing them and getting obliterated (yup, even with that certain broken Summon we were talking about before). If there is one thing that outweights the tedious task of grinding to defeat the bosses is the great satisfaction that such an achievement leaves behind.Be sure to play it. This will prove to be a formidable experience for almost any gamer who is ready to invest some time.9/10

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
												One of my favorite games of all time. Something about this game just draws you right into it. I never liked the Final Fantasy series as a kid and didn't find the appeal but one of my friends persuaded me to try FF7, and I reluctantly did, but never regretted it. Don't be fooled, even though this game is nearly 20 years old now, it is huge and has tons of content. There's a reason it took 3 discs on the original Playstation version.All of the main characters draw their own unique story and make you want to help their cause. The game starts out slow and easy, at first I didn't think it was going to be good, but once you get out of the starting area and unlock the world map, you'll quickly find why this game is so good. The areas, characters, and soundtrack all work together in a perfect way to deliver a very impactful story.As for the graphics and other technical details of the game, you have to remember that this game came out in 1997. Keeping that in mind, this game still looks and sounds amazing. The port to PC works great and has never crashed on me or had any issues. I do recommend a controller as that's just how the game was designed to be played, but even with a keyboard and mouse you can complete everything just fine. Using a controller adds to the nostalgic and original feel of the game, which boosts the experience though.100% recommended to anyone who is into old or classic games and like RPGs or to anyone who likes the other games in the Final Fantasy series. The story does not have any stale points and keeps you wanting to complete it all the way through! If you're planning to get the remake for Playstation 4, I recommend trying the original before or after you play that one so you can get a better feel for what FF7 is about.

												Final Fantasy VII is, in my opinion, the best of it's kind - crushing new games like Final Fantasy X easily. If you are capable to accept the simple graphics, you should really consider to play this game. In my opinion it has by far the best in-game and battle-system, giving the player the chance to find secrets and giving him the chance to obtain Bestias (powerful summonings which the heroes can summon at a certain state in the game) which are hidden somewhere in the game. Even though it's really old, it tried to do some easy render-sequences and if you want to the graphics are, with some know-how and troubleshooting, fully modable (be careful with spoilers while doing so). You should really try to play it some time, it served me well in 1997 aswell as now!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
												The pinnacle of JRPGs for many players, this game has aged like wine in many regards and like milk in others.The graphics have aged poorly, and the early-PS1 blockiness and untextured polygons of the characters may turn off some people, though they are charming in their own way. The pre-rendered backgrounds still look decent, and battle models are much less blocky than their overworld counterparts.The story has aged very well, and provides a strong narrative with many emotional moments and memorable locales, and all of the main characters have strong character arcs and growth throughout the story, even if they are not in the forefront at times.The battle system is good, never feeling too frantic or too slow, and abilities and strides a nice line between turn-based and real-time. Difficulty is pretty well-tuned throughout the game, there were not many situations where it felt that grinding levels and equipment was necessary (Although if one wants to take on some of the post-game optional bosses, they will need to grind quite a bit).The soundtrack is immaculate, and almost every track in the game is memorable in their own way.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2016
												A timeless classic RPG that has been loved by many people since the original release. I remember playing this game every few years never quite managing to fully complete it and now I begin again with the hope of an eventual completion that will make life worth living.The game runs fine apart from the occasional crashes though it only tends to happen when the game is minimized and this is easily avoidable. The steam achievements give an additional gameplay factor to help spurn on the dedicated player, though it would be nice to have a few more that are inventive and challenging rather than requiring a mass grind session (Of which we tend to do already) or perusing youtube/guide sites in order to find glitches and bugs to aid in the completion from almost twenty years of playing.I would recommend this game to all generations, as a long time fan of the final fantasy series (Waning in recent years due to the class of game they have released). I will rack up the hours gladly and not be disappointed that my life accomplishments end here.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												Do you really not know this game? Seriously, do I even have to write this? I want to note, that this was the first game I played when I upgraded from a Genesis to a PS1. I had never played an RPG before. This game introduced me to video games with true stories, even if the story is pure insanity. That said, instead of listing why it is awesome, I'm gonna tell you all the things that I know suck about it. Also note, I recommend it. I own it on PS1, PC hardcopy, and on Steam, so I want you to buy it.1. The graphics. Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥are they awful. Like seriously, so blocky and distracting and if I didn't love it so much I wouldn't even be able to play it and get past the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ graphics.2. Summons are so ♥♥♥♥ing long! They are beautiful, yes, even with♥♥♥♥♥♥graphics, but they get real tiresome after the 75th Knights of the Round.3. As previously mentioned, the story makes zero sense. Yes, in broad strokes, there's supposed to be a pattern and such, but as you get to the details it is nonsensical. Yeah, the death scene was tragic and yeah I cried, ♥♥♥♥ you I was young and had no idea and had raised that character as one of my powerhouses, but despite that the rest is just crap. Also that death still seems to have no reason behind it.4. Angst. so much angst! So much sad drama angst. Am I who I think I am? Are any of us truly human? Just... let me hit things with my giant phallic sword.There's more, but I'll stop there. So yeah, buy the game. You'll still love it.The Nostalgia is strong in this one.

												Dear Gamers, welcome to...« FINAL FANTASY VII »A few weeks ago, after doing my first trial on Final Fantasy 7,I though this game was crap. I even did a « downvote » evaluation.Alright, I knew that I would try to game more and that I might like itand would change my evaluation (actually, I really did one but Itrolled a bit on it. oAo Kinda. Was more like frustrated xD)Basically, Final Fantasy VII is a wonderful game. You might get lost in the beginning and hate the game (total beginning), but keep playing.Trust me, you will thank me later.The story is amazing, the game is pretty long itself. They were many questsnext to it, even though the game is from 1997.Most of players, when they first played the game, got lost. They did not know what was going on in that kind of uggly Factory area.But the game will explain you what was up at this time, a bit later.The fighting gameplay is awesome and kind of original, for a old RPG game kind!The game has some glitches that makes the game unique.I really hope that, in the FF7 remake, they would put the "duplicate item" glitch system back.It's one of the main reason of why players love this game. xDAnd you know what !?After doing the game, SquareEnix offers you an awesome and beautiful movie named « Final Fantasy VII: Advent Children » which is the following of the Story.Wonderful movie look for a 2004~2007 movie made.The only one thing I regret about that movie is the Kid voice acting.Like in many movies but oh well! I'm getting out of the topic.Please, buy FF7, enjoy every minutes out of it. Even the most annoying minutes. There is so much to do.Story, fights, chasing materias, growing chocobos, playing in Gold-Saucer, improving your character, hunting Achievements.Unlike my first evaluation, I do recommend you this game.Peace! ♥

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Final Fantasy 7.Possibly the most Iconic Video Game that SquareSoft/Square Enix has ever made. And for good reason.Final Fantasy 7, although the graphics compared with today's games are completely rubbish, however back in 1997 these graphics were top of the line. The cutscenes amazed fans and enticed them.Final Fantasy 7 has a great, gripping storyline, Filled with humor, horror and of course sadness which anyone who knows anything about Final Fantasy surely heard of the tragedy that happened with one of the main characters. Not only does it have a great storyline but it has one of the most iconic and loved antagonists, "Sephiroth", much more then just a "Mummies boy" as many fans and haters stated, he has one of the best battle themes and of course best Limit Break, "SuperNova".Final Fantasy 7 has a excellent soundtrack composed mainly by Nobuo Uematsu but the PC Version was given, poor horrible MIDI formats. Luckily Square Enix upgraded them but it isn't the same as the original PSX version.Not only is the main quest great but it also has a brilliant side quests and entertainment. You can learn the history of the playable characters during Disc 2/Disc 3 and you can spend your hard earned Gill at the Gold Saucer, betting on Chocobo Races, Smashing SOLDIER off bikes or just slide down a snowy slope on a snowboard some idiot kid gave you.Storyline: 10/10Graphics: 8/10Music: 6/10Side Quests: 10/10Addictivity: 9/10Overall, great value for money. And is definitely one of or THE best RPG game ever made. No wonder fans all around the world still want a PS3 / PS4 Remake. I know I do!

content:
Posted: January 2
												Normally I'm not into these type of old Turn Based JRPGS. I've tried Fire Emblem and Bravely Default, but they never really clicked with me. Now a friend paypaled me money to purchase the game and now that I have finished the game after 40ish hours, I can safely say I'm glad I got this game and it's probably the best b-day gift I have ever gotten. After playing FFXV and Crisis Core, I was pretty motivated to play this game. And based on what I've played in FFVII, I can see myself playing through the older Final Fantasy games for most of this year.The story has been and still is amazing and the simple yet satisfying gameplay is pretty nice. Idk why, but for this game, I feel a lot more motivated to grind in general regarding turn base JRPGs compared to before and the cast itself is likable with each one contributing an interesting personality. Even with the old visual styles, I found myself very immersed with the story because of how good it is and the characters that help bring it to life. I can't believe this game was released the same year I was born, so I never had the chance to play this game at all. The Soundtrack, obviously it's amazing whether you're fighting or roaming around the land. Very memorable and during certain scenes, very appropriate as well.The DRM regarding the square enix account, idk if that has been a huge issue prior, but I was watching my friend stream it and he had no issues with it and I haven't had any issues either. Ignore the negative reviews that mention the DRM cuz that doesn't hold it back. Sure you may need an internet connection, but honestly we're in an age where we need an internet connection.Overall, I honestly couldn't really find any flaws with the game that are very notable that could ruin the experience. I am aware that there are some glitches that can ruin the game, but thankfully I haven't ran into any of them. Outside of them, the game is perfect and definitely one of the best video games I have played of all time. I'm really glad I got to start on this game now because I almost avoided the game just to wait for the remake, which is still a few years away from being released. Now here I am just satisfied with FFVII and now even more excited for the remake to come out as well as having a huge urge to play through as many old Final Fantasy Games as I can. And I'm still not even done with FFVII because of a lot of post game content I definitely plan on doing, which will take up a lot of my time still. If you want to play an old game to get yourself into the FF series, definitely start with VII. You can't go wrong with this.Oh and as to note this game is just a little over $10 right now and I don't see why they would raise the price on this game, so for just that price, you get at least 40ish hours of immersive gameplay, and it's amazing how much an old game can really give you an amazing experience.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												A popular opinion among many, but FF7 is my favorite game of all time. Not just because of nostalgia, but because it is an incredible experience. While it has not aged well graphically, the story, soundtrack, and characters still stand tall. Fighting the Ruby and Emerald Weapons still has me mashing the O button hoping I don't get obliterated. The final fight between Cloud and Sephiroth still pumps me up as Cloud shreds him apart with Omnislash. The loss of arguably the most beloved character of all time still brings a tear to my eye. Hell, I will still attempt to bring Aerith back, knowing in the back of my head it's not possible, or I will try to get that mysterious chocobo the runs underwater or even outerspace knowing no such thing exists. Call me biased if you will but this game is a must play! Infinity/100 greatest game ever!

No other RPG you will ever play compares to this game. It was the first of its kind, when it came to visuals, story, and complexity. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												Final Fantasy VII is the first game I played on the original PSX back in 97. I was 10 at the time and the most advanced game I'd played until that point was Sonic ;) FFVII opened up an entire new world for me, showing what video games can and should be. With a story better than any film, that is both tragic and at times wonderfully frivolous and off the wall, the emotional dynamism of this game makes it an all time classic. It changed my life in more than one way - Nobuo Uematsu's timeless score, with it's clever variations on the main theme, was my inspiration to follow a career in music.I've finished the game at least 20 times in almost as many years, and every time I look at the game in a different way. It is as relevant emotionally and politically now as it ever was. If you've never played it before, it's not too late. And if you have, then seeing it spruced up is a great experience. Could Squeenix have tried harder to make this a more unique experience? Absolutely. Is the DRM a nuisance? Some say it is - I haven't had a problem yet but I do fundamentally have a problem with the idea of DRM. So Squeenix definitely lose points for that. But it is great enough as it stands to be worth it anyway.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												I never got the chance to play this originally on Playstation. It was always one of those games that I wanted to play, but could never find a copy of, so I was ecstatic when I found out that the PC port was available through Steam. One Steam sale and 36 hours later, I now finally understand both the hype and the hatred towards this game. Personally, I really enjoyed it and consider myself a part of the hype category. A colorful cast of characters that are well-designed and well-developed, a combat system intertwined with the Materia spell system for unique encounters and boss battles, and an amazing plot that kept me invested all the way through. Few JRPGs have held me for as long as this one has, rivaled only by the Kingdom Hearts franchise. There may be other entries in the Final Fantasy series that can be argued for over VII, but I can understand and respect why this game is held on such a prestigious pedestal.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												For a great many people Final Fantasy VII may as well have been Final Fantasy I. This was the game that introduced me to the genre of JRPGs, with its classic spiky haired protagonists and oversized weaponry. More importantly, it also demonstrated, to a worldwide audience, the potential scale and spectacle that modern video games now provide almost effortlessly. At the time, this was something special.Returning to the game now might intially highlight some out of date looks and casts a stark light on plotting that perhaps passes less muster to a more discerning, mature player. However, I think too much is made of these critisisms; the game, while aged (as happens to all of us) still has a charm to it's blocky low-poly models that elevate it above most games of that period (even ones that were arguably better looking at the time), and the high production values, cinematic camera shots, and incredible music score help promote a timeless quality that help retain playability. And the story, while suffering from a sometimes dodgy translation, touches upon big themes of identity, loss and the environmental cost of progress, while remaining accessible in a children's action/soap opera vibe. The story beats swing between comedy and seriousness a little unevenly (sometimes a more than a little, actually), but not unsuccessfully, and overall the plot is driven by appealling character relationships, and great action set pieces cut between quieter, more reflective moments.The game is huge, opening out from an inital starting city into a whole world to explore, filled with lots of optional things to do which will keep you busy way past the more linear main story path. The combat system is interesting, featuring an active time battle system which merges turn based strategy with some time pressure. The magic system is fun, collecting materia, which acts as spells which attach to your weapons and armor, and level independently of your characters, providing flexibility. The game finds lots of ways to play with the systems it establishes.The PC version has some weaknesses in that the backgrounds don't always merge as seemlessly with the video transitions and 3D foreground elements as well as on the original console versions, and the music suffers a bit too. Also, if you play with keyboard controls, some of mini-games have occasionally overly dexterous key mappings which might turn your delicate hands into twisted pretzels.Despite the flaws above, if you haven't played Final Fantasy VII, the PC version remains a solid way to experience a true classic of gaming.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
PC Port ReviewThis is a re-release of the original PC port from 1998.GameplayNothing has really been changed here, glitches and exploits included. It's plays exactly like the PlayStation version only with slightly better visuals and faster loading times. The only major difference in gameplay is how control prompts/instructions are displayed in-game.Controls- Xbox 360 controller is supported.  - Cannot use dpad or triggers (bumpers work, but not triggers.)   - Original game did not have rumble support, nor does this.  - Very playable.- Keyboard support only.    - No mouse.    - Majority of keys are rebindable.   - Very playable.GraphicsPros: - Can be played in a higher res compared to PlayStation version.- Models do not look as jagged and blurry compared to PlayStation.- FMVs (while compressed) have aged pretty well.Cons:- Game battles are locked in at 30FPS, menus included making Tifa or Cait Sith's limit breaks a bit harder to use.- Framerate is not consistent across world map and has major pop in of objects.- Pre-rendered backgrounds while upscaled are very pixelated.- Would recommend playing on a TV or a Window for those that do not like pixels.Graphics note: While the game has a "widescreen option" I would highly recommend playing the game in its original 4:3 aspect ratio with your regular screen resolution, playing this game in widescreen will only stretch the image and make it look worse.SoundWith a patch from Sqaure-Enix the game has all of it's original PlayStation music tracks, I have noticed some sounds are missing however. Not a major distraction.Would I recommend this?Yes! I played through the game through it's full story and some side quests and had no major problems or technical issues. It's not a perfect port but I support the Final Fantasy series being ported to PC and hope to see more in the future.

content:
Posted: February 17
												FFVII is an absolute smasher of a game.  Part of that for me is nostalgia but the other part is that when you get down to it this is probably the series at its best.  The magic system is flexible, summons are not broken, the characters are more interesting than in other installments...they just really nailed it.  I remember getting this game for Christmas when I was in my early teens and spending most of my winter break absolutely glued to it.  Having played through it a bunch of times over the last 20 years I must concede that it's one which I feel like "I wanna play that game again!" and then find myself saving at the same spot and not picking it up again for a long time because I feel like the beginning of the game drags a lot (pun referencing an early plot point not intentional).However, when the timing is right and I can get into actually going beyond Midgar I get sucked in big time.  Without exaggerating at all I will confess that within the past few years I have completed the game three times and in each of those playthroughs I would sit and play the game for a week straight, putting more hours into it than my full time job.  This game is that good, and it is seriously worth your time if you like RPGs.  There's damn good reason that this is a legendary chapter in the genre with its name spoken with the same reverence of titles like Lunar.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												I was one of those people who actively hated Final Fantasy 7 back in the day thinking that it was just all unnecessary hype (I'm more of an FF6 kind of guy). Having played it now, though, I can see the source of praise. This is a great FF to start with, but it has some problems that make it feel rather dated even more so than the GBA ports of the first handful of games.The story is great and the characters are all well-rounded and interesting and you actually feel for them. Kind of hard to do seeing as the dialog is very dated in terms of translation, but they're just that well-written, I think. And I think that's it's primary selling point -- the story. It's a fun time capsule for what it's worth and it stands up to the going version of FF6 at the time in terms of character and story and it might even be a bit better in some respects given that it has fewer characters, meaning more time to bond with each of them instead of having only one feature per character to go through an arc with like it's done in FF6.That said, I think that the controls and balancing are VERY dated. Command inputs are rather clunky when compared to other FF of the era (glad they fixed this with FF9). Accidentally targeting your ally with an offensive spell just because they walked up to an enemy or healing an enemy because they walked up to an ally is annoying and I wish that Sqaure hadn't experimented with the targeting system the way they did. The menu overlay in-battle as well as navigating through the Materia menu may take a bit of getting used to especially if you forget there's a [SWITCH] command on the button layout.Graphics, while great for their time, are rather dated seeing them in HD. The HD character polygons don't blend as well against pre-rendered low resolution backgrounds and it breaks the immersion a bit and makes things look more dated than they should. I think I'll give the graphics settings a few more tries to get it to emulate the old CRT-TV graphics on the PS1 as close as possible.

												I'm a huge Final Fantasy fan despite the fact that I never got around to playing FF7 in its glory days. I can now testify after finally beating it that the game deserves much of the praise it has received.HOWEVER, if you didn't grow up with Final Fantasy or "old school" JRPGs, you might find this game a little tough to get into due to the conveniences we are now offered in modern games.There are random battles which can't be avoided without the use of third party software. I still highly recommend it, but perhaps consider using a guide if you just want to play it for the story, as it doesn't always hold your hand.I still think FF9 is superior and makes for a better entry point to the Final Fantasy series. I think FF7 gets a bit too much credit. That being said, it is still a fantastic game--one that every RPG fan ought to play.8.9/10

												It's one of the greatest games of all time.  What more needs to be said?Well, unfortunately it's probably the worst version available. content:

												It's one of the greatest games of all time.  What more needs to be said?Well, unfortunately it's probably the worst version available.  The resolution is atrocious, the music is low quality, and the blocky characters have not aged well at all.  Solution?  Modding!...which leads to a host of other problems.  The game looks absolutely beautiful, music sounds great, better battle interface, and holy crap the character models are fantastic.  It's just...mods don't work on steam.  I've been playing the game off of steam in order to enjoy the game, and then load up the unmodded steam version at specific points to catch achievements.  Not to mention it'll crash every now and then.Final verdict?  Unmodded steam version: 6/10.  Still a great game just presented horribly.Modded nonsteam version: 9/10.  Unavoidable crashing and no official support keep it from a 10.I wonder how many people will call me a cheater for 100%ing the game in under 10 hours.
