content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												What is there to say? This is without a doubt my favorite game of all time!It is acclaimed as one of the best RPGs of all time and even as the best of its franchise, it has a grand story coupled with memorable characters and an epic soundtrack to boot.While I can't recommend it enough to everyone that still hasn't played it yet, I suppose that despite all the praise one could give, it still might not be a game for everyone. This is a Turn-Based J-RPG with an Active Time Battle system, and so if you're really not into this genre maybe this isn't the game for you.One of the best qualities of Final Fantasy VII that any of its fans can tell you is its incredible score, what a masterpiece! Nobuo Uematsu - long time Final Fantasy series composer - outdid himself with this soundtrack. It ranges from catchy and happy to sad and sombre pieces, from highly atmospheric to fast paced adrenaline-pumping tunes, from very simple to more complex melodies, it also covers a great amount of musical styles: classical, rock, industrial, techno, reggae, bossa nova... and the list goes on.As for the graphics, this version improves on some things: FMVs have been upscaled to be of better quality when compared to the original PlayStation FMVs, this time around Shaders were added to increase the quality and looks of models and thus eliminating the jagged lines that plagued the PS1 version, and now it also allows the use of resolutions up to 1080p by upscaling the game.Even with these modest improvements, for some the game hasn't aged all that well. And I can agree that to a degree the 2D backgrounds can look very pixelated at times, this setback is more apparent because of the higher resolution the game uses, coupled with the fact that the backgrounds were never redone for this newer version, from what I heard this was because the original 2D Pre-Rendered Background assets were somehow "lost" from Square-Enix archives (or maybe they never even bothered to retain the originals, who knows?) and so, to make higher resolution ones they would have to remake every single one of them from scratch.By releasing on Steam it also came with the now mandatory Achievements, I know some people that really look forward to those.And lastly, I would also like to point out that for those who are computer savvy enough and are willing to put in the extra effort, the exclusive possibility for the PC to Mod this game with all sorts of textures/models/sounds etc. is indeed a big plus for many.In conclusion, Final Fantasy VII is without a doubt one of the best experiences out there to be had, and this PS1 era Classic looks now better than it ever did thanks to it's 2012 version PC re-release.I sincerely hope you'll love it as much as I do.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												After the many years of this game being out and playable in various platforms I have finally taken the time and played this game for the first time.I see a lot of the praise this game gets for the Final Fantasy franchise for the creative and beautiful graphical achievements it did back in the day when the game was first released. It also had quite a deal of depth in the nature of option side-questing things that would give you good rewards for the effort (even though there were some I had not even tried/found.) The musical score definitely had some wonderful pieces in there that definitely set the mood and the feels with the story. Speaking of story this is where I believe it faltered a little. There were some parts that I felt were not needed or were not explained thoroughly for what it was showing. Some parts felt even patched in just to add more to the story and extend the gameplay. If it kept to the main theme of what the game hummed all along the story would have been solid.In the end though: I'd still give it a few more playthroughs just to see all the bits that I had missed for a first playthrough and try different team combos.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												Widely considered to be a true innovation of the series, this game tops the list of a lot of FF players - for good reason. Whilst not my own personal favourite, there is a lot here to love.Although looking a little jaded by today's "modern" standards, back in the day the graphics were thought of as a technological breakthrough; VII is the first true 3D game of the FFs. It may be a little blocky now, but if you really take issue with that then there are plenty of nice-looking mods for the PC version.At its heart, FFVII is an underdog story, telling the tale of a ragtag resistance facing a corrupt organisation (and later on, something even worse - a threat to the entire planet, coming from a villain who is without a doubt the most recogniseable of the series.) The characters are (mostly...I'm ignoring the existence of Cait Sith for the purpose of this review) a likeable bunch, with mixed backstories and rather good development. Cloud comes off as a little dull and bland to begin with, but he comes into his own later on. Occasionally the plot may take a little turn for the confusing and wacky, but it's largely resolved to a clean degree (anything that isn't is explained more in-depth through the spin offs.) The villains are very entertaining, and in some cases you really end up hating them - which is the point, naturally.The Materia system is a nice touch - any character can equip any skill, and the more you battle the more powerful these skills become, and the more often you can use them. There is a real sense of progression and accomplishment.Of course, as expected by now, the music is another accomplishment. This game probably has my favourite "standard" boss battle theme of the lot, except from maybe that of VI. The town themes largely have their own feel (an East Asian theme for Wutai, a tribal one for Cosmo Canyon, etc.) Also, "One-Winged Angel." Those of you who have played this before know that I need say nothing else.This is the "entry game" for a lot of players, and it does give a very nice feel of what to expect from the other games. It wasn't afraid to take risks with both technological boundaries and storytelling, and should be admired for that reason alone. As I mentioned - not my favourite, but no less of a gaming classic.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												I'm glad to see this game come to PC, since I don't own any consoles and I've heard my friends say for years how great of a game it was.  As a result, when it became available for a remarkably good price of four USD I picked it up.That said, they could have done a much better job on porting this game.  By the numbers:1.  The controls are permanently set, and if you don't own a gamepad you're permanently saddled with the most non-intuitive control scheme I've ever seen, where the binds make little to no sense and are scattered all over the keyboard.2.  The client is inherently unstable, to a point where I suffered from 4(!) crashes by the time I had finished the first battle.  I'm talking complete crash to desktop restarts here.  3.  In addition to this glaring problem, the client hangs severely even when next to no load is being placed on the system.  The first fight, as mentioned earlier, while not overly complicated and only requiring a total of 4 attacks including the ones against the player character took me over five minutes to complete.  Now I know that I don't have the best computer in the world, especially when I'm playing on my laptop like I am, but this system has no difficulty handling modern games.  It should be taking FFVII and bending it over the table, but instead it hangs... especially in the CGI sequences where I had to use CTRL+ALT+DEL to force close the client a few times because the video had picked a spot and froze while the TERRIBLE 8 bit sounding music was on a 2 second loop that would make the most patient man in the world go insane.To sum up, while I was very interested in playing this game, and I am sure that if it is patched to a playable state it will be excellent and enjoyable, I simply cannot recommend it to anyone in its current condition.  Ya let me down Square Enix.

number of helpful: 73 of 142 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
												Final Fantasy VII is basically the first game that I ever pre-ordered in my life when purchasing a game. This was when I was just a little kid, and was quite excited about the Japanese release of Final Fantasy VII. It took me months to beat this game on first try, and about 8 years ago, I bought myself an English version of it and beat it in 1 week. I still remember myself doing the final battle over and over, as it was very entertaining back then. And now Final Fantasy VII has got some HD treatment (Not sure I can call it a full HD....as it appears only the character models look decent and the background looks quite distorted still as the original. Meh, prob not a HD. Doesn't matter though) and what can I say. This game just never gets old. As I bought the Japanese version of FFVII on day one, I just had to buy this one on day one as well, as a hardcore, long time Final Fantasy fan.Music is just outstandingly epic. Even to this very day, I still listen to "You Can Hear the Cry of the Planet" 


YouTube™ Video: Final Fantasy VII - You Can Hear the Cry of the Planet [HQ] 

			Views: 421,005		

			Final Fantasy 7 - You Can Hear the Cry of the Planet [HQ]		

Which is possibly one of the most powerful music ever composed by mankind. Gameplay. Well, what can I say. I beat this game twice, in both Japanese and English versions, played the final boss battle for over 50 hours. This game, is almost like a standard of RPG. Am I exaggerating somehow? Not even. Story. Well? I have never encountered an RPG that has a better story than this game. It is purely filled with the best elements that the best games normally possess. The only other thing that I can say about this game is that this is truly the best game ever made.No wait, it is actually more than just a "best game". This is, a Mona Lisa of all RPGs.10 out of 10 = Masterpiece

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												So after reading a lot of reviews about all the trouble people have had with this game and with square I checked out all the positive reviews and figured it was worth a buy on sale. This game brings me back to my high school days and I have beaten it many times. I still have the original for my PS but the first disk is damaged and wont let me play in Midgar.Anyway, I have had zero issues with setting up my square account and it only takes one log in to play so that hasn't been an issue for me at all. I said "no thank you" to having cloud saves available and I will never use the character boost, to me it is a pretty dumb addition to the game.The cleaned up graphics took some getting used to and the controls on the keyboard are a little funky for sure so if you can set up a controller I would recomend it. That being said the characters now do look nice without funky angles shooting out of thier bodies. Music sounds great I am guessing it has been fixed since so many complained about it. If you loved this game when you were younger or want to play it now because you never have and it is on sale, go for it! Still an amazing game and I love that I can play it for what seems like the 100th time and still love every second.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												This is one masterpiece of RPG right here. It has great story, characters, music, and it's fun to make your own decisions to see how everything turns out. Unlike other RPGs this one has pretty fast paced battles, and implements mechanics that other RPGs don't, making this game unique. The default PC controls can be a little difficult to get used to, but are easy to use in most circumstances and you can change them any way you like. One feature I like is the Limit Break feature, because getting the crap beat out of you then taking your revenge with a Braver or Cross Slash Limit Break can be very satisfiying. I can't wait to get farther in the game, and I would personally recommend this game to any fan of RPGs or Final Fantasy. My Score: 9.7

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Underneath the crusty PC port is the game I love, shining like a jewel. But, with cloudsaving that, more often that not, doesn't work, an immensely rocky entry because of an account requirement for a single-player  game that should not have been a concern even months after launch on Steam, and multiple progress stealing crashes, FF7 for PC is not a game I can recommend, even as a diehard fan. It is just too much hassle, both in and out of the game.Update: Not really as upset with the game, but I still don't recommend the game, even to my friends. People who love Final Fantasy will play this regardless, just as I have. I don't encounter nearly as many crashes as I used to because I play it on a stronger computer, but have still encountered some. Cloudsaving is still a consistent problem, however. Though it works more than it doesn't, the times it doesn't are frustrating and can go on for as long as an entire day. The irony in this is that the player requires an account or linking of Facebook info, in part, because of this feature. To force a player to go to such lengths just to play a game that never required this in the first place for a feature that works so infrequently is not a good justification. This is not even mentioning that Steam has these functions covered, should the effort be put in. In text, it seems like a poor port.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												I didn't play video games as a child so I missed out on a lot of classics. Had a bit of trouble with the version on the PSN, tried using an emulator on my laptop but it kept giving me audio trouble and I just felt frustrated and bored.I bought this  version because I wanted to play the rest of the story myself and the remake announcement reminded me how much I love Aerith. I replayed all my progress from the past few months in a few days.The PC version is great, really easy to play with a gamepad. I didn't miss save states or any of the extras from the emulated version. It really sucked me into the story for the first time. Initially I was frustrated with the pre-rendered backgrounds but they grew on me. Very beautiful. It's really easy to get pulled into this universe.Gripes:I'm annoyed you have to make a square enix account to play the game. The site goes down all the time. The cloud saving rarely works and I reccomend turning it off if you are going to be saving a lot (like grinding on the world map etc). Also I didn't use the character boost because I didn't need it. I may try it on another playthrough though.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												Ok, I was really doubting this game. I thought it wasn't going to be as all the fanboys says it would be. "OH MAH GAWD THIS IS BEST GAME EBER" basically that. So I played alittle and I'm like, it's alright. But let's say a year later, a really good youtube channel (The Completionists') were doing a special on FF7. Since I saw that, I'm like, "Hey! Why not finish this game so I don't get any spoilers from the video!" It jurastically changed from that. I couldn't stop playing. It's like it was sucking me into this game. Although if it weren't for the PS1 music patch for this game, I wouldn't be here and playing this version, because I would be playing on the PS1 (but if I would have, it would take years because I never get on my PS1 on a daily basis). The graphics are a step up, and if you see a side-by-side comparison of the original vs this one, you only see that the character models are more high-def, and the pre-rendered graphics are displayed in a better resolution. Other than that, there is no difference gameplay-wise, except for the SUPER-OP character booster. What it does is that it makes any 3 of your characters in your party right now have 9999 hp and 999 mp (I'm not sure on the gil, it wasn't 99,999 but it was like 60,000 or something like that) other than that, it doesn't give you status buffs, nothing else. Just that (preety weird if you ask me, but you know, Square Enix will make anything worse *Puts on sunglasses*). It will also feel weird the first times using the keyboard, and I have found some mini-games unplayable when using my layout (A is OK, B is CANCEL, D is MENU, Space for START, Shift for SWITCH, Page Up and Down for left and right bumpers 'PS1 controller') and it is real nice that you can use an XBOX 360 controller even though I don't have one, I just use my PS3 controller and have some software to emulate the 360 (I'm not going in-depth about that). You can also use a PS2 controller, but you need an adapter (the best way to play if you ask me, but again, I don't have an adapter). In conclusion, it is the best Final Fantasy I've ever played, but not the best game I ever played.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												There's no doubt that this game is a classic, whether you like or not. But if it's actually held up all these years, that's a little more subjective.Expect blocky character models and low resolution (but still quite good looking, IMO) static backgrounds, and all the spelling and grammar errors from the original PC release are still here. However, the music has been replaced, the original MIDI soundtrack is now the same music used in the Playstation release, and the game overall has been optimized to run on new systems. The actual game mechanics and combat system are solid, and the story is also still good.If you've never played the game, don't come in expecting something that can stack up to a game released today in terms of graphical quality. If you can look past its age there's still a great game and plenty of time to be wasted in it, though. If you're looking for a nostalgia kick then it's definitely worth the price as well.The only detractor from what's overall a good game is the extra layer of DRM, requiring a Square Enix account, but considering it can be activated with your Steam account and ignored once you set it up the first time, it's hardly a hassle.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Underneath the crusty PC port is the game I love, shining like a jewel. But, with cloudsaving that, more often that not, doesn't work, an immensely rocky entry because of an account requirement for a single-player  game that should not have been a concern even months after launch on Steam, and multiple progress stealing crashes, FF7 for PC is not a game I can recommend, even as a diehard fan. It is just too much hassle, both in and out of the game.Update: Not really as upset with the game, but I still don't recommend the game, even to my friends. People who love Final Fantasy will play this regardless, just as I have. I don't encounter nearly as many crashes as I used to because I play it on a stronger computer, but have still encountered some. Cloudsaving is still a consistent problem, however. Though it works more than it doesn't, the times it doesn't are frustrating and can go on for as long as an entire day. The irony in this is that the player requires an account or linking of Facebook info, in part, because of this feature. To force a player to go to such lengths just to play a game that never required this in the first place for a feature that works so infrequently is not a good justification. This is not even mentioning that Steam has these functions covered, should the effort be put in. In text, it seems like a poor port.

												Final Fantasy VII is a game that I am pretty sure everyone has heard about. It is probably one of the most overrated RPGs to exist, but even so, it is actually a really great game. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												What could I ever write here that hasn't been said before. I remember putting in 70+ hours into this game when it first arrived to Playstation back in 1997. What I can say is that the PC port, while not the HD remake we always hoped for, provides a little more polish than it's 1997 counterpart and remains a distinct landmark in the Final Fantasy series.Graphics & Story: For the era it was produced in, FF7 had compelling graphics along with full motion video and a great cast of unique and interesting characters. Famous scenes such as Sephiroth's walk through the flame engulfed Nibelheim or the fateful moment in the Forgotten Capital provide the gamer with the type of immersion that has tried to be replicated through numerous games following FF7's release. Music: With Nobuo Uematsu at the helm, there was no doubt that the soundtrack would be any less than great. One-Winged Angel is one of the most memorable compositions in Video Game history and Aerith's theme provided the perfect emotional tone for that pivotal moment in the Forgotten Capital.Again not much more I can say but that I can't wait for the HD remake - 10/10Update: Mar 16, 2015Finally finished my 100% achievement file. Hoping we hear something regarding a sequel or remake in 2017 on the game's 20th anniversary. Give Final Fantasy VII a try if you've never played it before. This classic is certainly worth the time.Update: June 16, 2015Well holy hell....the remake is happening.

												This is one masterpiece of RPG right here. It has great story, characters, music, and it's fun to make your own decisions to see how everything turns out. Unlike other RPGs this one has pretty fast paced battles, and implements mechanics that other RPGs don't, making this game unique. The default PC controls can be a little difficult to get used to, but are easy to use in most circumstances and you can change them any way you like. One feature I like is the Limit Break feature, because getting the crap beat out of you then taking your revenge with a Braver or Cross Slash Limit Break can be very satisfiying. I can't wait to get farther in the game, and I would personally recommend this game to any fan of RPGs or Final Fantasy. My Score: 9.7

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												Goes without saying that Final Fantasy VII was considered by some to be the best RPG on the Playstation 1. It's reputation has started to decrease in recent years with some people claiming it was always overrated, but it remains one of my personal favourite RPGs. The story and characters are still gripping and interesting, the (newly patched) PS1 soundtrack is still amazing and the game has one of the best equipment systems in the entire Final Fantasy series.The polished HD models for the PC re-release can be distracting at times, but still look a lot nicer than their PS1 emulated counterparts. I will say that after playing the game across PS1/PS2/PS3 for over 15 years, I had no idea the character models were ever supposed to have mouths outside of cutscenes. The joys of HD models!This is an absolute steal at €7 or lower, let alone the €4.41 they're asking for in the 2013 Xmas sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												"Final Fantasy Seven, stylized as FINAL FANTASY VII) is a role-playing video game developed by Square (now Square Enix) as the seventh installment in the Final Fantasy series. It was released in 1997 for the Sony PlayStation. As with many installments of the Final Fantasy series, Final Fantasy VII consists primarily of three major areas: an overworld map, field maps, and a battle screen. The overworld map is a 3D model, featuring a scaled-down version of the game's fictional world, across which the player travels between the game's locations. As with preceding games in the series, the world map can be traversed by foot, on chocobos and in an airship or sea vessel.On field maps, characters are directed across realistically scaled environments, consisting of 2D pre-rendered backgrounds which represent locations such as towns or forests.The battle screen is a 3D representation of an area, such as a building's interior or an open grassland, in which the player commands the characters in battles against CPU-controlled enemies." -  en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Final_Fantasy_VIIThis is a turn-based RPG, that is when in battle, you take a turn and then the enemy takes a turn. It can be tedious at times as most RPGs can be and is filled with out of the way side quests and mini-games. The game does get more difficult the further you get into the storyline, however you can always go out and over level whichever boss you happen to be stuck on. Though despite its the repetitiveness and blocky graphics, Final Fantasy VII still has some of the most memorable story lines and characters to date. I would definitely reccomend this game to the younger generation or anyone with a budget looking for something fulfilling and entertaining to play.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												If you haven't played Final Fantasy 7, then you probably don't like JRPGs anyways. That said, it's probably the quintessential posterchild for modern day JRPGs, and one of the games that helped bring them to the mainstream. Final Fantasy 7 is easily one of the better JRPGs ever made, but also one of the most overrated. Also keep in mind, this game requires you to be always online, for DRM purposes, but gives no real benefits to this requirement other than Achievements. If you are wanting to play a JRPG, and are unable to find an original disc of this game, then this is the best alternative.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2013
												FF7 was the most groundbreaking RPG of its era. It was the edge that gave Sony dominance in the console market, the hammerblow to Nintendo's pride and the straw that broke Sega's back. It represents the pinnacle of Sqauresoft's history and in the eyes of many, no single player RPG has come close since. It also spawned one of the most recognisable bad guys in gaming history. The heavy anime style gives it a very Japanese feel, Nobuo's music is fantastic, from the energetic guitar based battle themes to the heartwrenchingly sorrowful Aerith's theme. A game that excited a generation, filling our heads with unforgettable memories of an awesome, immersive experience. It's a must play for any hardcore RPG fanatic.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												Ok, I was really doubting this game. I thought it wasn't going to be as all the fanboys says it would be. "OH MAH GAWD THIS IS BEST GAME EBER" basically that. So I played alittle and I'm like, it's alright. But let's say a year later, a really good youtube channel (The Completionists') were doing a special on FF7. Since I saw that, I'm like, "Hey! Why not finish this game so I don't get any spoilers from the video!" It jurastically changed from that. I couldn't stop playing. It's like it was sucking me into this game. Although if it weren't for the PS1 music patch for this game, I wouldn't be here and playing this version, because I would be playing on the PS1 (but if I would have, it would take years because I never get on my PS1 on a daily basis). The graphics are a step up, and if you see a side-by-side comparison of the original vs this one, you only see that the character models are more high-def, and the pre-rendered graphics are displayed in a better resolution. Other than that, there is no difference gameplay-wise, except for the SUPER-OP character booster. What it does is that it makes any 3 of your characters in your party right now have 9999 hp and 999 mp (I'm not sure on the gil, it wasn't 99,999 but it was like 60,000 or something like that) other than that, it doesn't give you status buffs, nothing else. Just that (preety weird if you ask me, but you know, Square Enix will make anything worse *Puts on sunglasses*). It will also feel weird the first times using the keyboard, and I have found some mini-games unplayable when using my layout (A is OK, B is CANCEL, D is MENU, Space for START, Shift for SWITCH, Page Up and Down for left and right bumpers 'PS1 controller') and it is real nice that you can use an XBOX 360 controller even though I don't have one, I just use my PS3 controller and have some software to emulate the 360 (I'm not going in-depth about that). You can also use a PS2 controller, but you need an adapter (the best way to play if you ask me, but again, I don't have an adapter). In conclusion, it is the best Final Fantasy I've ever played, but not the best game I ever played.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												With the upcoming remake of Final Fantasy VII there will definitely be mixed reviews about which is better. the remake or the original? The least any newcomer to the Final Fantasy franchise can do is to play the original first before any potential shortcomings the remake may have to offer.For most the 1997 release was their first Final Fantasy and is therefore special to them. Upon replaying FFVII on Steam I had such an overwealming nostalgia which quite honestly surprised me. I could remember everything so clearly even after almost 20 years since first playing it. Everything was the same as I had imagined it even back then, though I will say that this updated version has a few things which had been changed. Certain dialogue and so on, though I don't think this is such a major issue to many.The Materia system is still top notch, though now I am certainly more cautious with what I use instead of throwing everything on a character just because I had it, as I would have done on my first playthrough. Plenty of mini games to keep one entertained when sick of grinding or just want to take a break from the story. The battle system was exciting for its time, especially with the added Limit Breaks which were a huge improvement on VI's Desperation Attacks. which were quite frankly rubbish. The fact you could save the special attack for a better time as well as evolve them into better ones by using them was a reason to try out every character, just to see what they did. With the new release, the old battle system will certainly be dead and buried so we can probably say goodbye to many of the epic moves and abilities we once encountered.The soundtrack? 11/10. Nuff said.If anything, this is one of my least favourite Final Fantasies in the franchise, though it was my first. Even though I prefer most of the others, this truly is a special game that will not only challenge you, but become a part of you in the process. It can be a bit of an eyesore to look at in this day and age, but if you love a story rich game then there's nothing really stopping you from buying this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												There's no doubt that this game is a classic, whether you like or not. But if it's actually held up all these years, that's a little more subjective.Expect blocky character models and low resolution (but still quite good looking, IMO) static backgrounds, and all the spelling and grammar errors from the original PC release are still here. However, the music has been replaced, the original MIDI soundtrack is now the same music used in the Playstation release, and the game overall has been optimized to run on new systems. The actual game mechanics and combat system are solid, and the story is also still good.If you've never played the game, don't come in expecting something that can stack up to a game released today in terms of graphical quality. If you can look past its age there's still a great game and plenty of time to be wasted in it, though. If you're looking for a nostalgia kick then it's definitely worth the price as well.The only detractor from what's overall a good game is the extra layer of DRM, requiring a Square Enix account, but considering it can be activated with your Steam account and ignored once you set it up the first time, it's hardly a hassle.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												If you haven't played Final Fantasy 7, then you probably don't like JRPGs anyways. That said, it's probably the quintessential posterchild for modern day JRPGs, and one of the games that helped bring them to the mainstream. Final Fantasy 7 is easily one of the better JRPGs ever made, but also one of the most overrated. Also keep in mind, this game requires you to be always online, for DRM purposes, but gives no real benefits to this requirement other than Achievements. If you are wanting to play a JRPG, and are unable to find an original disc of this game, then this is the best alternative.

												This game is definately one of the best RPGs EVER!A game is so much more that state of the art visuals like you see nowadays.Playing only a few minutes you can see that the music and the story create an atmosphere that sucks you in immedately. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												I was one of those people who never played the game when it released, as I did not own a PS1. I now see why so many people list it as "greatest game ever". I wouldn't rate it as my "greatest video game ever" but it is certainly a very good game. My first experience with the game was around 1999 and even then I felt like these graphics were pretty dated compared to games such as Ocarina of Time, but the gameplay still holds up well in 2017. I have not finished the game yet but have put in a lot of hours, and so far the story is very good, and the gameplay itself has held up well. If you're a younger gamer I'm not sure if you'll be able to appreciate the highly 1990s nature of this game, but I grew up on Genesis/SNES/N64 and can say that this is definitely one of the games of its generation that have aged well.For the people complaining about the Square Enix servers, I created my account when I first started the game and immediately unchecked the "Cloud Saves" option in settings, and have never had an issue with trying to play the game other than one crash when I was near the end of the "Disc 1" (of 3) content of the original release.

												As an avid FF player, I have to say that this is my favourite game in the series.The turn based battle system is great. If you like RPGs and do not mind reading vast amounts of dialogue, then I highly reccommend checking this game out! If the news of the remake has brought you here, then give the original a chance! You will not be disappointed.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												I don't know where to start, but FFVII is one of my fav game for years now. When I first met with the title Final Fantasy, it was on my PSX many years ago. Right now the visuals are outdated. Ofcourse they are, because the game is 16-17 years old (almost an adult). But still one of the best jrpg out there in my opinion. You could ask me, that why is it so good, I will tell it, but remember, these are only MY opinions, not facts. First, i loved the whole story, the flashbacks, backgrounds of the characters. Second, i rly loved almost every music in the game (Imo Cosmo Canyon Theme is the best). And the third, that i like the most and miss in many other games, these are the mini games. For me the most fun was the Chocobo racing and the Chocobo farm. And one more thing, if I'm correct, then FFVII was the Game of the year in 1997. And one little thing, if anyone saw the movie Final Fantasy VII: Advent Children, but never tried the game, then I highly recommend atleast 1 playthrough.Update:Oh boy and I'm still waiting for the FF7 Remake. Sadly it will be a PS4 exclusive title, but for me still a must have and the only reason to buy a PS4.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Let me preface by saying that Final Fantasy VII is the last American release (by order of release date) that I have completed in the series, so far.  It is a classic, in that other video games in the role-playing genre are still compared to it today--with good reason.  I loved this game when it was released over fifteen years ago, and I still love it today.So let's focus on the negatives, starting with the most egregious problems: whomever was placed in charge of reprogramming this game for the computer put new mouths on those characters that lacked them (i.e. Sephiroth, Jessie, etc.).  Unfortunately, they used just the one mouth position: a whorish "O."  Suddenly every character with a new mouth has taken on the appearance of a blow-up pleasure doll, an image that is only reinforced by the early 3D animation.  It is NOT a pretty sight.For the Uninitiated: Players might be frustrated with some of the unintentional difficulties of an EARLY attempt at 3D gaming, specifically movement.  There is something of a learning curve with materia.  The graphics are dated.  Some of the mini-games are terrible (though most are thankfully avoidable).  I would also highly recommend purchasing (or at least looking up via internet) a guide, as not every quest is terribly clear.With that said, there are mods that can fix the mouth problem.  I am also grateful that some of the more distracting translation errors have been fixed since the game's first US release.  Overall, I'd recommend this game highly to anyone who's played it and wants to relive it... and for anyone else who wants to experience a classic.But seriously.  Get the mouth mod.  Sephiroth with that "O" face is just creepy.  Well... creepier.

There aren't many RPG's that can top this one.  It's totally worth every hard earned dollar that you put forth for this title.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												In my opinion; the game is a defining classic for the RPG genre.My first experience of the Final Fantasy series was with this title back in 1997 and at the time it was absolutely incredible. This was different to any other game I had played, the story was rich and enthralling, the score and graphics were both bright and vibrant but also moody and atmospheric when the scene dictated it and there was so much FMV that it felt like you were playing an interactive movie. The variation in scenery, the number of side activities, the secrets and the challenges keep this game alive for days longer than the main story (which is fairly large in it's own right as it is).Every Final Fantasy fan has their favourite and I'm not going to argue with anyone that doesn't agree; I have played and continue to play every one of the main series titles I can lay my hands on and although each of them has their charms I would still rate VII as my first choice.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												As someone who just missed this game when it came out, I was worried that I wouldn't be able to enjoy it so many years later, especially with so much hype around it.  Much to my great excitement, it not only held up, but far exceeded my expectations!  The story was great, with so many more twists than the lone one everyone knows, and the characters really stand out as some of the most colorful I've experienced.  If you're like me and have always meant to play this game but just haven't had a chance, snag yourself a copy and enjoy!(A note: The cloud saving is off by default and very finicky.  If you only intend to play on one computer, this won't be a problem, as it will just save locally.  If you plan on playing across a couple computers, you should go into the settings from the launch screen and enable cloud saving before you start to save yourself some trouble.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Let me preface by saying that Final Fantasy VII is the last American release (by order of release date) that I have completed in the series, so far.  It is a classic, in that other video games in the role-playing genre are still compared to it today--with good reason.  I loved this game when it was released over fifteen years ago, and I still love it today.So let's focus on the negatives, starting with the most egregious problems: whomever was placed in charge of reprogramming this game for the computer put new mouths on those characters that lacked them (i.e. Sephiroth, Jessie, etc.).  Unfortunately, they used just the one mouth position: a whorish "O."  Suddenly every character with a new mouth has taken on the appearance of a blow-up pleasure doll, an image that is only reinforced by the early 3D animation.  It is NOT a pretty sight.For the Uninitiated: Players might be frustrated with some of the unintentional difficulties of an EARLY attempt at 3D gaming, specifically movement.  There is something of a learning curve with materia.  The graphics are dated.  Some of the mini-games are terrible (though most are thankfully avoidable).  I would also highly recommend purchasing (or at least looking up via internet) a guide, as not every quest is terribly clear.With that said, there are mods that can fix the mouth problem.  I am also grateful that some of the more distracting translation errors have been fixed since the game's first US release.  Overall, I'd recommend this game highly to anyone who's played it and wants to relive it... and for anyone else who wants to experience a classic.But seriously.  Get the mouth mod.  Sephiroth with that "O" face is just creepy.  Well... creepier.

												I absolutely loved this game on the PS1 and when this was released on steam my wallet jumped out of my pants from the other room and started to fill out my payment information! I was petrified to see this very odd encounter that was unfolding before my very eyes. Once the payment was complete and of course printing out my confirmation email and carefully writing down my confirmation number for my personal records I quickly installed and attempted to play my newly but oddly obtained copy of Final Fantasy 7!  I checked all the options within the launcher to make sure the upmost  compatibility. I click play and my screen goes black...appears this very ominous logo on my screen "SQUARESOFT". I wait.....I wait some more....I click, I press ESC, my heart begins to race as this mysterious logo just stays on my screen! I rapidly start spamming all the keys on my keyboard! nothing happens! I finally Ctrl+alt+tab and I become blinded by this blueish-green screen with a few options. I choose "Open Task Manager" and a new window appears! I decide to put this horrible experience to an end, I had to make this my seventh and final attempt to live this fantasy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2013
												Even after 16 years since it's original release, Final Fantasy VII is, without a doubt, one of the absolute best RPGs in existence. It's characters, story, and gameplay are some of the finest the JRPG market has ever had. This is a game that anyone should play through at least once. This port of the classic is definently worth purchasing for both veterans of FFVII and first-timers alike. Cloud saving is a very nifty feature that allows you to play your saves on multiple computers, although there are occasionaly network issues with it. The character booster will be a great tool for those who want to observe the story rather than focus on hours of grinding. The textures have been polished up nicely, and the FMVs look a lot smoother than before. Overall, this is a gaming experience worth having, and this is the perfect version for those who wish to try it for the first time. My only recommendation: Make sure you have a controller, as the standard keyboard controls are a bit wonky.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												I'll make it simple.The DRM has turned me off from what should have been a lovely trip down memory lane. What blows me away is that I cannot even play a single player game without either giving out my Facebook credentials or creating a Square Enix account. Games for Windows Live did not work and neither will this. Learn something Square.Not only that, but the 'reset password' function on your website does not even work so I cannot recover an account that I apparently made with you. AND. I can't login using my Facebook unless I agree to let them post on my behalf. In my infrequently humble opinion, this is a mood killer. You know why? Because the only thing that let me play the game was allowing it to hijack my Facebook. Final Fantasy sucked after 10, you're not going to piggyback on my account just to talk about how great your recent 'products' are (if they could be called that). So needless to say, I revoked that permission and uninstalled.I loved this game growing up and still love it and nothing breaks my heart more than to have spent money on it and to realize that I'm going to download a cracked copy anyways just to bypass this incredibly uneccessary and ridiculous DRM. Avoid this version of the game everyone. Unless you have a Square Enix account handy (hopefully you remember your password) or have no problem giving away all your details on Facebook to a company that believes you cannot be trusted with a re-release of a PC port of one of their most popular titles ever and arguably one of the most popular RPGs ever released on the planet, you're not missing out.Dust off your PSX or PS2 and get an original copy. It will be less of a hassle than running it in this garbage version.I can't describe how thoroughly disappointed I am in you Square.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												Final Fantasy VII is about a stuggling jack of all trades who, at one point, questions his sexual outlook. After spending some time living as a lady in the slums, he realises he isn't meant for such roots and decides to wage war on the local pimp who ♥♥♥♥♥s out woman as if they were objects.Together, with the help of his female companions, they strike down the slumdog pimp and soon set their sites on bigger motions in works, Why stop the lesser evils when they can overthrow a government who oppress their people in order to gain monopoly for themselves?Our hero, Cloud, then sets off, hesitantly, on his way to see change brought to the land and its people. Through trying times, he bonds well with those around him and gains invaluable strength and bravey through out. Soon the group learn they are in way over their heads when they come across a talking dog, who's tail is constantly on fire (he doesn't seem to mind, though), and through the actions of said dog, they learn of a great evil at work. Sephiroth.Sephiroth was once a mentor, an idol and symbol of hope to Cloud, and the world at large. However, after learning of dark secrets kept from him, Sephiroth seeks vegence on those who wronged him - the Goverment known as Shinra. He learns he is nothing more than a lab experiment and that his mother was an alien. Naturally, Sephiroth is all like "hold the damn phone here, guys... The hell is this?" - having never met his mother, his desire to be passionately held becomes unbearable, to the point of dangerous obsession. He even steals her dead head.So, Cloud and his merry crew, who at this point are like "... This guy is mental, he's trying to summon a meteor with magic to kill everyone on the planet because he has mother issues... We should really do something about that", go about in search of an even greater evil. That being Septhiroth.After some forsakend, unforgiveable, and downright ♥♥♥♥ing twisted,♥♥♥♥♥♥sucking, lego ♥♥♥♥ing, herpes ridden deaths and Cloud loosing his mind, because, you know... He isn't actually the person he thinks he is, they confront Septhiroth, give him a slap on the rest and tell him "Mummy said you should be a good boy now".That's pretty much Final Fantasy VII, oh and there's also naked men bouncing around on beds, girls dressed as beads... I mean BEES, some weird ninja girl obsessed with stealing and a dude with a gun for and arm who suffers with suicidal tendancy. Oh and there is Zack Fair. And snow boarding, there's also a dating simulation thing in there. Did I mention future seeing stuffed animals with cats on their heads who are controlled by some dude in a goverment building?9/10.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												There are no words for how disappointed I am with this version of FF7. Required log ins, midi music tracks instead of the playstation ones, grainy super low-res video, stretched rather then up-scaled textures and world maps, and last but not least a confusing control scheme. This isn't a 2013 rerelease, its the exact same pc port from 1998 with the only differances being achievements and that you have to log in now.  Other then that Square-Enix didn't even put in the most trival effort to improve the game. Thankfully there are modders out there doing what Square-Enix is too lazy to and much more. If you don't mind losing the trainer and achievements I'd look into the various graphic and gameplay enchancement mods availible on the net to make the game at very least more playable.Edit: The midi music was due to a bad download. After deleting the local files and reinstalling I found I had PSX music. Still not going to recommend this game though, as the only way I found it playable is with the Tifas Bootleg mod compolation.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												Final Fantasy VII is about a stuggling jack of all trades who, at one point, questions his sexual outlook. After spending some time living as a lady in the slums, he realises he isn't meant for such roots and decides to wage war on the local pimp who ♥♥♥♥♥s out woman as if they were objects.Together, with the help of his female companions, they strike down the slumdog pimp and soon set their sites on bigger motions in works, Why stop the lesser evils when they can overthrow a government who oppress their people in order to gain monopoly for themselves?Our hero, Cloud, then sets off, hesitantly, on his way to see change brought to the land and its people. Through trying times, he bonds well with those around him and gains invaluable strength and bravey through out. Soon the group learn they are in way over their heads when they come across a talking dog, who's tail is constantly on fire (he doesn't seem to mind, though), and through the actions of said dog, they learn of a great evil at work. Sephiroth.Sephiroth was once a mentor, an idol and symbol of hope to Cloud, and the world at large. However, after learning of dark secrets kept from him, Sephiroth seeks vegence on those who wronged him - the Goverment known as Shinra. He learns he is nothing more than a lab experiment and that his mother was an alien. Naturally, Sephiroth is all like "hold the damn phone here, guys... The hell is this?" - having never met his mother, his desire to be passionately held becomes unbearable, to the point of dangerous obsession. He even steals her dead head.So, Cloud and his merry crew, who at this point are like "... This guy is mental, he's trying to summon a meteor with magic to kill everyone on the planet because he has mother issues... We should really do something about that", go about in search of an even greater evil. That being Septhiroth.After some forsakend, unforgiveable, and downright ♥♥♥♥ing twisted,♥♥♥♥♥♥sucking, lego ♥♥♥♥ing, herpes ridden deaths and Cloud loosing his mind, because, you know... He isn't actually the person he thinks he is, they confront Septhiroth, give him a slap on the rest and tell him "Mummy said you should be a good boy now".That's pretty much Final Fantasy VII, oh and there's also naked men bouncing around on beds, girls dressed as beads... I mean BEES, some weird ninja girl obsessed with stealing and a dude with a gun for and arm who suffers with suicidal tendancy. Oh and there is Zack Fair. And snow boarding, there's also a dating simulation thing in there. Did I mention future seeing stuffed animals with cats on their heads who are controlled by some dude in a goverment building?9/10.

Posted: September 12, 2014
												I absolutely loved this game on the PS1 and when this was released on steam my wallet jumped out of my pants from the other room and started to fill out my payment information! I was petrified to see this very odd encounter that was unfolding before my very eyes. Once the payment was complete and of course printing out my confirmation email and carefully writing down my confirmation number for my personal records I quickly installed and attempted to play my newly but oddly obtained copy of Final Fantasy 7!  I checked all the options within the launcher to make sure the upmost  compatibility. I click play and my screen goes black...appears this very ominous logo on my screen "SQUARESOFT". I wait.....I wait some more....I click, I press ESC, my heart begins to race as this mysterious logo just stays on my screen! I rapidly start spamming all the keys on my keyboard! nothing happens! I finally Ctrl+alt+tab and I become blinded by this blueish-green screen with a few options. I choose "Open Task Manager" and a new window appears! I decide to put this horrible experience to an end, I had to make this my seventh and final attempt to live this fantasy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Well well, what must I say about this game, voted as one of the greatest video games of all time, seen as one of the best games in the Final Fantasy franchise, and known for its colossal impact on gaming? Well. If your a gamer like me, who plays games by heart and not eyes (heart being story and eyes being blown away from games featuring explosions guns and violence), then this is a game for YOU. Before I go in depth of how amazing this game is, I must tell you how I got into the Final Fantasy franchise. As a kid I shied away from the series because honestly the roman numerals in the games was just too confusing and at the time I was a strict Nintendo fanboy. Times have changed, I am no longer a strict Nintendo fanboy though I still am but now I accept other games. I gave Final Fantasy 1 a try and quickly got hooked. Then I moved on to 2 and at that point it was clear I am now a Final Fantasy fanboy. I then went to 3, and at the time (all of this happened recently btw), there was a Steam deal going on. The Square Enix publisher discount stuff. Final Fantasy 7 and 8 were in that, and I had some spare change and decided it would be a fantastic idea to purchase two Final Fantasy games with the highest amount of reputation within the franchise. I did not regret that decision, it was clearly worth buying. Now, back to our discussion on why the game is great. This game, is addictive. No, not addictive in a bad way like Minecraft (You know, playing all day losing your mind). Addictive story-wise. The story in this game is ENGAGING ON SOO MANY LEVELS. IT DOES NOT AT ALL FEEL LIKE I AM PLAYING A GAME ITSELF, BUT WATCHING A MOVIE WITH A DEEP STORY AND AMAZING CUTSCENES AND FLASHBACKS. The gameplay itself is interesting and apealing to me. When I play the game, I don't care for the gameplay, I am anxious to see what happens next in the story. When a game gets you feeling like this, it is clear why Final Fantasy 7 is regarded or arguably one of the greatest games of all time. Its games like this one we just don't see anymore, it really does suck because I myself wish that these games with all these DLC's and micro-transactions would just STOP and use this game as an analogy to what a perfect game should be. This game is a classic, I had no problems with it other than how frustrating it was to get my freakin Square Enix account setup. If you can get past that one problem, you got yourself a perfect beautiful game right here. In conclusion, I say if you are one who enjoys a great story with fun gameplay, then this game is worth your 12 dollars. Or, at the moment if the deal is still going, its half off.

Posted: May 2, 2014
												As someone who just missed this game when it came out, I was worried that I wouldn't be able to enjoy it so many years later, especially with so much hype around it.  Much to my great excitement, it not only held up, but far exceeded my expectations!  The story was great, with so many more twists than the lone one everyone knows, and the characters really stand out as some of the most colorful I've experienced.  If you're like me and have always meant to play this game but just haven't had a chance, snag yourself a copy and enjoy!(A note: The cloud saving is off by default and very finicky.  If you only intend to play on one computer, this won't be a problem, as it will just save locally.  If you plan on playing across a couple computers, you should go into the settings from the launch screen and enable cloud saving before you start to save yourself some trouble.)

content:

												What more can be said about this game that you probably haven't already heard? It's going on almost 20 years old and highly regarded as one of the classic JRPGs to set the standard for quality, story, innovation, battle mechanics, and more. If you've heard about this game and never played it, there's a reason. It has some of the most interesting settings and characters, even by today's standards. When this game released in 1997, the graphics were hailed as some of the best out there. Although they may not hold up to that these days, they are still colorful and fun. In all honesty, I still think they're good.If you have not played this game, do yourself a favor and buy it. I consider it the best Final Fantasy in the series, and I've played almost all of them.

												Final Fantasy VII brought us all into the world of Final Fantasy, but just not in any way. It brought the stories and worlds we grew up loving into a 3D masterpiece. It was and still is one of the best Final Fantasies in my opinion. For those who are reliving the tale of Cloud, enjoy it yet again on Steam! I don't know about you guys, but when I heard of the remake it made me want to experience the original for what it is. I have beat it so many times and have done everything there is in the game. The only thing I didn't get to experience was achievements. I went ahead and bought it here so that I could relive the tale once more and to challange myself in the achievements. I encourage you all to relive our Fantasy yet again and shoot for the stars. Now for someone that didn't live in this era and experienced it during the time it was released, may look at it and compair it to todays tech. I urge you to look past that and remember that this was the first Final Fantasy release in 3D. Final Fantasy VII was the steping stone to what we have today. Thank you for your time.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												The game has aged quite a bit and although this game doesnt look the best, if your looking to get into final fantasy this game is a must for PC. Now although this game is amazing and has sold millions worldwide in its day, the reality is it may not be your style of game. Final Fantasy 7 features a turn based sytem which may be a hit or a miss for you but also allows for intense and strategic battles. We also have to take into account that the game doesnt look amazing, and this factor could be a miss for people since the characters look like lego but the PC version does somewhat fix this issue with mods to make the character models in the game look a little bit better and more desirable to look at. If you can look past the graphics this game has a well written story to really put you into the world of ff7. Also time, this game takes some time to finish which is good and bad but we have to take into account that not everyone likes long games. This game goes for a long time and will take up a lot of time but if your like me and dont mind the graphics, long gameplay and turn based system then this is a must buy and is a garuntee you will enjoy this game if you give it a chance.However if your not a fan of turn based but want to enjoy the ff7 story square enix is making a ps4 ff7 that will not feature a turn based style and has better graphics so you could wait for that game to release. But if your just looking to get into a ff game and want something new or that looks decent id reccomend ff10 and possibly ff13 although ff13 is a huge hit or miss for people. If you still dont like the turn base system ff15 releases on the 29th of november and looks promising for the ps4 and xbox one however a pc release is unknown at the momment sadly.OVERALL: the game is a 9.5 out of 10 considering the game has aged fairly well and that needs to be taken into account but despit the graphics you are looking at a very fun game that will consume your life until completion.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												For years I've avoided this game, mainly going by the kind of reviews that currently plague this Steam page.  But, I decided to take a leap of faith, and guess what?  The game is awesome, and highly recommended if you've been playing the PSX version through an emulator to get slightly better graphics, and especially to those that have been rocking the older PC version, which was buggy and contaned inferior music tracks.  Let's check off the list of improvements, eh?- Overall smoother looking graphics AND backgrounds- Same music as the original PlayStation game- "Easy" mode that boosts all of your stats so you just enjoy the story (requires Cloud save and to be online)- Can be modded if you want (though outside of Steam)To be clear, you DO have to create a Square Enix account, but I've only had to login once and never again.  Try that with your Origin or UbiPlay games.  And to all those people complaining about have to be online, this is what happens if you want Cloud saving and are online with Steam.  If you don't want this, turn off Cloud saving and you can take Steam offline.  You lose the ability to use your save between computers, but you can also be offline all the time.Now, things aren't perfect, but this is more indicative to it being based on the PC game.  While I am primarily a PC gamer, FFVII just feels unnatural on the keyboard.  I'm sure that if I played a few hours I wouldn't care, but right now thinking about juggling all that materia whilst using the keyboard gives me the cold sweats.  Luckily, it does have partial controller support.  You know the drill for Steam; get a compatible controller or an app that can get you own working.So, to recap:  This game rocks!  You have to create a SQ account, but since you only login once, I don't see what is the big deal.  I mean, you have to login into Steam to get this far, don't you?  Plus, you get to cheat right out of the box (no mods required).  So, if you've always wanted to get a better looking version of FFVII, or haven't played the game but was curious as to why it is lauded so, go ahead and pick this game up.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												I recently began an epic Final Fantasy binge. I bought FFIX, FFXV, FFIII(VI in Japan) and this game.  I've only finished IX so far, but what I've played of this game, it's gonna be one of my favorites.  The combat is simple, yet engaging, the characters have great interactions, and the story(so far) has been good.  The few drawbacks I've encountered is that sometimes it's hard to maneuver in small spaces, and that with a controller, the button prompts show up as [OK], [BACK], [MENU], etc instead of A, B, X and Y.  The music is amazing, as well.  Overall, if it doesn't take a major turn for the worse, I'd give this game a 8-9/10 depending on how the story ends up.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
												What more can be said about this game that you probably haven't already heard? It's going on almost 20 years old and highly regarded as one of the classic JRPGs to set the standard for quality, story, innovation, battle mechanics, and more. If you've heard about this game and never played it, there's a reason. It has some of the most interesting settings and characters, even by today's standards. When this game released in 1997, the graphics were hailed as some of the best out there. Although they may not hold up to that these days, they are still colorful and fun. In all honesty, I still think they're good.If you have not played this game, do yourself a favor and buy it. I consider it the best Final Fantasy in the series, and I've played almost all of them.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												As a kid, when i was 7 years old, I went to a pc shop with my dad and he told me, that i could choose one game and he'd buy it to me... I saw a game outcast - you know,an epic game for that time... the problem was that outcast needed some additional drivers in order to run and as a kid I did not know nothing about drivers. Because i was just a kid and even though he already bought me outcast, we went back to the store and the salesman told me, that i can exchange a game with another one, so when i looked up, I saw it on a shelf - "Cloud, holding this massive sword (buster sword) behind his back". I've told dad: "Dad, that's the game that i want", he "obeyed" me and we took it home.Came home, sat down and installed the game - started it and the arrow keys weren't working - as a kid I knew how to use only arrow keys and i didn't even try to bother with other ones, so i tought the game was broken - and god bless my ignorance, i think that a couple of days have passed when i've figured out the controls - numpad.When I've started the game, (since i'm not from America nor Britain) I had poor knowledge of english - I got terrified how many dialogs were popping out and got really depressed when i didn't understand most of the written words -  "That's it, i've decided to delete the game".2 years have passed, I turned 9, other games and cartoon network were teaching me english at that time, so i've decided to give FFVII another go... and that's when it happened... I couldn't stop playing FFVII for 2 years. I found the story so interesting, even if there were words that i didn't understand, I had a dictionary besides me and the game helped me to learn english (the funny thing was, that i've pronounciated words differently, since i've never heard the words before). number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												Final Fantasy VII is universally recognized as the best installment of the series, and maybe one of the best RPG ever. I played the original, on the PS1, all the way through at least four or five times. FF7 was the only game I liked enough to get me to shell out the extra 20 bucks for the guide, just so I could find and/or beat every little side quest or hidden area. It absorbed many countless hours of my youth.Not to long ago, I found FF7 on Steam and quickly bought it for second time. Now I never did find my old guide (not that you need it with the internet), but I played Final Fantasy VII once again and loved every minute of it. I was reminded of it’s great story and characters, awesome weapons with unique leveling up, the way powers can be mixed together, and the great interface for both battle and world map. I enjoy that you can spend hours racing giant birds around for an awesome hidden item or fighting through a tough dungeon for a unique weapon. But the game doesn’t make you, very little of the required gameplay is grinding. This game does not require continuous, fast button mashing. So if you like to take frequent, short breaks from the game controller to enhance your video gaming experience, Final Fantasy VII is great for that.After completing this game once again, even though it took a bit longer because of that pesky thing known as a job, I still find it to be my favorite game ever. It has everything that made it great on the PS1, but the PC version is much smoother because of the updated hardware. If are a fan of the original, have played others in the series, or just enjoy RPGs or good games, it will be more than worth it to buy FF7, a great game all around.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												Well, I guess now's a good time to write a review.Final Fantasy VII (FFVII) is a very special game. A lore-filled world that's been expanded on for years after its release, Gaia ("The Planet") is the setting of FFVII. Deserts, secret islands, ancient ruins, glaciers, mountains, a cyberpunk city, and even the bottom of the sea are all open to you as you hunt for a man seeking to destroy The Planet.You probably already knew all of this, so I won't bore you with story. Square sunk over 30 million dollars into this game, and that was back in 1997. The visuals show age, however. FFVII was meant to be played on a CRT television, which blended the screen together a bit. It's hard to explain, but the pixelation of the pre-rendered backgrounds is readily apparent and contrasts against the sharp, crisp polygons that make up the denizens of The Planet.The keyboard controls are pretty sensitive as well. Often I would find myself skipping over commands in battle on accident, so I switched to using a controller. DO NOT PLAY WITHOUT ONE. Speaking of battles, the encounter rate is very reasonable throughout the whole game, and as long as you don't run from too many enemies, you should never have to do any level grinding whatsoever.That goes for abilities as well. Want to use someone else? FFVII's skills take the form of items that characters equip, meaning they can be switched freely and removing the need to level up the Fire spell for all nine playable characters.There's a ton to do besides fight and progress in the story. Snowboarding, submarine battles, Chocobo racing and breeding, and a plethora of hidden treasures are all waiting for you, along with many other distractions. It's easy to sink a good 50-60 hours into the game.The music is my favorite soundtrack in the series. Some love it, some hate it. I don't have much else to say on that.Final Fantasy VII is a game many call "overrated". I personally couldn't agree less. It's a fun, creative, and engrossing adventure, and all of the hype you've heard is, for the most part, completely true. While I still think Final Fantasy VI is the best title in the series, VII is an incredibly close second. If you've never played this masterpiece before, do it now.
