content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												Ahhhh FF7, the cornerstone of my rpg exposure from days past. It's good to see this particular title make it to Steam (honestly I was starting to think I was the only kid that had it for his PC back in the day). I remember growing up playing on my old win 95 pc, juggling between 7 disks contorting my fingers to use the numpad controles. But I'm not here to bore you with my nostalgic bantering lets go over the good the bad and the ugly.The good: This is a pretty basic jrpg thats real easy to pick up and understand. If you never played an rpg before this would be a good well-rounded game to break into. As far as game-play mechanics go, it's got a very gentle learning curve where if you take a moment or two to read some material explained on some of the games finer points and tool around with some of the settings (like ATB if you're new or want a purely turn-based combat style) IMHO, if not personal opinion, the magic and skill materia system is just more easily managable than previous/alternative character-class styles or the ill-recieved drawing/job-skill system of other games in the franchise.The bad:Looking at the story and analyzing it a little bit closer since growing up I've started to notices the flaws I didn't notice before. True it tickles my nostalgic core to no end playing this game and the characters and story is going to be something that sticks with me forever but looking closer and taking an outside perspective it's impossible to overlook some of the major story flaws. Plot points will be brought up that lead nowhere (or if you're a Square-enix executive, you'll just write whole new games around these points to cash-in on the fanbase). Yet one of the things that killed me playing this game again was the blatant continuity errors. Characters will mention or prod the player in a direction that they really wouldn't know about in the first place. Compared to other RPGs it's these flaws that I think may have made this and other similar games too watered down to appeal to a larger base audience like say the kind that don't like investigating, talking to every npc, or just simply spending the time to make an attempt at trial-and-error. Now, this doesn't break the game mind you. It's just try not to expect wracking your brain too much with this casual game.The ugly:Keyboard controls.... nuff said. Pick yourself up a xbox controller or logitech if you're cheap but do yourself the favor.Story: 7/10Controls: 4/10Nostalgia-boner: 9999/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Memories... This game evokes many. I first played Final Fantasy VII in 1998 since I was late to the PSX party; it was the entire reason I made it a point to purchase a Playstation in the first place. I had just turned 15 and had the entire summer ahead of me. This was probably my tenth playthrough of FFVII and the first time I've touched the game since 2004.I was excited to sit through the intro as Midgar slowly comes into view again and we gradually see the full expanse of the mako megapolis in all of its glory, spouting geysers of planet energy into the air miles above the upper plate. Seeing Aerith's face slowly appear on my screen reminded me of an angsty, heartbroken 15 year old version of myself that could never forgive the game developers for doing what they did, even though what they did is probably what cemented this game in my mind as one of the all-time greats. They got me emotionally invested, which probably isn't very hard to do with a 15 year old - let's be real. There are critics everywhere and I respect their opinions on why FFVII is flawed - but I'm here to share why I think it's great and has withstood the test of time.Let's start out with the setting. Inconsistent? Maybe a little. Fun and interesting? Absolutely. Midgar (especially at the time of the game's release) was unlike anything ever seen in a video game before. It was dark, gritty and full of danger. Your capital city isn't supposed to be crawling with monsters and infested by extremely unsavory folk at every turn. I mean EVERY turn. We aren't talking your staple renegade rogues and bandits, either. We're talking a group of eco-terrorists, a brothel with all kinds of sexual deviants, and a Kingpin pimp with the rule over the most lustrious town in the slums. Not to mention you have ShinRa's hitman shadowing you in the very early stages of the game: Reno. Most of this was unheard of in video games, especially a game that garnered as much attention as Final Fantasy VII did and still does. Clearly, there was a good formula at the start.Leaving Midgar, you begin traveling to other towns which are typically much smaller and far less populated as well as more peaceful... if they haven't been ravaged by ShinRa, Inc. Some favorite locations for me personally, in no particular order include:Fort Condor -- It's small and there's hardly anything going on there. Two people to talk to, but this place first gave me the initial sense of desperation people feel towards ShinRa (outside of AVALANCHE and some other Midgar residents) as they fight to protect the near-extinct Condors, one of which happens to be nesting atop the Mako Reactor built there.Costa del Sol -- Swing by and have a Tropical Nights at the bar! Costa del Sol was the first town in Final Fantasy VII I felt like I could relax in (the short run-in with Hojo aside). Finally I seemed to be out of ShinRa's grasp for a little bit and had some chill time. The music and ambience of this town is the first like it I really got to experience in such detail; it felt like a fun, albeit short, reprieve for the crew. Everyone split up and gave you the opportunity to have brief dialogue with each member of your party.Nibelheim -- One of the creepiest towns outside of Silent Hill. You walk into Nibelheim and you automatically know something's wrong (outside of it just being there alone since it should be ash). The townsfolk are all obviously hiding something and just simply either chuckle at you or demand that you leave. Nibel Mansion is one of the most unsettling places around, although I think they could've done better with enemy choices for this location to expand upon that, the music is chilling as you venture deeper and deeper into the mansion to try and uncover the mysteries it hides.Wutai -- It's like Beijing and Kyoto got mashed together hundreds of years ago with pretty awesome results. Wutai is one of the biggest locations you can visit outside of Midgar and even has a large mountain - Da Chao - in which you can participate in a sidequest to rid yourself of a slimy pimp and settle an old score once and for all. The Pagoda is my favorite. Influenced by Bruce Lee's 'Game of Death' there are five floors for the spunky young ninja Yuffie to fight her way up in 1 on 1 combat before meeting the Grandmaster in a deadly fight for supremacy, and pretty good rewards.I like most locations in FFVII and could keep talking about them for awhile, but let's skip all that. Next, I want to talk about some COMBAT.FFVII sports the ATB System which allows you to increase or decrease the speed of battle at your leisure - personally, I have to go full throttle in games like this, but to each their own. Materia is engaging but not so comlex that it will make you walk away scratching your head in frustration. It's fun to level up and see new spells get unlocked as well as find new Materia. My major gripe with Materia is that the stat adjustments (some would give you -02% HP, for example), were pretty inconsequential; especially with the introduction of HP / MP Plus Materia. I like the cause and effect game and trying to work through it more.  There are several different Materia types which I'll break down here:Magic (Green) Materia: Magic Materia covers all of the elements such as Fire, Lightning and Ice. There are a number of others as well. You start off with Fire, Bolt and Ice as the basic spells of these Materia and as you win battles, your Materia basically gains experience as well and will eventually evolve to its next stage and unlock a higher tiered spell for most. This was very interesting as in other games it just seemed to be either done at a random level some character would learn a new spell for the most part - FFIII for SNES being one of the exceptions also.Summon (Red) Materia: Ever feel like calling forth a primordial beast from the depths of the netherworld to wreak havoc upon your enemies? Yeah? Well, you should probably get mental help. Summons are bad♥♥♥♥♥incarnations that are... summoned, and do heavy damage to all enemies. Most of these guys are elemental based as well and they range from an Ice Queen to the Lord of the Underworld all the way up to a mecha-Godzilla looking Dragon that blasts your enemies from outer space with the force of a nuclear bomb. I can dig it.Command (Yellow) Materia: This Materia is very versatile in that it enhances a character's actions or unlocks new actions for the character utilizing the materia. For example, throw Double-Cut on Tifa and she will attack twice in a row with a physical attack instead of the normal one time. Sense Materia allows you to view the HP/Status of an enemy at any time when used, and you can even use your Gil as a weapon to hurl at your opponents - the more you throw, the more damage is done.Support (Blue) Materia: Also very useful, allowing you to cast basic single targetting spells on all enemies and even allowing you to Steal when you perform a certain attack that you have the Materia linked with.Independent (Pink) Materia: Covering your allies is always useful if you have someone who can take a lot of punishment. Some of this Materia is good and useful early in the game - later on, it feels pretty broken though. I would've liked to have done without.I did get Materia Master on this playthrough and it was very gratifying for me, personally. Though I will warn you, it is time consuming and there are a few Materia that you can miss and if you do: you will not get the achievement on that playthrough.Combat is fast and exciting for awhile and if you're a gaming masochist like me, the Battle Arena at Gold Saucer can be really fun, especially if you go there at lower levels. Some of the Materia combos just make this game busted at higher levels. I think Ruby and Emerald Weapons (the super bosses of this game) each got two to three hits on me before I annhilated them. Out of room here. Part II will come later. Thanks

content:
Posted: October 5, 2013
												There's really not much I can say about Final Fantasy 7 that hasn't already been said. It was a revolutionary game and it changed the face of RPGs forever. Some say it was for the best, others disagree.In any case you've likely heard all the JRPG stereotypes, the random battles, and the menu based combat. The storyline is extremely character driven, and it's one of the highlights of the entire experience. That's not counting the large world you explore, the sidequests and all the optional content. Much of which most players don't know about until they read a wiki. Final Fantasy 7 is a game about replayability and choices, and one that anyone can enjoy.

It transcends all of what is expected and surpasses all basically. This game is not overrated or neutral in my book, in fact it is indeed considered underrated now for me, it’s been a while since people experience it’s raw power but it is still is to this day one of the best games ever made. . Of course the stands of its title as the best game ever made are still pretty known yet dismissed which is very sad because this is an overachiever of an experience ESPECIALLY compared with the rest of its series and many of the genres.  It’s faster than what its series is normally is; its gameplay is simpler and funnier, having personally one of the best mechanics ever, the materia. Especially considering this is one of the best games I’ve played I recommend it to anyone really. It’s just a nice smooth experience even if you aren’t the type to play big games to the end; I really recommend this, even I someone who cannot support this type of length it is still a game that every second manages to show me something cool. It is basically my saving grace on long JRPGs and perhaps video games in general. The gameplay is one of the most mechanically best I’ve seen, simple and straight to the point unlike many other games that take a long time to get to the basic of it, this one gives you it all at full front and doesn’t hesitate to make it entertaining at all times. Magic is simple to use by any character using the materia system which is the best system ever, they’re these little magic pearls that once equipped within your weapon can be used, they can also be combined with slots that are combined slots which you can make combos with such as (A “Cure” materia with an “All” materia makes it possible to use that magic on all). On top of this the materia can be leveled up as you battle to be more efficient by gaining , not only this, all characters within the game are extremely useful even without the power to equip any materia you wish from battle power to healing! Every character has a Limit Break which is when they get hit a couple of times and can’t take it anymore, they will release a power blow that is mostly based on their characteristic, for example Tifa Lockhart will use wrestling moves done by a roulette a system, and Aeris’s first limit will be to give some health to the 3 of your team. The entire game’s backgrounds are made with these amazingly animated CGI pictures that are filled with detail and are always cool to look at, it has beaten any texture or tile pack in its genre of how memorable and incredible it’s visuals are. Not only that but a fair share of interactive cutscenes blending in with the game’s models, an insane amount of in-battle animations with over a thousand enemies with their unique attack patterns and styles and in general lots of effort put into to the limit. I used to dislike this game due to my short attention span I grew to notice how much it has to offer especially compared to others of the genre; it has indeed a wider variation of options while remaining simple and straight to the point, from dialog, to character selection, to how many weapons and powers you can acquire, different styles to take on an enemy entirely there are various choices to do on side missions side too and you can collect rare items as you explore a giant world, collect more, experiment with powers, there are multiple statues that are negative and positive, a round of elemental powers given to about anything in the game including actual weapons you receive, accessories that facilitate you by nullifying certain types of times and just a huge number of other statistics that yes while describing seems complex but seems very natural and simple within the game, all this to discover new ways to make gameplay easier and this is all done in a balanced manner quickly.. It’s a bit long to go into detail about each content you can go to but as an example there’s a materia that allows you to turn enemies into items. The plot is amazingly crafted and designed; it is filled with foreshadowing, flashbacks and not an adventure that manages to keep continuing without any breaks and always a bigger goal in front.  Out though yes everything within the game is almost as If a satire of how simple it is, mostly everything is based of clichés and yes it’s mostly comical and never 100% reassured (I mean c,mon by this point you would tell yourself “Oh I guess the magic goop heals all of the plot’s wounds” to be honest or “Must be symbolic” because really It’s a just science fantasy with a more serious turn), but that only comes within the standards of nitpicking, I mean honestly, if you were to go to the single first bone of this game realistically you would think to yourself “Isn’t ecoterrorism flawed?”, but don’t worry they later on in the game kind of regrets what he did to save the planet SO HEY Plot filling exists at a high level in this game, this game can truly sustain itself in terms of plot elements sometimes even if it’s silly so I’ll end it at that considering there’s many other silly major plot concentrations that can be easily taken away in a bad way if you don’t see it from the adventurous perspective or ATLEAST EXPLORE THEM!  What’s there is there, it’s a simple story within a typical cyberpunk sceneario and I’m more than ok with that, other than that the implied adult themes are strong… And the adult themes that are straight up shown are STRONG TOO! This game is still pretty grimdark to this day, it was the first of the series to introduce real issues such as poverty, world pollution, life goals, what death means to a person and how to live with it amongst other deep contents in which the game casually comments on with a quote or 2, perhaps even an entire character built on the topic. Some may complain on how it tries to deep but for me it’s more the merrier, it isn’t the best psychological take on characters but it certainly isn’t the worst, especially compared with what Japanese media takes as “Psychological” it could BE WAY worse.  Either way I appreciate it’s psychological tones it gives the plot way much depth and it doesn’t deliver itself at first glance, anyone against it must REALLY hate people with actual personalities that are basically perfect cardboard main characters, again it’s balanced because the characters themselves are competent, which is needlessly to say the necessary for a character, outside of that you can have your emotional problems as long as you use it to power yourself within your journey, I give this long speech about character development because IT SEEMS This HAS BEEN DONE WRONG MANY TIMES and Final Fantasy VII manages to do it alright. This is THE adventure, the most over achieving product in history, this game manages to hold my attention in all of the aspects it gives, a great and full of effort game that has grown out to be known as the best game ever made numerous times, it comes with a dark well designed plot filled with numerous great characters, it’s silly, humorous  and memorable,  it’s filled to the brim with content which is all amazingly crafted (which honestly is the reason why I fear this review might be TOO basic to cover up the entire game), there are 4 hour long documentaries which document every aspect, nook and cranny from this full of experience game. I mean it doesn’t seem much like it but I’m actually trying to refrain myself from writing more than a book here considering there is so much to comment on! This is my Final Fantasy. Also not full revie

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
-Quick Review-Final Fantasy VII (FF7) is a turn-based RPG that was released in 1997 on the Play Station Console by Square Co., Ltd (in 2003 they merged with Enix, creating "Square Enix"). Final Fantasy VII (FFV) is one of the most popular games in the series.-please note before purchase-I need to add a comment that, I tend to review the game alone, however for Final Fantasy VII you are required to creature (or use an existing) Square Enix account. Achievements/Steam-Achievements, and other features are accessible through that account... I don't really know many of the perks because I just jumped through the hoops to play the game. But to some people, that's a deal breaker.I just wanted to give people a heads up. Thank you for reading the rest of the review.-Detailed breakdown review-Story:  You play the game as the main protagonist "Cloud", whom is probably tied for being the most iconic figure in the series with the antagonist "Sephiroth". You start the game as a member of the terrorist group AVALANCHE, Cloud has just been hired and is providing combat assistance to the group... Good thing too, the raid doesn't go nearly as planned.As the story progresses you're limited to only to the city of "Midgar", after hitting the pinnacle of the story within Midgar (oh, you'll know what I'm talking about, if you make it that far. I was praying for a save point, I wanted to go to bed). You'll suddenly discover the world is a much larger place then you ever thought.To people who are new to the series, it's easy to brush it off as "oh, that's nice, a large world map *yawn*." Try to imagine seeing it as a little kid playing the PlayStation? To many of my friends this was the first game in the genre they had played, so naturally it's actually a very memorable experience. After this excellent transition, you realize "wow, this game is going to be a big long one" and it is, it came in 3 disk set.Game Play: I needed to do some research to refresh some of the terms used to describe the Final Fantasy VII combat system. I have played several Turn-based RPG's, however FF7 utilizes "Active Time Battle". The main difference is that there's a visible timer that counts down before you can make your next move.I had no idea that's how the game worked, so when I first played and my enemy had hit me three times while I was trying to learn the menu... well... needless to say I was more than a little surprised. "WHAT! You cheaters! I don't know what any of these moves do!" I have no shame in admitting I almost lost my first battle, and I lost my first boss battle in the first 20 minutes of the game. Yeah, go ahead and laugh at me; but this was my first time encountering that mechanic.Outside of the combat, there are many in-game events that you do throughout FF7, sometimes it's pressing key sequences to ride a snowboard, or chocobo, or arm wrestle. While very fun with a controller and on the original game console... with a keyboard and mouse the controls and tutorial still use the old button names. So there's extra difficulty trying to accomplish those. I end up failing MOST mini events because I don't know which button I'm pressing."Press select" mmmmk, letssseee... which one is select... *presses X* *Cloud face plants*. Well that was fun, let's try that again...Achievements: There are 36 Achievements for Final Fantasy VII, and four categories; 1) Person joins your party, 2) you do your first breaker limit with that character, 3) you do your last breaker limit with that character, 4) Some ridicules long end game achievement.I've played 26 hours so far (05/14/15) and only have 10/36 achievements, so naturally getting all the steam achievements will be quite an accomplishment in this game.Price: Final Fantasy VII is priced at $11.99, considering the amount of time you'll spend playing FF7 to get through the whole story alone, that's a very fair price. However, if you're just collecting games to your "maybe I'll play it someday" list, you should probably wait for a steam sale.Conclusion: The only real negative things I have to say about the game is that I don't like making accounts to log into an offline-game (but that's just the way it is), and using a keyboard isn't nearly as streamlined and seamless as using a controller.I personally love the story, the characters, and will be spending more time playing the game, I suspect I've just moved on to disk 2, So I've still got a lot farther to go before I beat the game... Then there's the whole thing about figuring out the achievements.I recommend this game to anyone who played the original game and wishes for some nostalgia, people who want to experience "Active Time Battle" game play in an RPG, or anyone casually interested in the story behind any of the characters in the FF7 world.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												This was my very first Final Fantasy game and still one of my favorites in the series and of my greatest childhood memories, i loved this game back then and i still do today, but i will say that it is not the best Final Fantasy game and it is by far the most overrated one in the franchise.The materia system without a doubt my favorite thing about this game and is my favorite "leveling" system of all the Final Fantasy Games.The music is great just like most of Nobuo Uematsu's work, one of my favorite things about this game.The steam version also includes the PS1 soundtrack the original PC version didn't have :D (From what i'v heard it wasn't included at first when the game launched on steam until a few months later which is a lazy move on Square's part)! One of Nobuo's best works alongside Final Fantasy VIII.The story is not the game's strongest part but its far from bad.Most of the characters are pretty good though but not best in the series.The graphics may look silly by todays standards but back when it first came out i found them really impressive.However the minigames in this game are definently the worst part of this game, the chocobo racing is decent, raising them however is time consuming but still kinda fun, the Bike Race is fun too but aside from that none of the other minigames are fun or intresting.Also this might be somewhat of a nitpick but i think the Steam achievements are just made up with no effort at all, boring as ♥♥♥♥ and not intresting at all, oh wellFinal Verdict 8.8/10 if you are a Final Fantasy fan and you haven't played it yet i'd say its worth your time, and for those who havent gotten into the series its a decent game to start with.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												I see little point in discussing this game's content because by now it's probably common knowledge. So what's the deal with this release?Well it's on PC, Steam, has cloud saving, a booster thing that makes the game easier, and achievements that made me play this game much more than I otherwise would have (I'm crazy, ok?). It also has a piece of DRM that i've heard is a real nuisance for some, but I didn't have too much trouble with it. You have to make an account, but once I linked it with my Steam account I never had to worry about it again. The real problem is the instability of their server, which takes down cloud saves during busy hours (during the sale it did, but not after that was done with). It does save locally though, and it updates your cloud save once that gets going again, so it's not really a big deal. Nevertheless, I felt the need to mention all this.Aside from that, this is FF7 as it was on the PS1 ~15 years ago (I still have a [friend's] copy :o). Everything. The story, gameplay, optional content, and even some glitches (W-Item) carry over to this version.That's really all I need to say, I think. Chances are you already know if you like this game or not. And if you never played it... well, you can if you want to. I had a decent time, but people tend to love or hate this game. Less because of what it is and more because of what it did: became a "standard" for JRPG's that has more or less remained the same ever since, for better or worse.Ok, i'll stop now. Buy if it interests you. You get what you expect: an aged PS1 classic that plays competently on the PC and has a few nice little additions.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												This is now the definitive version of the game now that they added PSX music. The translation and graphics are superior to the PSX version and it's most likely going to be cheaper than actually purchasing a physical copy. As for the game itself, the flaws are all still there and have become as glaring as ever with its age. The story still is as nonsensical as ever, the super deformed characters still look ugly, and the materia system actually destroys the traditional RPG formula for balance and makes each character essentially blank canvases outside of their base stats and limit breaks. That can be fun at first glance but it becomes very bland when every character essentially operates the same way and the end game becomes so single-minded. It's also a turn based/random encounter affair so if those kind of games get on your nerves you should avoid this at all costs. Lastly, the characters are your standard JRPG affair (although at the time, these archetypes in video games weren't common in North America) and most don't really evolve past their initial character development, especially outside of the party. The good?-The materia system is fun, flexible, and broken. I can't say I agree with it on a balancing or variety level but on the surface it's fun and gratifying.-The story ends up being paced pretty well throughout the entire journey which doesn't happen very often with JRPGs. -Random encounters are paced very well for a JRPG and I didn't find myself ripping my hair out until the final dungeon (two battles every screen with a mastered Enemy Away? Nah). -There are many side-quests that feel naturally implemented into the world and I enjoyed most of them aside from Chocobo breeding which was nothing but tedious.-The pre-rendered backgrounds are also usually pleasing to the eye (then again, they're a stark contrast to the awful character models that populate them). -The music and sound effects are great and overall the presentation has a charm to it that most JRPGs don't. My personal outlook on the game may have soured a bit over time but the core of the game holds up fairly well to this day despite some obvious flaws. I rate it overall a very strong 7. A worthwhile experience that I think gamers insterested in the history of the medium should attempt to tackle, especially those who are familiar with Japanese RPGs.

The only downside to me is that it doesn't seem to use the PS style of controller I wanted to use for playing it -- at least it doesn't let me use it very well.  However, it is perfectly fine for the mouse and keyboard.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												Final Fantasy VII is universally recognized as the best installment of the series, and maybe one of the best RPG ever. I played the original, on the PS1, all the way through at least four or five times. FF7 was the only game I liked enough to get me to shell out the extra 20 bucks for the guide, just so I could find and/or beat every little side quest or hidden area. It absorbed many countless hours of my youth.Not to long ago, I found FF7 on Steam and quickly bought it for second time. Now I never did find my old guide (not that you need it with the internet), but I played Final Fantasy VII once again and loved every minute of it. I was reminded of it’s great story and characters, awesome weapons with unique leveling up, the way powers can be mixed together, and the great interface for both battle and world map. I enjoy that you can spend hours racing giant birds around for an awesome hidden item or fighting through a tough dungeon for a unique weapon. But the game doesn’t make you, very little of the required gameplay is grinding. This game does not require continuous, fast button mashing. So if you like to take frequent, short breaks from the game controller to enhance your video gaming experience, Final Fantasy VII is great for that.After completing this game once again, even though it took a bit longer because of that pesky thing known as a job, I still find it to be my favorite game ever. It has everything that made it great on the PS1, but the PC version is much smoother because of the updated hardware. If are a fan of the original, have played others in the series, or just enjoy RPGs or good games, it will be more than worth it to buy FF7, a great game all around.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												This is now the definitive version of the game now that they added PSX music. The translation and graphics are superior to the PSX version and it's most likely going to be cheaper than actually purchasing a physical copy. As for the game itself, the flaws are all still there and have become as glaring as ever with its age. The story still is as nonsensical as ever, the super deformed characters still look ugly, and the materia system actually destroys the traditional RPG formula for balance and makes each character essentially blank canvases outside of their base stats and limit breaks. That can be fun at first glance but it becomes very bland when every character essentially operates the same way and the end game becomes so single-minded. It's also a turn based/random encounter affair so if those kind of games get on your nerves you should avoid this at all costs. Lastly, the characters are your standard JRPG affair (although at the time, these archetypes in video games weren't common in North America) and most don't really evolve past their initial character development, especially outside of the party. The good?-The materia system is fun, flexible, and broken. I can't say I agree with it on a balancing or variety level but on the surface it's fun and gratifying.-The story ends up being paced pretty well throughout the entire journey which doesn't happen very often with JRPGs. -Random encounters are paced very well for a JRPG and I didn't find myself ripping my hair out until the final dungeon (two battles every screen with a mastered Enemy Away? Nah). -There are many side-quests that feel naturally implemented into the world and I enjoyed most of them aside from Chocobo breeding which was nothing but tedious.-The pre-rendered backgrounds are also usually pleasing to the eye (then again, they're a stark contrast to the awful character models that populate them). -The music and sound effects are great and overall the presentation has a charm to it that most JRPGs don't. My personal outlook on the game may have soured a bit over time but the core of the game holds up fairly well to this day despite some obvious flaws. I rate it overall a very strong 7. A worthwhile experience that I think gamers insterested in the history of the medium should attempt to tackle, especially those who are familiar with Japanese RPGs.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												Well, I guess now's a good time to write a review.Final Fantasy VII (FFVII) is a very special game. A lore-filled world that's been expanded on for years after its release, Gaia ("The Planet") is the setting of FFVII. Deserts, secret islands, ancient ruins, glaciers, mountains, a cyberpunk city, and even the bottom of the sea are all open to you as you hunt for a man seeking to destroy The Planet.You probably already knew all of this, so I won't bore you with story. Square sunk over 30 million dollars into this game, and that was back in 1997. The visuals show age, however. FFVII was meant to be played on a CRT television, which blended the screen together a bit. It's hard to explain, but the pixelation of the pre-rendered backgrounds is readily apparent and contrasts against the sharp, crisp polygons that make up the denizens of The Planet.The keyboard controls are pretty sensitive as well. Often I would find myself skipping over commands in battle on accident, so I switched to using a controller. DO NOT PLAY WITHOUT ONE. Speaking of battles, the encounter rate is very reasonable throughout the whole game, and as long as you don't run from too many enemies, you should never have to do any level grinding whatsoever.That goes for abilities as well. Want to use someone else? FFVII's skills take the form of items that characters equip, meaning they can be switched freely and removing the need to level up the Fire spell for all nine playable characters.There's a ton to do besides fight and progress in the story. Snowboarding, submarine battles, Chocobo racing and breeding, and a plethora of hidden treasures are all waiting for you, along with many other distractions. It's easy to sink a good 50-60 hours into the game.The music is my favorite soundtrack in the series. Some love it, some hate it. I don't have much else to say on that.Final Fantasy VII is a game many call "overrated". I personally couldn't agree less. It's a fun, creative, and engrossing adventure, and all of the hype you've heard is, for the most part, completely true. While I still think Final Fantasy VI is the best title in the series, VII is an incredibly close second. If you've never played this masterpiece before, do it now.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												One of my all time favorite games I have ever played. The graphics now are outdated but that doesn't take away much from the game. In my opinion one of the best of all the Final Fntasy games. But don't expect this game to be easy on you; you will see the "game over" screen a few times (5 times for the Demons Gate battle for me...) and this game at times will not show you mercy and it will push you a bit. Haste, Regen, Cure and MBarrier will be your friends in battle, as will the All materia, so get these materias and begin using them to level them up to help you through the tougher battles.Though I highly suggest this game there are a few little things to be warned about, like the camera angle making moving around in some areas a bit tricky and annoying, and the button configuration for the game is still shown in game as buttons for a Play Station controller so some mini games that require specific buttons pressed become a little harder but not impossible.As you progress in game and level up your party, the nice thing is you don't have to worry too much about everyone who didn't fit in your limited party of 3; as you level up, they slowly level up as wel on their own. So if you get Cloud up to level 25, those who haven't been in your party in forever (for me this was Aries...) will often be around level 20, so close to the others in level. This is convenient because you don't always get to pick who tags along in your party.An added element to the game that was avaiable in the American release of Final Fantasy 7 are the WEAPON monsters. They are here in the Steam game and are typically a nightmare to fight so be prepared.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Those of you who have played the FF Saga on Gameboy...yes..Gameboy :D that grey cubelike thing u could play 2d games on...known for Tetris and Mario... and enjoyed it will be happy about this jewel. FF7 meets all the criteria for a rly good rpg. The story is just fantastic, you can spend weeks on this game and the battlesystem is pretty sweet. Ofc you have to keep in mind that this is oooone oldschool game. I loved it when I was little and as soon as it was available on steam I thought Id give it another try and even though the graphics are 1990 style I (almost) enjoyed every minute (more or less).Unlike the rest of the FF series the story takes place in a rather machanical-the world-is-going-to-end atmosphere. So there will be no witches, no knights and no princesses (yaaaay!). As usual you and ur mates are up to save the world...this time from Sephiroth (you must all know who he is... otherwise u have a serious  lack of gamers knowledge...). To save the world from its nonexistance you have the power of some outta this world materia which allows u to cast spells. So if you think urself back in time 20 years you will think these spells are f**** mindblowing. Today in 2014 they are not quite that cool but still worth the time.Imo the batlesystem is much better than in the latest FF games. Its round based and if u speed it up in the menue you will spare urself precious time. What is really really annoying though is that u have to watch the endscene after every battle. Even if it just takes about 5 seconds it is rly annoying... But sometimes u have to go through hell to experience the best story ever seen in an RPG!There are plenty of youtube vids you can check and it may look rly boring in the beginning but this game is probably the most amazing of all the FF games. The second best is FF8 which we you can luckily also get on steam and the rest I didnt like and I am also not spending a second (or third or fourth) playthrough on... but this one I must have played...5 times... :D So thumbs up! Hope Squaresoft (Square Enix...) will let go of the princess and knights and medieval mixture soon and get back on track after.... uhm.... 14 years.So Frankly: Characters are great. Battlesystem is good. Dialogues can be a bit annoying and u have to rapidly click through them if your not interested into listening to everything. Story is the best. FF7 is the best RPG :D

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Okay, to write a review of Final Fantasy 7 is not a simple task, believe me it's not. Now you've probably heard this before from dozens of people, whether it be your friends, gaming magazines, internet or basically any other form of communication; written or spoken, Final Fantasy 7 is one of the best games of all time, and though now it may seem like an overrated, outdated RPG nearly 17 years later, it deserves the title.I only beat this game once, and have dived back into it thanks to this updated re-release on Steam. Visually, it's eye-candy to me. Though current-day gamers might turn thier heads, this game looks awesome and if it weren't for the PlayStation's graphical limits, i would say that this is the way the developers originally invisioned the game back in 1997, fluent animations, sharper character models, and just overall better looking port.The Story is something else, The story of Final Fantasy 7 is not a forgettable one. You begin as part of an eco-terrorist group who is hell-bent on destroying the world's biggest power company for killing the planet, hours into the game later you find yourself on a mission to save a world that is doomed to complete annihilation at the hands of a super-soldier who is "taking back the planet". (i hate to give away to much spoilers.)As for the gameplay it is your typical, run-of-the-mill, turn-based JRPG. for a series who practically invented the genre, this game doesn't stray to far away from it's predecessors in terms of the battle system and means of progression, hell if you're having trouble understanding how to play, there are countless websites dedicated to this game as well as an in-game tutorial, have fun.If you are a fan or RPG's, JRPG's, or curious about the genre, PLAY THIS. you are doing yourselfs a huge injustice by reading this and playing some damn Final Fantasy 7, you will not be dissapointed.

												Pros:- Excellent story.- Interesting characters.- Amazing soundtrack (unlike FF8 the music has not been ruined for the Steam version).- Cutscenes look amazing and the in-battle graphics are very good for the time and are still bearable today.- Exploration and chocobo breeding is rewarded well.- Materia system allows for easy change of characters' magic and experimentation.- The localisation has been mostly fixed.- Fun in-battle gameplay.- Grinding is pretty much never necessary for the main storyline.Cons:- Out-of-battle character models are terrible.- Materia system is a bit too simplistic.- The overall game is far too easy (except for the optional bosses).- The parts of the game where the pace is slowed down last for too long.Overall score: 8.5 / 10

												Overall, a good deal on sale and for RPG fans who haven't had a chance to play this classic, or who just want the convenience of having it on Steam. FF7 fans/vets won't really find anything new worthwhile and are probably better off replaying whatever version they already have. Personally I would recommend a version where you can save anytime and use a speed boost, but it is all up to your preference.+Outstanding gameplay, story, music, and characters just like you remember+Every RPG fan should own/play at least once+Supports variety of resolutions from launcher+Runs great with Win7 64+Achievements+Variety of mods available including ones to improve some graphics/bugs-Graphics aren't really a strong point, though of course good for the time-Widescreen resolutions work but just result in black bars on the sides-Some minor screen cutoff, usually not too noticeable-Few achievements, either very easy or very hard with no intermediate-Mods aren't really user-friendly to most casual players-Extra DRM: Requires sign-up and login to Square Enix account

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
AUDIOClassicVISUALPolygonalDIFFICULTYToughVIBEClassic RPGCRAVINGJourneyON SALERarelyPROS:  Music has been changed back from MIDI form. Cloud-saving is kind of nice I suppose, since the game is so long (It can also be disabled.) Mistranslations and errors have been fixed. The game itself flows smoothly and is not prone to eye-sore jittering. I have not run into any crashing. FF7 itself is a great part of RPG history and worth a try.CONS: Logging in with Square is irritating and leads to issues if you aren't connected via internet. I'm not sure that level of invasiveness in the DRM is worth what benefits it gives you. The monster designs in this one are absolutely laughable, to the point of embarrassment. That's part of the fun for some, though.WORTH: FF7 only goes on sale only a few times a year, and goes down to about 50% off. You could wait for it to go on sale since it's such an old game, but you will be waiting for a while. With many Final Fantasy titles coming, we may see good bundles with this game in the next year or so.OVERALL: Solid port that has fixed issues both in the original PC and PSX versions. SCORE: 9/10                                                                     Full Review Coming Soon

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												Final Fantasy VII is probably my favorite FF game, next to VI. Maybe my favorite game ever.I never played this in my youth--I played it one year ago when I was 17. I have no blinding nostalgia surrounding this. The game itself is great, and I genuinely think it stands up against the test of time.This port of the game is accurate and polished. There are some blemishes (such as inherent D-Pad functionality not being supported; just bypass that with a manual keymapper), but none of them are fatal.I'm doing a modded playthrough right now (New Thread mod--highly recommend after you've beaten vanilla at least once).If you're hesitant and unsure, pick this up on sale. I can't recommend this masterpiece enough.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												This is, without a doubt, one of the best RPGs I've played over the years. It's engaging, it's fun, and the world is so huge, with so much to explore. There's a great variety of enemies, as well as different activites, including many fun minigames. The story is amazing, there's so much going on, yet it all fits very well. And the soundtrack, superb.When it comes to combat, I really liked the "turn-based but with some real time thrown in it as well" approach this game has. It makes the battles feel more dynamic as well as strategic. The Materia system is really cool as well, and, in fact, I might prefer it more than the old "your character gets to learn these specific spells"; in this game, you can equip your characters with whatever magic/summon/command you like, not to mention that the Materia that doesn't fall in those categories can provide different bonuses to your character.I think this review could go on and on for pages, but even then I don't think I'd ever do justice to this game with my words. All I can say is, I enjoyed it greatly, and, if you're a fan of RPGs, I think you will too.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												First of all,I'd like to say there is no good or bad game really.It all depends on your personal preferences.One may find a certain game fun while the other might not.Anyway,I'm actually a bit half-half on this game when it comes to recommending and I'll tell you why.-FF7 has a really GREAT storyline to it(that's what I love about Final Fantasy).It's not your typical predictable story.It just pulls you in.PLUS POINTS FOR THAT.-When it comes to gameplay,it's not your typical hack-n-slash style or fps.It involves characters taking turns to make their moves and you select and action for the character to take for example attack/magic/defend etc etc.(If you don't understand what I'm saying,you can always search for a video on youtube on final fantasy 7 battles).Personally I like this system.It's fun and unique:} In case there are people out there who are worried it may be confusing,don't worry,it's not:)PLUS POINTS!-Brilliant cutscenes.For a game that has somewhat "oldish" looking graphics (no offence it's a fact),it has some pretty neat looking cutscenes.I was amazed when I saw the first few cutscenes(and the later ones afterwards).I really enjoyed watching every one of it.PLUS POINTS AGAIN!-As you play the main character,you're not alone.You have friends together on your journey:3 Hurray! So,these other characters that join your main character are interesting,fascinating and unique.Having their own rich personality as well and their own stories.PLUS POINTS.Now for the negative part..For some reason,I feel that the amount of damage you can deal is pretty "suckish" even if you level up pretty high.Either that or the enemies are superbly strong.Or it could be both.I say that because from my experience from another Final Fantasy game,FFX to be exact,I levelled up my characters to a pretty decent level(not all the way to 99) and I could still win and complete the game)Some enemies can just easily land you one-hit kills.ONE-HIT and you're dead.This pretty much means that it's kinda tricky to take down enemies.It can be really frustrating sometimes.I remember when I was stuck near the final stages of the game where I had to beat the enemy boss.He was so difficult to take down even after 30 mins.I've seen several people on youtube who posts videos of their ff7 gameplays on beating this boss and they successfully did it but I realised something.I've seen people who levelled up their characters all the way to lvl 99,acquired special items from side quests,special moves etc(basially it's like they've gone through almost everthing in the game) and yet,it still takes some time to beat the boss.So it's still a little bit tricky but it's possible.And to get to lvl 99 and acquire all those special items and moves is a whole different story.You will need A LOT OF PATIENCE AND PERSEVERANCE with this game.That is like the key to this game.If you have that,then this negative part of the review should not be a problem for you~p.s This review is a personal view and opinion.I understand that not everyone will agree with me as they have their opinions as well.I can respect that.Also,everyone's gonna have their own different and unique experiences from the game.Oh and one more thing I need to admit.Remember I said you need a lot of patience with this game?Yeah...I don't have that.So I'm actually stuck at the final boss.Yup.I do NOT have the time and patience to do all the side missions and battle for hours and hours just to get to lvl 99 all just to beat that one freaking♥♥♥♥♥boss.I find that it's not worth my time.But if you feel otherwise,by all means go ahead~ There's an amazing cutscene after that and well,not forgetting the sense of satisfaction and achievement it bringsTvT All in all,it's best to have your own experience of the game:)

Product received for free
												FINAL FANTASY VII as a game is amazing for its time however the PC/Steam port is pathetic. My custom made top end PC does not like the old graphics and they like to glitch around a lot. The whole linking to SE's system is just extra crap that we don't need. It is better in it's original state on PS1 or you would be better off getting the PS3 downloadable version as that one does not have the porting issues that the PC has.Some of the issues include the aforementioned glitches in the graphics but also poor sound quality in music and sound effects, the attempt to scale it to the average computer screen makes it fuzzy and honestly shows that it has not aged well graphically. Some games just don't and this game is one of them. This port does not do the game the justice it deserves.

												You need an internet connection to log into a Square Enix account to play this game. It's kind of annoying, but not really a huge deal in this day and age. number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												“Let’s mosey!”I effectively ruined my original '97 hardcopy dics with how often I've replayed and burned through this game. The entire VII compilation (from Before Crisis to Advent Children) is something I hold very near and dear to my heart. VII isn't everyone's favorite Final Fantasy installation, saying it doesn't live up to it's hype, but I honestly think you can't overstate how EPIC this game is. It rightfully holds its place on the pedestal of one of the greats in the series--and in gaming entirely. Classic FF battle mechanics with the addition of a GREAT materia system makes necessary leveling up enjoyable. Graphics are most certainly dated, but to be honest, it’s so easy to look past playing with blocks of colored polygons for characters on maps. That’s how good it is. An engrossing story; good gameplay; a memorable, iconic soundtrack; and the most beautiful characterization and character development (especially if you follow the ragtag team throughout the compilation) that isn’t selective to a choice few party members—and you’ve got yourself a game that still remains strong after nearly 20 years.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												Bringing back the same incredible game and experience that blew RPG fans the f*** back , a timeless story , incredible cast ( Cloud Strifu , Million Dollar Baby , Terry Crews , and many others! ) , a beautiful story and though the graphics are of another time , the game feels and plays a lot smoother on Steam than it even did on the original playstation , it even looks better ! The online cloud function is a win , though I know people got a little mad and some would even go far enough to consider it "cheating" , which is total rubbish . A lot of gamers have already played this cult classic to death , and even then want to relive the timeless experience that is FF7 - without spending more time than necessary grinding - especially since we've already finished this game several times! So if you don't want to grind any more than you should , your prayers have been answered .Don't get it twisted though , as this game isn't only for veterans . If you've never played Final Fantasy VII and want to play arguably one of the best JRPGs ever made , and also potentially develop a HUGE crush on Tifa ( something about her post battle celebration , oh lord . )  , I now , more than EVER , STRONGLY RECOMMEND you buy this game on steam and play it inside out , if anything , it'll prepare you for whats to come in gaming's biggest remake to date . There's nothing that can be said about the game itself that hasn't already been said - there isn't a gamer out there that can deny the hype behind the remake of VII , and it is THIS game that is the very source of it . Will FF7's remake live up to the hype? Probably not , but this original is what created the hype in the very first place.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												When this game came out 17 years ago, it was for many, babies first JRPG.If you're looking for a challenging JRPG and never played FFVII, then don't expect it to deliver that (Try FFIV). Nevertheless despite how♥♥♥♥♥♥easy it was, you should still buy it for its visuals. music, and overall entertaining scenarios. FFVII was a hallmark of the PS1 era. It was the game that defined what was once the most dominant developer in the industry at the time: Squaresoft. It innovated the industry with its outstanding cutscenes that were just completely jawdropping at the time. Despite the fact that the ingame models look really primitive (even for back then), I wouldn't have it any other way. They just work with the art style and you'll grow to love them within ten  minutes of the game.That said, the game had one of the most obnoxious and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ gaming fanbases on the face of the internet. It's almost bad enough where you could get to the point where you might even despise the game itself.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												It's hard not to overstate my love for this game, It's pretty much my fourth favourite game of all time, just behind Final Fantasy 6, Persona 4, and Metal gear Solid 3.  It's one of those games which is completely umissable to play if you're a fan of the turn based genre, the bucket loads of praise its recieved even now is well deserved, with an absoloutely incredible OST to boot. This is a straight up port from the original PC version with very minor additions, including a rather pointless feature of being able to boost and give yourself max level and stats and what not, which is fine for people who just want to see the story, but the game is so very easy already, it's just there as a free bonus if you wish to use it. Another very amusing addition is the inclusion of mouths to the polygon models  As seen here! it adds nothing, and I have no idea why it's even a thing, but it looks funny as hell, so I keep it on.In short, you owe it to yourself to play this game if you haven't, perhaps just to see what all the fuss is about. This port is now the best way to play the game past the original PS1 version, so what are you waiting for?

number of helpful: 12 of 23 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												After spending more than 100 hours on the PSX I had to buy this masterpiece on Steam. An extraordinary JRPG from the golden age of this genre. Final Fantasy VII gets a 10 in almost every department: Character Design, Setting, Story, Gameplay, it's absolutely uncanny how addicting this game can be. Tons of secrets, unlockable party characters, weapons, subquests that will explain backstory and motivations of all your party and not only the main character. And let's not forget the presence of Sephiroth, probably the best villain in all the Final Fantasy saga (togheter with Kefka, from Final Fantasy VI). And the Gold Saucer... wanna talk about the Gold Saucer? This whole game is crazy good. Action, humour, a GREAT story with a major (and unexpected) plot twist... this game is the whole package. Keep in mind that this is a 1997 game though, so graphic-wise it feels a bit old. I personally don't care about it, but you might.MASTERPIECE. Buy it, so maybe Square Enix will give us Xenogears too! :)

This happened to me at least every two or three hours as I'd put my controller down to use the bathroom and grab a drink I'd come back to a crashed game. If you start your game before you turn on and connect your controller, it will not register the inputs on the controller making you have to close the game and restart it.

												Omg omg omg omg.Final Fantasy VII on Steam - I has it :DIf only I could copy my PS1 saves to Steam...I played FFVII back in 97~98.I loved the game, the story, the graphics, the characters, everything. I explored the game several times, most my playthroughs were capped at 99 hours and 99 minutes. I beat Emerald Weapon, got Omnislash, got the Golden Chocobo and the Knights of the Round materia.I tried to do everything I could, back then having no internet, meant using your head, asking your friends, or buying gaming magazines. It ended up being my first big game, and even today I still have many fond memories of it.Yes the graphics are very dated, but the story is top notch, and after playing it a little bit, Midgar still carries that dark overtone. Can't wait to play this again.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												FFVII was and remains the pinnacle of turn-based RPG adventure games. Set in a dystopian sci-fi fantasy future, the story follows Cloud as he saves the world from the insane and evil Sephiroth. This game holds up extremely well after all these years. I definitely recommend playing with a controller, because it feels really weird to play this game using a mouse and keyboard, but it can be done. This is the epitome of turn-based RPG epics, and is a must-have for any and all fans of the genre. One of my top games that everyone should play at some point in your life. The visuals don't stand up quite as well over time, but it still looks really good. My one and only gripe is that you HAVE to create a Square Enix account to play, but you only need to be connected to the internet when you play the game for the first time, after that it doesn't have to connect to your account anymore.--------------------------------------------------------------------If you enjoy my reviews, why not follow my curation page? Click here to do that thing!

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												This game is superb. I never had the chance to play this game as a kid and thanks to Steam, I can finally play it. 20 hours in the game and this is the best RPG I have played in years! the story pulls you in and doesn't let you go until you finish, the combat is pretty fun and there is a good variety in attacks and magic spells including summoning, healing, cursing and elemental attacks. the Ultimate attacks achieving at a certain point in battle are nicely made and very well executed despite the limited technology used to create this masterpiece. The world is diverse in many ways, you travel oceans, cities, villages, caves, mines, deserts, hovering theme parks, mountains and many more. There are a lot of side quests to finish and the rewards for finishing them are worth your time if you put hours into finishing a single quest. the variety of monsters to fight is truly jaw dropping and the amount of boss battles each with their own abilities and disadvantages really makes you think of the best way to defeat them. You simply must buy this game and all of its many features and the superb storyline which is both emotional and dark. Once you play this game, you will fall in love with for many years to come

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												When Final Fantasy VII finally came to Steam I nearly died yo.This game is one of the greatest games of all time. I first played this game on the PlayStation (when I was only young) I played it several times and again when it was released on PSN and now finally on Steam.Final Fantasy VII follows protagonist Cloud Strife a mercenary for hire who joins an eco-terrorist organisation AVALANCHE to stop Shinra from draining the life of the planet for use as a source of energy.Upon its release it was an immediate critical success.As with previous FF games it consists of three areas: A world map, field maps and a battle screen. What makes this game truly unique is the use of the turn-based battle system in which players command the characters in battles against CPU-controlled enemies. The skill system is based on Materia (magical orbs of condensed life energy) which are used for magic, summons and special abiliies.Good:-Hironobu Sakaguchi is a god-The story is simply amazing and it will literally take your breath away lol-Gameplay is amazing and winning battles against tough enemies is well rewarding (Emerald and Ruby Weapons)-The soundtrack is one the best ever composed in a video game, Nobou Uematsu the composer is a music god lol-The game truly redefined an era of RPGBad:-The Windows/Steam release uses PC MIDI files for its soundtrack which are terrible quality compared to the original on PlayStation, it is strongly recommneded to swap the files which you can do here: 


YouTube™ Video: Final Fantasy VII - J-E-N-O-V-A [HQ] 

			Views: 1,713,351		

			Final Fantasy 7 - J-E-N-O-V-A [HQ]		

It deserves 10 foxes out of 10 foxes :D

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												One of the best RPGs ever made and one of my favorite games of all time.In FF7 . you are trying to stop Sephiroth from absorbing the necessary energy he needs in order to destroy the plane. You control a group named Avalanche and you try to prevent that. The game is full of things to do : explore well hidden towns in the suprisingly enormous map (especially for the time it was released) , grind your way up the levels , find new equipment , fight bosses , enjoy the soundtrack and immerse yourself in an amazing storyline about the battle of good and evil.GAMEPLAYThe gameplay is incredibly enjoyable. The battles never get boring! Combat is turn-based , meaning your party will attack one member at a time , then it's the enemy's turn. You can use potions to buff your characters or simply to restore HP , make a basic attack or wait a few rounds until your Ultra-Supa-Dupa-Power attack becomes available in order to smash your enemies. Throughout the game you will meet different characters that can join your party - each one has his one specialties and disadvantages. Make sure you are properly geared up and loot everything you can and save FREQUENTLY!  Exploring the open world in order to find new towns or landmarks is very interesting , however it can sometimes get very frustating because of the random encounters you are forced to deal with once a while. You can run away from them , but this can make you lose money or even let your enemies steal precious gear while trying to. Boss Battles can take a while to finish , especially if you are not properly prepared. Levels are important in this game , so you should take your time to level up and grind a bit - don't just rush the story. Now , note that there are no big green arrows pointing to your next objective (like modern games). Therefore , you will need to listen to the characters' dialogues and use a bit of common sense in order to identify where you will need to go next. At some point of the game you will also be given vehicles you can use to travel the world faster (and safer ,s ince you won't get into random battles). Overall , the main gameplay aspects of the game (combat and exploration) are well done and long-term RPG players will feel familiar with the Mechanics of the game (such as Potion system , vehicles to travel the world , characters to join your party , equipment all around the world). Additionally , there are some nice mini-games that can earn you some money or other stuff (such as Chocobbo Racing) , however I found most of them not very appealing to me , so I didn't pay much attention.Keep in mind there are many ''special'' bosses you will have a chance to fight in order to get some incredibly rare and powerful gear - they are incredibly hard to defeat though and you might not really stand a chance unless you have really put many many hours into the game and Maxed Out most of your stats. Oh , and you can't explore or do anything after you are done with the main story , so make sure you are satisfied with your achievements throughout the game BEFORE you enter the final area of the game.STORYLINEIn the game , you play (mainly) as Cloud Strife -  a young man that still is unsure about his true identity and will try to find out who he really is. Apart from that , you are also part of the AVALANCHE group which was secretly formed to wage a rebellion against Shinra , an organisation which is absorbing Mako energy, destroying the natural world as we know it , in order to fullfilltheir own , dirty plans and take over the world. One of the most interesting and engaging villains of all time , Sephiroth , doesn't want you alive and you will also have to deal with him as he is going mad and loses control of his actions. There are many other side quests you can do as well and you will get to know more about the world around you - and obviously , there are many other stories that developer throughout the game , such as romantic relationships between the characters or conflicts! You get to decide what you will say in many of the dialogues and the cutscenes are really well done and drive-away some of the monotony constant gameplay can cause.TECHNICAL ASPECTS + SOUNDUnfortunately , FF7 is a game that hasn't aged very well (granted , it's 18 years old and was originally released on PlayStation 1 , so it's understandable). It still doesn't look that horrible , however and inspired many modern RPGs. The PC port is also not particularly good either , but most PCs will be able to easily handle it today , so it should no matter what run smoothly. There are many mods you can use to enhance your experience , however I prefer to play games they were meant to be so I didn't try any of them out. Perhaps the visuals aren't great , but the soundtracks of the game are still INCREDIBLE and make me feel incredibly excited.. It's a very weird feeling but the sound it makes when you enter a battle or when a cutscene is playing , it's just so refreshing! I am not an audiophile and I usually don't pay much attention to that sort of stuff , but this game stood out for me. Back to the visuals , the colors are decent and despite the aging graphics , the atmosphere in the dungeons or the snowed mountains for example is still top notch and will certainly not distract you from enjoying the game.CHARACTERSThe characters development through out the game is special and some of the things that happen to them can be gamechanging. You will get emotionally attached to some of them , others you may not like them. And that is a very hard to come up with and something Square Enix put a lot of effort in order to develop. It's hard to find games that put so much emphasis that onto the character development . The characters this time make the story  , but the story also makes the characters. What I mean by that is , that what happens in the world affects the characters but what happens to the characters can also affect the world.CONCLUSIONFinal Fantasy 7 is a game for everyone . It is one of the games that felt nearly perfect and even though it might not have aged out as well as many would have wanted , it's still one of the best games of all time and for many the best RPG ever. All the critics and reviewers of the game in general can't just be dellusional - if you haven't played this game yet , you are missing out big time!-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------EDIT : Nominated for ''Test Of Time'' Steam Award

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												One of the most over rated final fantasy games and still very highly talked about to this day since it's release in 1997 and for good reason. Not only does this game have a great cast of characters  but as you progress through the game you can see them chagining emotionally and thats hard to pull off.  before i get talking about it let's get to the pros and the very few cons pros . Excellent battle system : this improoved on the atb system and made it even better .Learning spells from materia : Yes at first it can seem like a chore to do but once you get furthur in the game it's really easy to master materia and gain a good amount of skills especially after game. . number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												Final Fantasy VII is often times considered as one of the most revered and acclaimed games created.  This game is labeled as a 'Classic', a 'Masterpiece', etc.  Having played this game around the time that it first came out I was overwhelmed and as such played the game casually, not taking in the full importance of this game.  Coming back to play this game after experimenting with the newest Final Fantasy (13) I realized that we generally all lost something.  The over-commercialization and graphics card pushing aspects of some of the 'Classic' series have gained the highest degree of importance; replacing the storyline, battle system, customizability, and replayability.  To think that a game produced 16 years ago can still captivate an audience as it does is astounding.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Omg omg omg omg.Final Fantasy VII on Steam - I has it :DIf only I could copy my PS1 saves to Steam...I played FFVII back in 97~98.I loved the game, the story, the graphics, the characters, everything. I explored the game several times, most my playthroughs were capped at 99 hours and 99 minutes. I beat Emerald Weapon, got Omnislash, got the Golden Chocobo and the Knights of the Round materia.I tried to do everything I could, back then having no internet, meant using your head, asking your friends, or buying gaming magazines. It ended up being my first big game, and even today I still have many fond memories of it.Yes the graphics are very dated, but the story is top notch, and after playing it a little bit, Midgar still carries that dark overtone. Can't wait to play this again.

												The best Final Fantasy game, in my opinion. Besides VI. And V. And IV. And I. And X.God I love Final Fantasy.The Good!- It's Final Fantasy VII- Moddable- Slightly Updated ModelsThe Bad...- Graphics have not aged well. Part of this is the port's fault.- The music can sound really awful sometimes...- The Character Booster. It's basically a cheat. No, literally a cheat. I mean, you can use it if you want but...Ugh- Backgrounds... The pre-rendered backgrounds, one of my favorite parts of the game, are really stretched out and pixelated. It's not even a minor issue. The only fix I could find was changing the resolution, because I have a large monitor.- Weird DRM, a lot of people don't seem to like it. You gotta make a Squeenix account and register the game before you can play.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												This game is superb. I never had the chance to play this game as a kid and thanks to Steam, I can finally play it. 20 hours in the game and this is the best RPG I have played in years! the story pulls you in and doesn't let you go until you finish, the combat is pretty fun and there is a good variety in attacks and magic spells including summoning, healing, cursing and elemental attacks. the Ultimate attacks achieving at a certain point in battle are nicely made and very well executed despite the limited technology used to create this masterpiece. The world is diverse in many ways, you travel oceans, cities, villages, caves, mines, deserts, hovering theme parks, mountains and many more. There are a lot of side quests to finish and the rewards for finishing them are worth your time if you put hours into finishing a single quest. the variety of monsters to fight is truly jaw dropping and the amount of boss battles each with their own abilities and disadvantages really makes you think of the best way to defeat them. You simply must buy this game and all of its many features and the superb storyline which is both emotional and dark. Once you play this game, you will fall in love with for many years to come

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												The best game of the series for me followed by 8 and then 10 but this game has to have the best story for pulling you in I still rememebr the day I bought this for PS1, back when I was 15 (which was 15 yrs ago lol) I had endless nights of staying up late playing this game and probably had more sleep during school lessons than ever lol. The story just twists so many times during the game it really makes it the masterpiece that is I mean how many games do this now for example you start off blowing up a reactor for some miletent group for it only to twist and then your doing something else for it to twist again and again and this is what keeps this games story fresh.You get one main objective Sephiroth but it's not as easy you think and during that journey your meet and help people along the way again there are some fantastic moments of story twists that just keep you wanting more, for me play after school only to be playing for hours in to the late hours. You will get a lot of people saying this isn't the best one of the series and I except that it's personal preference but if you've never played this game of the series the re done PC version on here is worth buying (wait for sale if you want) and playing since it's had it's music fixed it's exactly like the PS1 version.If there is one thing I do miss about the first time I played this game is the feeling of what's going to happen next I've played it over and over in the last 15 yrs and I never get bored as I try to change the way I play but I would kill for that experience again of playing the game the first time back when I was 15.

												Quite possibly the best Japanese RPG ever. Everybody should play this game once. content:
Posted: November 5, 2013
												At last i beat the s**t out of this game!... It's nice to play this classic again, works very well on new systems. I had a crash or two, but nothing dramatic if you save at each given spot... especially now that you don't have to deal with the enless PS1 loadings or savegame access times we had back in the days. I recommend a gamepad to play this, much more practical. Although enjoyable, the J-RPG formula kinda get on my nerves after the second half of the game. I was happy to play this game again... but after a while you wish to finish it  ASAP and move on to something else. The longer you play, the more it feels like a chore. I suggest to get it only with a good sale applied on it.
