number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2013
												Stars bolt around the screen as if being gazed upon by some drunk in the middle of the night, only to fade to the image of a young woman holding a basket of flowers, strolling into a vast industrial city the only light being the faint flicker of houses and the green glow of the mako reactors, amongst the pitch black polluted sky above. "Final Fantasy VII" scrolls across the screen as a drum roll picks up, slowly zooming into a platform, with quick interruptions from a speeding train grinding to a spark spitting halt. A woman and three blokes jump out and take down several guards, "C'mon Newcomer" shouts the burly black guy in am armless shirt. A spiky headed blonde, purple jumpsuit sporting dude backflips of the train with a sword bigger than him. Battle commences and you are thrust straight into the fray, swinging said sword and conjuring lightning.Cinematic gold within five minutes.From start to finish, Final Fantasy VII is an intense roller-coaster ride in terms of everything you'd expect from a video game and more. As if seeing the copious amounts of five star reviews for this game wasn't enough, one quick search for FF7 provides commercial acclaim left and right. People hold this game close to their hearts, stick up for it vigilantly, often ignore its (minimal) shortcomings and its not difficult to understand why. Released in 1997, 2 years after the Playstation One's world wide release, VII boasted a brand new, groundbreaking experience. Not many games were spread across three discs.. but the length of the game pretty much demanded it. My first experience of this game was in 1998 whilst visiting a friend I witnessed something fascinating, simply hearing the music as I walked into the room was enough to peek my interest but actually seeing 3 mysterious characters using all sorts of magic and summoning gigantic beasts to aid them in battle was, for lack of a better word, breathtaking. A few months later the same friend turned up LATE for my 8th birthday party, suffice to say all was forgiven when I realised what he had given me. By far the best gift I have ever received, it put all other presents to forgotten shame, and that was the beginning.The battle system in Final Fantasy has largely remained unchanged throughout the early games, utilising 3 varied characters, each with a different class or set of abilities and stats, to ultimately defeat an opposing enemy. Taking turns, making use of magic, physical attacks and abilities. Often offering a different experience each time. VII is no different but improves on its predecessors considerably with new additions such as the materia system. Materia, a large part of the game involved not just in combat but story as well, is essentially an item equipped to enable the use of the specific magic within it. Its a rather unique system as there are so many combinations and levels in materia alone that its worth exploring the entire world to find every last type. The world itself is a strong reason alone as to why this game is so vast, featuring several locations ranging from the massive powerhouse conglomerate city of Midgar to a small snowy village where the only pass time is snowboarding. VII's amusement park, Gold Saucer is a marvel to behold, abundant in mini games that make the stresses of the game fade slightly if only for a moment.Surroundings alone aren't enough however, Square had to go one further and get veteran composer Nobuo Uematsu to come up with one of the most memorable and emotional soundtracks ever made. The music enhances not only the environment but also effects the mood during dialogue. A whopping 85 MIDI tracks have never sounded this good. Whether its a sense of urgency, romance, pure adrenaline fuelled action, the soundtrack comes up trumps every time. Stories are a dying aspect in recent video games, its all for graphics and gameplay alone, with no magic, no plot, no heart. VII in many ways is like a novel, with thousands of conversations and sub plots to get stuck into, you can't help but experience them all. I can understand how insane that must sound, comparing similarities between a video game and a novel, but that just shows how in depth the story really is and how high I regard it. Keep in mind that many gamers would avoid or completely disregard a video game dubbed to have similar qualities of a book.In the beginning you are thrust into a job with a group of environmentalists/activists/terrorists known as AVALANCHE, trying to take down ShinRa Inc. the ones behind the reactors that suck the land dry of its life source, mako. As you skulk through Midgar with your group you get to know all of its members, finding main characters along the way, get sidetracked, separate and reunite after major battles only to finally discover there is a greater evil at work. Events take you all around the globe via boats, submarines, airships, buggies and or course chocobos. You'll witness more incredible scenes at caverns, beaches, glaciers, temples, mountain tops, marshes, the ocean floor, the sky and even outer space, all whilst taking on nightmarish enemies and gaining new powers. Limit Breaks spice up battles using unique individual abilities to deal major damage after taking enough yourself. Secret characters hide away and must be convinced to aid you in your quest to save the world from utter chaos and destruction. If all that wasn't enough, you can try your hand at taking on optional bosses that appear in the later stages of the game, some with over 1,000,000 Hit Points. Final Fantasy VII has endured so much success it has spawned several spin offs.    Advent Children, a film set 2 years after the events of VII    Dirge of Cerberus, a PS2 game revealing further insight to one of VII's most mysterious characters    Last Order, a short anime film remodelling one of the epic events of VII    Before Crisis, a mobile phone game about ShinRa's special branch, The Turks    Crisis Core, a PSP game shedding light on events before VIIWith all that you could say Square-Enix have milked the franchise, but to be fair to them, they have gone about it with respect to the original and catered to the fans needs. Its no wonder that with all this success, the internet forums are a buzz with the hype of a remake. If all my ramblings of reminiscant nostalgia hasn't at least tempted you, my apologies, but it is my impression that you are missing out on an absolute gem and the best game ever made. 15 years later, its still going strong.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												This JRPG was the game that introduced me to the genre. Many people will say this is the best RPG ever made, if not the best game ever made. I disagree. It's a very good game, but nostalgia seems sweeter than this product.The music and graphics havn't aged well. Thankfully there are many user mods available to help with this. The gameplay is standard Final Fantasy fare and holds up well, though. You will read through an epic story, explore new areas, and participate in both random and scripted battles that can play out in either partially real-time or strictly turn-based modes. There is no job/class system in this game. Instead, the Materia system will define what actions your characters can take in battle as well as modifying their base stats.Some of the translation problems that plagued the original PSX version have been fixed. There are still many moments in the game that are heavily influenced by Japanese culture and will have some Westerners shaking their head with incredulity. The one scenario that pops into my head is the cross-dressing quest that will take the protagonist to a gym with a cross-dressing owner and a bordello where the hero can get taken advantage of by a group of men in a sauna. Thankfully, there are no Onsen scenes where the females compare breast sizes like the one that exists in Final Fantasy X-2.This port will let you play Final Fantasy VII with all of its flaws and charm. It may not be the best game ever, but it is a good Final Fantasy game and worth checking out if you're a fan of the series.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												The best game of the series for me followed by 8 and then 10 but this game has to have the best story for pulling you in I still rememebr the day I bought this for PS1, back when I was 15 (which was 15 yrs ago lol) I had endless nights of staying up late playing this game and probably had more sleep during school lessons than ever lol. The story just twists so many times during the game it really makes it the masterpiece that is I mean how many games do this now for example you start off blowing up a reactor for some miletent group for it only to twist and then your doing something else for it to twist again and again and this is what keeps this games story fresh.You get one main objective Sephiroth but it's not as easy you think and during that journey your meet and help people along the way again there are some fantastic moments of story twists that just keep you wanting more, for me play after school only to be playing for hours in to the late hours. You will get a lot of people saying this isn't the best one of the series and I except that it's personal preference but if you've never played this game of the series the re done PC version on here is worth buying (wait for sale if you want) and playing since it's had it's music fixed it's exactly like the PS1 version.If there is one thing I do miss about the first time I played this game is the feeling of what's going to happen next I've played it over and over in the last 15 yrs and I never get bored as I try to change the way I play but I would kill for that experience again of playing the game the first time back when I was 15.

My first experience of this game was in 1998 whilst visiting a friend I witnessed something fascinating, simply hearing the music as I walked into the room was enough to peek my interest but actually seeing 3 mysterious characters using all sorts of magic and summoning gigantic beasts to aid them in battle was, for lack of a better word, breathtaking. A few months later the same friend turned up LATE for my 8th birthday party, suffice to say all was forgiven when I realised what he had given me. By far the best gift I have ever received, it put all other presents to forgotten shame, and that was the beginning.The battle system in Final Fantasy has largely remained unchanged throughout the early games, utilising 3 varied characters, each with a different class or set of abilities and stats, to ultimately defeat an opposing enemy. Taking turns, making use of magic, physical attacks and abilities. Often offering a different experience each time. VII is no different but improves on its predecessors considerably with new additions such as the materia system. Materia, a large part of the game involved not just in combat but story as well, is essentially an item equipped to enable the use of the specific magic within it. Its a rather unique system as there are so many combinations and levels in materia alone that its worth exploring the entire world to find every last type. The world itself is a strong reason alone as to why this game is so vast, featuring several locations ranging from the massive powerhouse conglomerate city of Midgar to a small snowy village where the only pass time is snowboarding. VII's amusement park, Gold Saucer is a marvel to behold, abundant in mini games that make the stresses of the game fade slightly if only for a moment.Surroundings alone aren't enough however, Square had to go one further and get veteran composer Nobuo Uematsu to come up with one of the most memorable and emotional soundtracks ever made. The music enhances not only the environment but also effects the mood during dialogue. A whopping 85 MIDI tracks have never sounded this good. Whether its a sense of urgency, romance, pure adrenaline fuelled action, the soundtrack comes up trumps every time. Stories are a dying aspect in recent video games, its all for graphics and gameplay alone, with no magic, no plot, no heart. VII in many ways is like a novel, with thousands of conversations and sub plots to get stuck into, you can't help but experience them all. I can understand how insane that must sound, comparing similarities between a video game and a novel, but that just shows how in depth the story really is and how high I regard it. Keep in mind that many gamers would avoid or completely disregard a video game dubbed to have similar qualities of a book.In the beginning you are thrust into a job with a group of environmentalists/activists/terrorists known as AVALANCHE, trying to take down ShinRa Inc. the ones behind the reactors that suck the land dry of its life source, mako. As you skulk through Midgar with your group you get to know all of its members, finding main characters along the way, get sidetracked, separate and reunite after major battles only to finally discover there is a greater evil at work. Events take you all around the globe via boats, submarines, airships, buggies and or course chocobos. You'll witness more incredible scenes at caverns, beaches, glaciers, temples, mountain tops, marshes, the ocean floor, the sky and even outer space, all whilst taking on nightmarish enemies and gaining new powers. Limit Breaks spice up battles using unique individual abilities to deal major damage after taking enough yourself. Secret characters hide away and must be convinced to aid you in your quest to save the world from utter chaos and destruction. If all that wasn't enough, you can try your hand at taking on optional bosses that appear in the later stages of the game, some with over 1,000,000 Hit Points. Final Fantasy VII has endured so much success it has spawned several spin offs.    Advent Children, a film set 2 years after the events of VII    Dirge of Cerberus, a PS2 game revealing further insight to one of VII's most mysterious characters    Last Order, a short anime film remodelling one of the epic events of VII    Before Crisis, a mobile phone game about ShinRa's special branch, The Turks    Crisis Core, a PSP game shedding light on events before VIIWith all that you could say Square-Enix have milked the franchise, but to be fair to them, they have gone about it with respect to the original and catered to the fans needs. Its no wonder that with all this success, the internet forums are a buzz with the hype of a remake. If all my ramblings of reminiscant nostalgia hasn't at least tempted you, my apologies, but it is my impression that you are missing out on an absolute gem and the best game ever made. 15 years later, its still going strong.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												Let's get down to brass tacks: for vets of the series, this is Final Fantasy VII the way you remember it. If you don't have a Playstation or the ability to play this through more "unscrupulous" means, by all means this is what you want in a moddable package until the Remake comes out.Now, for you uneducated in the ways of VII, here's the real meat: Final Fantasy VII tells the tale of a ragtag little party initially out to save the Planet from being sucked dry by the Shinra Corporation. Along the way, things go south and blah blah blah even if you haven't played it you know the story with how much Square has thrown into the Compilation of VII. There are some plot twists that most may not know of because of the framing around it, and if you want to know the whole backstory of what led up to the various famous events, you'll find VII to be very accomodating in the way of letting you experience them.This is done by way of various, at the time and even now, enjoyable facets of the ATB battle system. Active Time Battle is just what it sounds like: each character has a bar, it fills up over time, and then you can make your action. If you choose Active for the battle system, enemies can attack while you make your choice. Choose Wait, and action pauses while you do so. This allows you a small degree of customization on the difficulty of the battles, as you can either choose to think your turns through or you can put yourself on the spot by making decisions relatively on the fly when a boss is breathing down your neck.Beyond this lies the Materia system. An extension of the Esper system from VI, Materia function as a condensed way to grant your party magic. As you battle, the Materia grow and develop skills. When mastered they create duplicates, and no skill is tied to one character. You want a scary guy with a gun on his arm dropping meteors? Go ahead and give him Comet. Get the urge to make your meteor dropper the spiky haired blond dude? Take the Comet materia off of the scary guy, give it to spiky dude. Simple as that, but so much more in-depth because of the stat boosts and penalties attached to the materia itself. HP, strength, luck, magic, all affected by the type of materia equipped.The bottom line, barring any moddable issues that other reviews may cover, is this: VII is still as good as it was. Nostalgia goggles are wicked in terms of this game for some people, but as someone who played it at 12 years old then came back 15 years later and played it again? A few times? I still had a major blast with it. If it's on sale, pick it up. If you have a small fortune spare on hand from playing the market? Pick it up then too. It's a long ride, but it's enjoyable.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												I played a bit of the original and I really like this port. People seem to have a problem with the sound but I think it sounds fine to me from what I've already played and its just nostalgia getting in the way of enjoying this game for what it is on PC for people who have played the original on PS1. What I liked about this re-release is the grammar issues I had with the original are gone from what I've played however the old bad translation is there but at least you get the gist of whats going on. I would have liked a redone translation but I guess I'll wait for the PS4 remake for a better translation. I was happy to know that my 8-9 year old Windows Vista computer is able to play this, it seems to be the only game on steam that can run it just fine. This version offers Character Boosters if you use Cloud Saves (Square Enix Members account needed). This will MAX out your HP, MP, and Gill. This is also for newcommers that want to know the story of Final Fantasy VII.Pros-Its Final Fantasy VII-You dont need a powerful PC to play this.-Grammar errors from the original PS1 translation are gone.-Cloud saves are for newcommers who want to know the full story.Cons-The old bad translation from the PS1 version is still in this version. -Cloud Save barely works sometimes. -You need to log in to Square Enix Members before playing this game for the first time.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												Amazing game. I have played this game for the first time and beaten it shortly before writing this review. So my opinion is non-biased on nostalgia. The game is older, so the graphics, and art style are nothing compared to what is out now, and may be a little jarring at first, it was for me. Soon after getting used to the graphics was an amazing and wonderful experience I wish I had undergone when the game first came out. However, it did not diminish over time. The story is great, even if it is a bit confusing at first, it all falls into place mostly over the course of the game. I did feel there were some plotholes and unexplained points, but nothing too serious. Music is awesome. Definitely some memorable tunes will be stuck in my head for awhile. I enjoyed the turn-based gameplay, and the world map. I highly recommend the game if you have never played it, it will be good to play through the original before the remake comes out, as the original will surely have a special place in your heart.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												There's a reason so many people call this the best game of all time. I won't give it that title, but this is the definitive Final Fantasy experience, and it is definitely the one of the best RPGs ever made. It stands right up there with the likes of Chrono Trigger and some of the earlier Final Fantasy games. If you're an RPG fan and you've never played this game, just buy it, you owe it to yourself. I am a highly critical gamer - I nitpick everything and usually don't enjoy many games anymore - but this game charmed me when I played it on the PSX, and it charms me again every time I boot it up on Steam. There just hasn't been an RPG this good since the generation it was made in. If your eyes absolutely cannot handle old-school graphics you may be skeptical, but understand that when this game was released, it was on the top of it's class in that department. So many years later, and no RPG has done what FFVII has done.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												FF7 is amazing, I played it first in 2009 due to somehow missing it back in the 90's, and it STILL blew me away. It's got incredible production values for the time it was made.However, I do not suggest the Steam version. The MIDI tracks sound terrible and the soundtrack's completely butchered because of it. I don't recommend the older PC release either, as the game simply doesn't work on recent operating systems.The best way to play this is the actual PS1 copy, or the PSN store versions. The second best way is to play the old release on Windows XP, with a "combat models while out-of-combat" mod.Avoid FF8 like the plague unless you're a full-blown weeaboo with a child's understanding of story-writing.

Posted: January 16, 2014
												This game is a mixed bag to be honest as it was hard to me to choose if to give it an upvote or downvote. First to talk about the game itself is a not bad port. Nice music better graphics and better difficulty scaling thanks to SquareEnix's new "Character Booster" if you are a pickle by scaling your character(s) levels to a point of your prefrence aswell as gil. Pretty much the same as the psx version. HOWEVER the game has a stupid client that FORCES you to make a SQUARE ENIX account which is really pointless to be honest. The controls are really cluncky and are very awkward although you can change them to your prefrences. Also, I do not see the point of achievements for this game. I guess it does provide more playable value but there is really no point getting max gil or max level before the final bosses (And doesn't that achievement collide with the character booster?).In conclusion it is an okay port, if you can get your hands on it get the original because it is much better in my opinion however this game does hold up to the FFVII name. The only real downside is making a square enix account.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												Let's get down to brass tacks: for vets of the series, this is Final Fantasy VII the way you remember it. If you don't have a Playstation or the ability to play this through more "unscrupulous" means, by all means this is what you want in a moddable package until the Remake comes out.Now, for you uneducated in the ways of VII, here's the real meat: Final Fantasy VII tells the tale of a ragtag little party initially out to save the Planet from being sucked dry by the Shinra Corporation. Along the way, things go south and blah blah blah even if you haven't played it you know the story with how much Square has thrown into the Compilation of VII. There are some plot twists that most may not know of because of the framing around it, and if you want to know the whole backstory of what led up to the various famous events, you'll find VII to be very accomodating in the way of letting you experience them.This is done by way of various, at the time and even now, enjoyable facets of the ATB battle system. Active Time Battle is just what it sounds like: each character has a bar, it fills up over time, and then you can make your action. If you choose Active for the battle system, enemies can attack while you make your choice. Choose Wait, and action pauses while you do so. This allows you a small degree of customization on the difficulty of the battles, as you can either choose to think your turns through or you can put yourself on the spot by making decisions relatively on the fly when a boss is breathing down your neck.Beyond this lies the Materia system. An extension of the Esper system from VI, Materia function as a condensed way to grant your party magic. As you battle, the Materia grow and develop skills. When mastered they create duplicates, and no skill is tied to one character. You want a scary guy with a gun on his arm dropping meteors? Go ahead and give him Comet. Get the urge to make your meteor dropper the spiky haired blond dude? Take the Comet materia off of the scary guy, give it to spiky dude. Simple as that, but so much more in-depth because of the stat boosts and penalties attached to the materia itself. HP, strength, luck, magic, all affected by the type of materia equipped.The bottom line, barring any moddable issues that other reviews may cover, is this: VII is still as good as it was. Nostalgia goggles are wicked in terms of this game for some people, but as someone who played it at 12 years old then came back 15 years later and played it again? A few times? I still had a major blast with it. If it's on sale, pick it up. If you have a small fortune spare on hand from playing the market? Pick it up then too. It's a long ride, but it's enjoyable.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												WARNING! THIS REVIEW CONTAINS A LIFE STORY: Back in elementry school around the mid 2000's (In high school now) my friends and I would play pretend at recess. We would make up stories and pretend to be characters we made up fighting imaginary bad guys. We had stories that would actually span over a long time. I guess it was kind of like basic LARPing. One day as we we're heading back from recess one of my friends was saying something about new villains that would appear. The only name I remeber hearing and possibly one of the only non made up characters in our game was Sephiroth the One Winged Angel. At the time I had no idea who he was. That is how I was first introduced to Final Fantasy VII. As I was first finding out about it my friend would pretend to be Sephiroth while we fought him as he sang One Winged Angel. I eventualy figured out my friend had discovered Sephiroth was a character from the previously mentioned game Final Fantasy VII. Apparently my friend had discovered it online and developed an obsession with the game and even more so with it's villain Sephiroth despite never having actually played it. As he told me about it he wore off on me and we both became FF7/Sephiroth fanatics. We never played the game but were completley obsessed. I would listen to the one winged angel song multiple times a day and dreamed that some day I might get to play the game. I was also constantly renting the movie that's a sequel to the movie and forcing my older sister (who hated the movie and my obsession) to watch it with me. I forget exactly when but as time went on and I stopped hanging out with that friend due to him moving I stopped caring about it. Before I ever got to play the game my obsession ended. I actually felt kinda ashamed that I was ever obsessed with a game I never played. For a few years the only thing I felt about FFVII was shame for having been so obsessed. Then just this last june I got steam at the advice of some friends. After having it for a little bit I discovered Final Fantasy VII on the steam store. Due to the fact I had heard on the internet that it's a good game and some curiosity left over from my obsession I eventaully decided to get it. I finally did just few weeks ago and my obsession was reborn. This game is freaking AMAZING! I just beat it a couple minutes ago and it normally takes me FOREVER to finish a game! Everything about it is great. The story is great, the battle system is great, the music is great, the bosses are great, the world map is great there isn't anything that isn't great. If you're considering getting this game stop considering. Buy it right now! If you're not intrested in this game at all BUY IT ANYWAY! If you play this game and don't like it THERE IS SOMETHING WRONG WITH YOU! This game gets 11/10.

												Game itself is great but there is a big issue which has me wondering wether to give a thumbs up or not as i right this so ill start with what i like.excellent story line, maybe not for everyone but for me quite engrossing some cool twists even if characters would now be considered generic achetypes elsewhere.awsome combat, yes its turn based but the strategy in set5ting up characters with the right gear and meteria abilities is both fun and rewarding.Sephiroth, such an awsome bad guy he deserves a mention of his own, like heath ledgers joker to batman sephiroth is a damn excellent bad guy.although the plot is fairly serious the game contains a great deal of humour and fun moments that will have you laughing out loud.My god the sound track is brilliant, yes its a bit out dated but it still rings through me when sephiroths theme comes on, and that very emotional moment late game its like a bomb going off (im not going to give spoilers)this game is a classic!!!now with the issue, im sure anyone that owns this game will immediately recognise bad gate way error 502. its depressing that this game has DRM turned on and the server or whatever program that governs it is pathetic!!! and means that actually getting to enjoy this game almost ends up coming down to pot luck!!!seems the best work around is to start a square enix account and link your steam account to it which seems to have mainly fixed the issue for mein closing ill go with a thumbs up, the game itself is an age less classic that has echoed through decades and still has fans that have demanded a HD remake so much that square have finally had to give in to the pressure

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												This game is superb. I never had the chance to play this game as a kid and thanks to Steam, I can finally play it. 20 hours in the game and this is the best RPG I have played in years! the story pulls you in and doesn't let you go until you finish, the combat is pretty fun and there is a good variety in attacks and magic spells including summoning, healing, cursing and elemental attacks. the Ultimate attacks achieving at a certain point in battle are nicely made and very well executed despite the limited technology used to create this masterpiece. The world is diverse in many ways, you travel oceans, cities, villages, caves, mines, deserts, hovering theme parks, mountains and many more. There are a lot of side quests to finish and the rewards for finishing them are worth your time if you put hours into finishing a single quest. the variety of monsters to fight is truly jaw dropping and the amount of boss battles each with their own abilities and disadvantages really makes you think of the best way to defeat them. You simply must buy this game and all of its many features and the superb storyline which is both emotional and dark. Once you play this game, you will fall in love with for many years to come

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												My favourite game of all time (and I just replayed Ocarina of Time to make sure!).  I love this game so much I played and completed all of the main numbered final fantasy titles since playing this on PS1 way back in '97.  This PC port is far better than it was back in the day (on my 486!) and FFVII has never looked better.  The music has now been sorted too and rightly so as this is one of the greatest soundtracks of all time (Aerith's Theme, Cosmo Canyon, One Winged Angel anyone!).In my opinion this game has the perfect mix of steam punk sci-fi and fantasy and has too many memorable scenes and characters to mention here!  The battle and materia systems have also never been beaten for me, in terms of being simultaeneously easy to learn, but allowing for some really satisfying tactical decisions.  This game was amazing at the time and just when you think you've seen it all the summons come along and push the spectacle to new heights.  I think this game has aged pretty well (nostalgia notwithstanding!), but all I can say is if you are an RPG fan you owe it to yourself to check it out!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												Attempting to do a perfect game run as I'm writing this review during my holiday. As far as how I'd rate this port, I'd give it a 7/10. You do need to log into a square enix account the first time you load up the game. After that however, you dont need to be connected online to play this game. Just disable cloud saves if you want to play offline. Still a bit annoying you have to do that, but once you do, you should be fine with playing the game.My main issue with this port is that in the PS1 version, battle menus ran 60fps, which made slot limit breaks smooth. In this version, menus match the fps of battles, which mean they'll also be 15fps. You can feel it's a little slow compared to the ps1 version when one of your characters reaches a limit break and your bar, while moving up fast, feels more choppy compared to the ps1 version. Some of the mini games are also cut to 30 fps instead of the ps1 60 fps counterpart, such as the speed square and the snowboard mini game. Now I hear that there are fixes for this, but in return, your steam achievements for FF7 will not work, so in the end you have to decide whether it's worth it to sacrifice your achievements or put up with the slowdowns in this game. Other than that though, this is still an outstanding classic for you to play, and even with those issues I mentioned, I ended up getting used to them after awhile. I really do like the achievements in this game too. All in all, I really do recommend this game if you're thinking about playing it, but if you want to have the best version of ff7, I would suggest playing it on PS1.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												There's a reason so many people call this the best game of all time. I won't give it that title, but this is the definitive Final Fantasy experience, and it is definitely the one of the best RPGs ever made. It stands right up there with the likes of Chrono Trigger and some of the earlier Final Fantasy games. If you're an RPG fan and you've never played this game, just buy it, you owe it to yourself. I am a highly critical gamer - I nitpick everything and usually don't enjoy many games anymore - but this game charmed me when I played it on the PSX, and it charms me again every time I boot it up on Steam. There just hasn't been an RPG this good since the generation it was made in. If your eyes absolutely cannot handle old-school graphics you may be skeptical, but understand that when this game was released, it was on the top of it's class in that department. So many years later, and no RPG has done what FFVII has done.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												Writing a review about FF7 without letting the nostalgia goggles get in the way is difficult. This is a game that I picked up in 1998 or 1999 after seeing a friend play it at his house. I immediately fell in love with it. It's immersive, the music is amazing, and the Materia system changed how people view equipment in RPGs. The game is constantly moving, and as you progress through the game you really gain an appreciation for every area you've explored through.I'm not someone to tell you to play an NES game in the year 2014. Old games do not age well. However, they did a really good job of freshening up FF7 for a PC re-release, and if you don't play this game then it's my opinion that you're missing out on the greatest RPG of all-time.

												FF7 is amazing, I played it first in 2009 due to somehow missing it back in the 90's, and it STILL blew me away. It's got incredible production values for the time it was made.However, I do not suggest the Steam version. The MIDI tracks sound terrible and the soundtrack's completely butchered because of it. I don't recommend the older PC release either, as the game simply doesn't work on recent operating systems.The best way to play this is the actual PS1 copy, or the PSN store versions. The second best way is to play the old release on Windows XP, with a "combat models while out-of-combat" mod.Avoid FF8 like the plague unless you're a full-blown weeaboo with a child's understanding of story-writing.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2013
												This has got to be up there as one of my favorite RPG's of all time. It's certainly up there on my list of all time great games aswell. Its one of the few games from years ago that I can play these days and not get bothered about the graphics. The story line is amazing, totally original back then and still not repeated now. Not forgetting some very impressive characters. The battles and enemies are varied. There are quite a few battles that require a real strategy. Unless you use a guide and follow it word for word, you will be able to play it through over and over and still find new things about the game. The mini games and side quests can keep you entertained for hours on end.You can put in 30 hours or 100 hours in a single run, its completely down to how you feel during that play through.This game has one of the best soundtracks I have ever heard. In a way it makes the game and adds to the story. The bad thing is this steam version does not have the high quality version of the soundtrack which does take something away from the game. A petition is being done at the moment and at 1100+ players at the time of wriiting this has been sent to the owners who say they are looking into it. If they do change it and update this version then I would give it 10 out of 10!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Same game I played back in the 90s... over and over again.  I never stopped playing this game.  It made sense to get the Steam version so I could have easy access to the game and various PC mods for it.This is not a port of the PSX version!  It is a patched version of the old PC port from the 90s with Steam achievements and non-Steam cloud saves and controller support.  There is nothing wrong with that.  The game worked fairly well back in the day.  However, Square should be ashamed of such a lazy re-release.  There should have been more work put into extra features and graphical enhancements.  There are some mods for tweaking the graphics, but I would still enjoy some official love.Overall, the game is only worth getting if you never played the original version or have nostalgic feelings toward FF7 like I have.  Wait for a sale if you can.  I've seen the game sell for $4.

content:
Posted: March 19
												This was my first FF game, so I didn't know what to expect. I started it and I saw some ludicrous character models that made me question what I just bought. But soon after getting into the game I was gripped. The gameplay is solid and easily beats any 2017 AAA game. The music is great and it never gets tiresome, it makes playing for hours feel like minutes. But the one thing that stands out is the story. Unlike most games, the story in FFVII is very interesting and unpredictable. There's a good variety of characters that become quite memorable after you spend some time playing. Before I got into the game, I expected cheesy dialogue and a kid-friendly story, but the game is far from that. The story and dialogue are made for everyone, but only adults understand the full story. The only problem I've noticed is the controller compability, but that can be easily fixed with the "JoyToKey" application which you can download for free online. It's totally worth the setting up because the game is unbearable with a keyboard in my opinion. Overall this is a timeless 10/10. I recommend it to everyone.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												This game changed my standards for videogames. It is by far the best RPG I have ever played if you have the opportunity to buy this game I highly recommend it. It takes roughly 50 hours to beat the main story without guides or whatever the game was entirely worth every minute I put into it. The soundtrack is surprisingly good. A lot of people will say "ZOMG THIS GAEM HAS THE BEST MUSICS IVE EVER HEARD HOLY TOLEDO" no seriously though, this music is catchy, it perfectly portrays every emotion it is supposed to capture and it will make you feel exactly how you should during every scene of the game. Also the combat system is unique and captivating, it is much like its predecessors with the whole timed wait for using your next move and whatnot except this time if you get hit enough you get a limit break for each character with which they will unleash an intensely powerful barage of moves that do loads of damage and make you feel very powerful. This game influenced many games' leveling systems for spells and what have you and with good reason. Buy this game when you get the chance you won't regret it.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												I didn't play this game in my childhood unlike most people that I know, but instead I started playing Final Fantasy titles aged about 23. I kept arguing with my boyfriend that I couldn't handle the graphics for FFVII and would wait for a remake before attempting to play it (I had tried the PS3 port) but he kept telling me it would never be remade...I finally picked up the game in a sale in Spring 2015 having come to the conclusion that it would never get a remake and I'd just have to deal with the blocky graphics. I played it, and fell in love with it - the story, the characters and the music.The day after I completed the game we were watching the stream of Sony's E3 conference... I cried a little, fell off the sofa and still to this day am a little convinced that I must have caused the remake to be announced.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												Keep in mind, this is a very short review. I am going to give an opinion of the game but I wont go into depth becuase I am sure I would end up leaving something out even if I sat here for 7 hours trying to write the review, so here it is:This game is one of the best games I have ever played, if not the absolute best. Nostalgia is not a factor here what so ever as I first played this game last year after buying it during the holiday sale. This game is NOT overhyped by any means, don't let someone's opinion of that prevent you from playing this game. It was amazing when it first released and it is amazing now. The music is perfect and fits every situation in the game while sounding great. The story is better than almost any I have ever experienced in a work of fiction, including novels and movies. The graphics are simple, but because they are stylized I like the way the game looks anyway, simple does not always equal bad. If you love turn-based gameplay, the you will love this game. If you don't like turn-based gameplay, you might warm up to it after this game. Having three chracters with an "Active Time" system makes the battles fast paced and forces you to think quickly. The materia system will you an extreme amount of freedom when playing, allowing you to have characters act similarly to any Final Fantasy class type. Or you could just make them unique, they don't have to mirror any class if you want them too. Combos of many different types are possible with the materia system as well. The characters in this game are some of the most well done, multi-dimetional characters I have ever seen in a work of fiction. Both the chracters and story end up being so complex (without being messy) that to this day people still have heated debates on them. This game also has a habit of making unforgettable moments for the player, but for obvious reason I wont state examples. There is so much more to this game, but as I said before, I am not going to make this a long review.This game is a perfect 10 out of 10, you really should play it. Also Cloud Strife, the main character of this game, is now going to be in Super Smash Brothers 4. That's pretty cool.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												Final Fantasy 7 is (obviously) the seventh entry in the numerical series of the Final Fantasy game. Throughout the game you play as Cloud Strife, ex-soldier, with your party made up of Tifa, Barret, Cait Sith, Vincent, Red XIII, Aeris and Cid (I'm pretty sure that's everyone, apologies here if there are more).The game is split up into three parts, however Part 2 and 3 are considerably shorter than Part 1:The main quest in Part 1 is around 12-14 hours The main quest in Part 2 is around 4-6 hoursThe main quest in Part 3 is around 30 mins-2 hours.I'll split this review into four parts (the first three parts being about the game with the last part being about anything else such as music).PART 1:Part 1 opens with you playing as Cloud on an AVALANCE mission (AVALANCE is the eco-terrorist group in the game who is at a constant battle with Shin'ra). Cloud starts off as being tough and only really cares about the money he'll get from this mission which makes him start off being somewhat unlikable-which in this game isn't a neccacarly bad thing and Cloud becomes very likable after the first AVALANCE mission in the game. Throughout Part 1 your party will be made up of Cloud, Barret, Tifa, Aeris, Cait Sith and Red XIII. Part 1 goes at a steady pace with the story becoming very intriguing as you go through the game.The bosses in Part 1 are very easy to defeat WHICH wouldn't be a problem however considering you'll be spending the majority of your adventure on Part 1, even if you're just going through the main quest, it'll make you at first feel powerful which is great however it soon becomes tiresome.The ending of Part 1 is considered one of the most amazing twists in video game history-however I would disagree as throughout Part 1 the twist was constantly foreshadowed, such as when you first meet Cait Sith (whose twist I view as being greater than the ending of Part 1).One of the most ridiculous parts in Part 1 is the story explaining why Barret's hand has been replaced with a gun instead. I have no problem with the backstory about his missing hand and found what happened with Dyne and Barret very touching. Although I have no problem with Dyno killing people for no apparent reason this part has annoyed me for two reasons, one of which because he can and the second of which is didn't have that much to do with the main story, this could easily have been explained as a side quest. All in all Part 1 was a very entertaining segment of this amazing game.PART 2:Part 2 of Final Fantasy 7 is when the game kind of goes off the rails (in a bad way though this doesn't stop the enjoyment). In this part you will have other members added to your party-such as Cid. Part 2 holds two of my favorite scenes-one which explains the truth of when Sepheroth set fire to Nebliehem and also the truth about Cloud, unfortunately these two events weren't enough to put Final Fantasy 7 back on the rails.In the first half of Part 2 the boss fights are fairly easy, just like in part 1 however half way through things become a little more interesting and the boss fights becoming harder and harder, with the fight between your party and Hojo being the 2nd hardest of the game.A lot of the time in Part 2 you play as the other members of your party-such as Tifa so that way you don't get bored of Cloud just yet. There are several interesting mini games-such the snow boarding segment of Part 2 which  I would argue is perhaps the best part of the game-would have been great if there were similar segments incorporating into the main story! Unfortunately there are perhaps more bad minigames than good-such as the tower defense and submarine mini games. I was looking forward to the tower defense mini game however this was ruined by its slow pace, even when sped up and I found the controls for the submarine mini game to be too clumsy and the mini game was too easy, even for my liking.PART 3:Part 3 of the game is very short-the main story not being that long (it's only really the fight between your party and Sephiroth) with the rest being made up of end-game content. The final boss fight is fantastic-it's long and hard (and as such the hardest fight in the game). It is the only one of two boss battles which requires you to use your brain (the other boss fight being Hojo). Unfortunately the game's ending offered nothing interesting-not even a twist (even a very crappy twist would have made me slightly more happy) however this is very small compared to the feeling you get after the defeat of Sephiroth.PART 4:In this final part I will talk about things such as music and graphics. The music of the game is very beautiful at first however the repetitiveness of it makes me want to stab knives through my ears-it could work as great torture tactics perhaps (take note MI6), there isn't that much variety with music at all, the same would be with the sound, not that much variety.This is of course a port of the original game released for the PS1 so I won't say much about the graphics (besides-graphics don't make a game). The game is very dramatic so it makes you wonder why the graphics is the way it is (which makes the game not seem very dramatic) instead of graphics similar to the resident evil games, however the games graphics does work and is what makes the game what it is in my opinion.There is many materia in the game, which makes up the spells and abilities your party has and also may take away or increase some of your attributes such as HP and MP which becomes very important as you get towards the end of Part 2, so pick your materia wisely!The weapon models used in the game are interesting and aren't the same model retextured over and over again unlike in most games which gives each weapon its own kind of feel. Despite there being plenty of weapons to chose from in the begging of the game, as you go further into the game you realise there isn't that much variety at all.My second-to final complaint about this game would be the "class system". The game somewhat has a classless system due to the use of materia-which allows you to give spells and summons to characters though it feels like you must give each character a certain materia due to they way they're presented with their weapons or limit breaks-an example being Aeris. One of her limit breaks "healing wand" heals all of your party members which make syou feel like you must give her materia which will give her healing kind of spells.My final complaint is very small however it does make the game very annoying and this would be summoning. I do enjoy the summoning in the game however after every battle you can summon the summon(s) you used in the previous battle which means you may be able to get through several parts of the game easily and their animations are long which can somewhat annoy you later on in the game when you'll be using summoning a lot.Despite my complaints-I found the game to be very interesting and is perhaps the best game I've ever played. I would recommend this game to anyone looking to get into the final fantasy series, looking for a very dramatic game or want a game which is great even by today standards which could run on a low end computer! However I would not recommend this for RPG fans due to the linear game play which makes the game feel more like a high fantasy turn based adventure game rather than an RPG.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												"Overrated" Is a term people seem to throw around a lot these days. The more I hear it, the more I realize what an empty, vain and pathetic thing it is to have so little bad to say about something that instead you have to resort to devaluing everyone else's praise for it. Once I really got into it I thought to myself "Damn whoever caled this overrated for the millionth time, who steered me away from this gem with a criticism not even able to really say anything about the games faults, and damn me for being dumb enough to listen to such an empty claim" This game has faults, yes, but none of them make it any less of a great game.FF7 is one of many masterpieces to be plagued with these claims of being "overrated" I have never played the original, I was never touched by the nostalgia, I do not think it is the best game or even the best RPG game. But hell, it deserves the praise it gets through and through. Like many other entries in the FF series, it has an amazing, unique battle system that is fun to test and level up in, a good story with plenty of shockers, feeling and depth, not to mention the godly soundtrack. I give this game a 9.5/10 easily, and provided the remake isn't chock full of DLC and other money grabs I will be getting that as soon as I can.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												Game: Final Fantasy VIIGenre: RPGPublisher/Developer: Squareenix/SquaresoftSystem: Steam (PC)Total Score: 93/100Value Score: 9.3/10• Story: 10/10• Characters: 10/10• GamePlay: 8/10• Graphics: 9/10• Sound: 9/10• Music: 10/10• Length: 10/10• Replay Value: 7/10• Player Value: 10/10Pros+The Steam port's resolution is higher than the PS1 versions and also fixes the glitches and errors of the original PC version+Ability to play in PS1 visual style or in Steam visual style (higher resolution)+Music has been patched to the PS1 version's OST rather than using the original PC version's OST which was remixed and unpopular+Achievements have been added+A Character booster is available for anyone to use to increase their HP and MP to the maximum 9999/999. content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												I've loved Final Fantasy VII for years, I still have the discs for the fist play station. Am I ecstatic that they put it on steam??  Do you even have to ask???  For those of you that have never played any Final Fantasy games, I totally recommend that you try this one first.  The graphics are the same as they were on playstation if there are any of you that are like me and remember the game.  Steam also has a guide for all of those hiding potions,GFs, etc... and guides you through.  The only change that I've seen so far of couse are that you use the keyboard keys instead of the playstation controller.  The keyboard keys are not hard at all and pretty well lined up. I would recommend this game to anyone young or old, because   even back in it's newest days it had an awesome story line.  I have yet to see a game come even close to this game's story line.  The story line,and the fact that in many parts of the game you are free to go run around the map and level are  two of the best things about this lovely turn-based rpg.  There are many other good things about it but I'd rather not spoil anything for you.  Happy Gaming!  I know it'll be a happy gaming day for me for sure!

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												Keep in mind, this is a very short review. I am going to give an opinion of the game but I wont go into depth becuase I am sure I would end up leaving something out even if I sat here for 7 hours trying to write the review, so here it is:This game is one of the best games I have ever played, if not the absolute best. Nostalgia is not a factor here what so ever as I first played this game last year after buying it during the holiday sale. This game is NOT overhyped by any means, don't let someone's opinion of that prevent you from playing this game. It was amazing when it first released and it is amazing now. The music is perfect and fits every situation in the game while sounding great. The story is better than almost any I have ever experienced in a work of fiction, including novels and movies. The graphics are simple, but because they are stylized I like the way the game looks anyway, simple does not always equal bad. If you love turn-based gameplay, the you will love this game. If you don't like turn-based gameplay, you might warm up to it after this game. Having three chracters with an "Active Time" system makes the battles fast paced and forces you to think quickly. The materia system will you an extreme amount of freedom when playing, allowing you to have characters act similarly to any Final Fantasy class type. Or you could just make them unique, they don't have to mirror any class if you want them too. Combos of many different types are possible with the materia system as well. The characters in this game are some of the most well done, multi-dimetional characters I have ever seen in a work of fiction. Both the chracters and story end up being so complex (without being messy) that to this day people still have heated debates on them. This game also has a habit of making unforgettable moments for the player, but for obvious reason I wont state examples. There is so much more to this game, but as I said before, I am not going to make this a long review.This game is a perfect 10 out of 10, you really should play it. Also Cloud Strife, the main character of this game, is now going to be in Super Smash Brothers 4. That's pretty cool.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												I didn't play this game in my childhood unlike most people that I know, but instead I started playing Final Fantasy titles aged about 23. I kept arguing with my boyfriend that I couldn't handle the graphics for FFVII and would wait for a remake before attempting to play it (I had tried the PS3 port) but he kept telling me it would never be remade...I finally picked up the game in a sale in Spring 2015 having come to the conclusion that it would never get a remake and I'd just have to deal with the blocky graphics. I played it, and fell in love with it - the story, the characters and the music.The day after I completed the game we were watching the stream of Sony's E3 conference... I cried a little, fell off the sofa and still to this day am a little convinced that I must have caused the remake to be announced.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												"Overrated" Is a term people seem to throw around a lot these days. The more I hear it, the more I realize what an empty, vain and pathetic thing it is to have so little bad to say about something that instead you have to resort to devaluing everyone else's praise for it. Once I really got into it I thought to myself "Damn whoever caled this overrated for the millionth time, who steered me away from this gem with a criticism not even able to really say anything about the games faults, and damn me for being dumb enough to listen to such an empty claim" This game has faults, yes, but none of them make it any less of a great game.FF7 is one of many masterpieces to be plagued with these claims of being "overrated" I have never played the original, I was never touched by the nostalgia, I do not think it is the best game or even the best RPG game. But hell, it deserves the praise it gets through and through. Like many other entries in the FF series, it has an amazing, unique battle system that is fun to test and level up in, a good story with plenty of shockers, feeling and depth, not to mention the godly soundtrack. I give this game a 9.5/10 easily, and provided the remake isn't chock full of DLC and other money grabs I will be getting that as soon as I can.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												I first played this game when I was 12. I remember spending most nights either manically grinning at how cool the game and graphics were, or heartbroken by bit of storyline. I had the guide (lost in a move sadly), and its what made me turn from my megadrive to the pc for gaming.Flash forward to 15 year later, when I see this for sale and think I will re-live the good old days. I have a family and work, so I'm still playing late at night, only difference is now I'm not being naughty up past my bed time. That being said there have been nights when my wife has walked in and I almost jumped out of my skin, thats how hard the nostalgia has hit me.FFVII has some of the best characters, and is an amazing story. The only downside is the graphics which for a 19 year old game are pretty awesome, but thats not saying much by todays standards.The remake is supposedly on its way, but I am wary about the innevitably changes and how it could taint my memories. That being said I will probably give it a go, but if you havent played the game, or like me you played it years ago I would recommend having another go now!TLDR:Re-live your childhood, or set it right with what you missed. This is easily my favourite game of all time. Just don't expect ground breaking graphics.10/10 would be 12 again.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												Despite my coming to the party 18 years late, Final Fantasy VII was one of my favourite games I played in 2015. Expecting greatness when I went in, I tried my best not to get immersed in it thinking it was good because of all the universal praise it gets; it didn't take long for me to realize I didn't have to, because I could see it for myself.Before I get to the actual meat and potatoes part of this review, looking at the negative reviews, I see a lot of criticism towards Square Enix about having to make a Squenix account in order to play, which is understandable in 2016 with a lot of people being very protective of their information (seeing as some personal information is mandatory to sign up, if I remember correctly). If you're so worried about this, I recommend you read more about it, because if I'm going to be honest, I'm not familiar with what Square Enix can and can't do with what you give them. If you don't want to support Squenix, I don't want to support piracy, but you should put some thought into it.I'm also going to make it clear that this is the only Final Fantasy game I've ever played; if you've played other games in the series and are looking for a comparison, this guide is likely not for you. Final Fantasy VII is thought of universally as one of the best RPGs, or even one of the best video games of all time, and while I'm not sure how much I agree with that, I can definitely stand by the claim that the majority of its praise is well deserved.The characters are all memorable, creative and unique, and are personal enough to make you care about what happens to them and the world around them. The dialogue between them is excellent, and portrays a great level of personality and emotion, and creates great relationships such as the passive-aggressive friendship between Cloud and Barret, and how Yuffie is seen as the immature Materia loving ninja girl always looking for a fight.The 85-song soundtrack is incredible, with songs that portray emotion and songs that portray anger, or a sense of adventure, or a feeling of despair, anxiousness, being back in your hometown, any song you'd expect in a dramatic RPG, just done better, and made to work on PlayStation 1 hardware, no less (although I don't really know how all that works). And if you enjoy it as much as I do, I recommend you listen to the official Final Fantasy VII - Piano Collections album (Cinco de Chocobo and Tifa's Theme are my favourites).The graphics, in all honesty, have NOT aged well; the pixelated battle backgrounds, while revolutionary for their time and still a nice touch today are not amazing visually, but in terms of the blocky and polygonal model appearances and the repetitive shrug, anger and disappointment animations used for nearly every character with a humanoid build, they're charming in a sense, in the same way people look at the 30+ year old Super Mario Bros. Mario sprite. And if the PS1 style graphics bother you that much, there are indeed graphical mods out there (although I couldn't tell you much about them, I've never used any).Despite being a typical RPG, the gameplay is fresh and exciting, even going into it today. The Materia system, in which you attach magic-based attacks, monster summons, or bonuses like HP Plus or Magic Plus makes the entire magic system more interesting and complex, and the unique 'ATB' battle system allows for real-time RPG combat as opposed to turn-based (although this can be configured in the game's settings; if this is your first Final Fantasy game you might want to read about ATB because it can be confusing at first; I actually jumped into this game expecting turn-based and was surprised when the enemy would attack me in the middle of a menu. If this is not for you, look into the options menu.) Limit breaks keep the battles interesting and can quickly turn the tide of a losing battle, used by filling the Limit Gauge which fills the more damage you take (but make note this is far from a crutch to help a bad player.) And the last thing I'm going to mention, but far from the least important, is the story; while complicated and sometimes unnecessarily complex, the story of Final Fantasy VII is a long roller-coaster of surprise and drama, involving AVALANCHE's quest to stop Shinra Headquarters, Sephiroth's rampage and plot to kill the world, black materia, lifestream, Mako energy, among many other subjects.Branching storylines include Cloud's conflict with his real self, Barret's disappointment in himself for failing to protect his hometown, and many other unique and dramatic storylines within the game. It's honestly a lot to keep track of and remember, and even harder to write about, but the point I'm making is that the story is never lacking in any places and you never feel as if what you're doing has no important outcome or consequence; I was thoroughly entertained without the game, which I honestly didn't expect; I expected to play it continously every day for maybe an hour, but I would spend days playing in 6-hour periods, which is something I rarely do for any game I enjoy, just to see what would end up happening because of the actions I took in the past.In terms of things I wasn't pleased with or I feel could have been done better, I feel like I need to make note that the story is pretty hard to follow at times, and it can be hard to lose track of what you're doing and why you're doing it, but this might just be a personal thing.On the topic of cons, this game has a lot of unnecessary minigames, and I mean a LOT of them. What makes this worse is that this port of Final Fantasy VII, while completely functional and complete with Cloud saving (heh), if you're playing on a keyboard, the game is not set to recognize what button you have to what input, so if you're being instructed to press a key, it will say [CANCEL] for example instead of [X]. This goes the same way no matter what kind of controller you're using; a friend of mine played it on a GameCube controller.Back on the topic of minigames, I'm having Vietnam flashbacks remembering a marching minigame in which you have to press the keys it asks for (which you might not be familiar with because it doesn't tell you which letter on the keyboard), and other similar minigames in this vein. There's an unnecessary amount that honestly could just be changed into a cutscene, such as a slap-fight between Tifa and the female Turk (although this one was actually kinda funny), a squat battle (you heard me), pushing barrels onto Shinra soldiers who are chasing Aeris (or Aerith ♥♥♥♥ you), among others. Some of them are fun for the most part, but generally speaking I feel like they're just wasting my time, but I appreciate the effort to give the user some control.But despite the game's problems, I would recommend Final Fantasy VII to anybody in a heartbeat. TL;DR, the characters are unique and personal, the music sounds spectaular and works great with the game, the story makes you care and keeps you involved, and the gameplay is nothing you've seen before. I would recommend this for full price.[this is the part where i don't know how to close a review]

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												A classic.  Chances are if you're buying this you've played it already.  If not, well you'll get to see what all us thirty-somethings are talking about.  There are options to run at a higher resolution and dither the textures and stuff like that... but there isn't much point.  This game has polygons and fmv's and whatnot - but it's really born from a 16-bit era design philosophy.  Keep that in mind while playing - it's more about the story than the presentation - and that story is a parable for the true struggle of our age, which is why it resonates with so many people.  The irony here is that Squenix is behaving more and more like the evil corporation in its cautionary tale...Worth the 40 or so hours, I say.  Get it.  Run it at low rez.  Punch Square-Enix in the face for big-brothering you before letting you play.  (An account is required!)  Wish you had just kept your Playstation and curse the death of privacy.  Square:  Either you die Squaresoft... or you live long enough to see yourself become Square-Enix...

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												I will admit I never, repeat, NEVER completed a Final Fantasy game before and the only one I remember seeing all the way to the end was the first Final Fantasy on the Playstation (My sister beat the game.) Due to me being sheltered for so long from the begining era of the PS2, I barely heard about this game for a long time.But when I heard that this game was being parodied by my favorite YouTube channel Team Four Star, I thought it looked interesting. And I seem very interested in the remake trailer since everyone was wanting a remake for so long.I had some money leftover in Steam. I suddenly saw FF7 for purchase on it. I figured what the heck, and bought it.I'm afraid to say that it's the greatest RPG of all time because all kinds of people have different tastes. What are my thoughts?Nothing but amazing.The story is pretty good with some touches of things from other types of media. Combining action, peril, slight love, comedy, and drama, but most of all, character build up. Cloud seemed to be a perfect example. I will admit that this game is NOT easy and will require lots of stradegy in order to get from the begining to the very end. However it is worth it with it's dark story that with these characters fills you with hope as well as a fantastic soundtrack.The only flaws is that there seem to be no way to use specific controllers without using mods. I had to download a specific mod to make this game compatible with my 360 controller.I hope the remake is just as good as this orignal. Now I'm interested in hunting down all the other Final Fantasy games that I missed out on.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												It's the good old PS1 classic from late 90's in the form of a good pc port. Many people, including me, know it as one of the best RPGs ever done or maybe the best of all time. The one that started it all. I think it was my first big RPG/JRPG I ever played, when I was 10 years old.Simply put, it's a masterpiece. The story, characters, world, gameplay like Materia-system + turn-based combat and soundtrack are what make this game really memorable throughout the years. Nobuo Uematsu is a wizard when it comes to making game soundtracks. Even though this is one of the older games that does not have voice acting, the fantastic music is one huge part that makes the world feel alive and give you emotions. It's still perhaps the greatest OST ever made for games imo. And it is always nice to imagine how the characters sound like when had no VA.I still enjoy replaying it, be it for the nostalgia or something else and it's been almost 20 years since original release. FFVII is one of those timeless classics, like MGS1, that never gets old :).Those who never had the chance to play FFVII back in the days, if you can get past the old graphics (characters look funny I know), you will find a very special experience that won't disappoint. Some cutscenes show more detailed characters. If you don't want to wait for the upcoming FFVII:Remake, give this one a try.

												This is the game that stole my teenage years and one of the few I don't look back at and say "I want my time back", because it changed a part of me.The story, although confusing, also resonates well with today's world problems and I believe there couldn't be a better time for the upcoming remake. You will laugh. You will cry. And when you complete it you will be happier than ever for that measely 12$ you spent for this experience, because it's one you won't get anywhere else.Do you want to try a good japanese style RPG but don't know where to start? Buy this game.Do you want to relive the game and don't mind outdated graphics? Buy it.Do you want to play the game but live for graphics rather than gameplay and story? Wait for the remake.Do you hate Final Fantasy? If yes, you're fired.Why is this game good, you say? Why is it being remade? This should explain it all.

												FF7 is a true classic.  Though it was made in Square's golden era, Square is about as bad as they come nowadays.  I'm not here to bag on Square though...I'm here to bag on the worst gamepad support I've ever seen in a game.  Using a Logitech 310...will not work. Why this is even let on Steam in the current state, I have no idea.  It's like they took a steaming dump on one of the greatest games I've ever played.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												Firstly, my rating: 9/10This game is all together flawless. Aside from the simple nostalgia of going back to my first and favorite RPG, the game, in itself, is amazing. The combat system is tweaked from the previous, 2-D Final Fantasies, and while it could be argued that the protagonist in the game can be whiny a good amount of the time (And I will not argue that), I personally feel it adds to his character. This is only a review, so I won't post that whole rant here, but overall, he's actually my favorite protagonist of all the series.The ONLY flaw, and the only reason this is a 9/10, rather than 10/10, is that the steam version does not allow the HD patch that is available. Valve Anti-Cheat will strip you of all your achievements for the game if you install it, which is unfortunate. The game is a solid 10/10 for me, I would always recommend you at least try the title, even if the other games were not to your liking, and I'm docking a single point for this STEAM review as Valve Anti-Cheat is a pain for this game.Cheers

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Welcome to the past!  Sexy, sexy polygons.  Final Fantasy VII plays through your emotions by telling an intricate story about life, love, loss, confusion, revenge, and death.  The simple (almost lego) character models provided a challenge that we don't really worry about these days: The characters had to express emotions using body language (no facial expressions).  [Slight spoiler incoming] You can literally see the rage coursing through Barrett as he watches his hometown get destroyed.  I find this form of expression refreshing compared to the perfectly rendered expressions in videogames these days.  It makes it a bit difficult to empathize sometimes. But do your best- it's worth it!Also, the polygons and twisty winding maps leave a LOT to the imagination- which is a good thing.  Imagination is a form of thought that games have been slowly eliminating through our advances in detail.  That's not to say I wouldn't want this game to be remade in beautiful stunning detail- I'm all for it!  It would be like reading a book -then watching the movie and saying, "Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ they cast Ender PERFECTLY!!"  -rather than skipping the book, watching the movie and thinking it had some cool concepts~The real beauty in the game is a combination of the writer's inspiration and what they had to work with.  The writers poured their hearts into making this game- they had no idea it would be such a hit.  All they had were crummy PS1 graphics to work with, but they did what they could hoping people would like it.  Nowadays, game devs have more than enough money and the writers are getting less and less passionate because of it.  The Final Fantasy franchise has been going pretty strong and can still give me a good cry sometimes.  But why was 7 such a hit?  I'm thinking it was sincerity.Something else that comes to mind is how the mini games weave into the standard gameplay like they ARE the standard gameplay.  A player is expected to adapt on the fly~  One moment you're fighting in a turn based system, then suddenly you're on a motorcycle swatting baddies on either side!  Don't forget snowboarding, chocobo races, and other golden saucer attractions!  -----------------------SPOILER ALERT - personal feelingsFirst time through (I'm talking 12 years old), I put all my time into Aeris.  Her limit ability heals your entire party, so naturally she was my 'white mage'!  I thought she'd be there forever- we dated and everything!  I cried so many tears of sadness because of it.  *sobs-----------------------If you haven't played the game, I recommend it.  The story is stellar; each character shares a bit of the spotlight.  Some develop more than others, but they do ALL develop in some way.  Read everything and explore everything.  When you finish, go watch Advent Children and tell me what you think!

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												This game changed my life as a child, as a 5 or 6 year old watching my dad play through and trying to follow him on my own save file,  this was probably the first *real* game I ever played.  This game and Zelda: Ocarina of Time define my childhood and set me on the path of gaming for the rest of my life.The storyline is deep and rich and complex but still makes perfect sense, which is more than can be said about later entries in the series (FF13 I'm looking at you)  The graphics might be obviously dated but this game has established itself as an all time classic.  You will not regret purchasing this game if you didn't get the chance to play it on the PSX.  I've personally completed this game maybe 20 or 30 times.  And still play it now almost 20 years later at least once a year.  Graphics (for their time) 8/10Game play:  9/10Storyline:  10/10The grind: 8/10  you level up well with the story but not enough to make the game too easy.  The materia system is by far my favorite magic system in any FF title, it's almost as much fun trying to max out each one as it is playing the rest of the game.  Think getting a lv100 pokemon but even better.over all, and considering this game as stood up to the test of time for TWENTY YEARS,  I'd rate it 10/10 and not ironically or satirically.  I really mean it, this game is so god damn powerful and if you're younger it'll change your life playing it for the first time.Enjoy
