number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Welcome to the past!  Sexy, sexy polygons.  Final Fantasy VII plays through your emotions by telling an intricate story about life, love, loss, confusion, revenge, and death.  The simple (almost lego) character models provided a challenge that we don't really worry about these days: The characters had to express emotions using body language (no facial expressions).  [Slight spoiler incoming] You can literally see the rage coursing through Barrett as he watches his hometown get destroyed.  I find this form of expression refreshing compared to the perfectly rendered expressions in videogames these days.  It makes it a bit difficult to empathize sometimes. But do your best- it's worth it!Also, the polygons and twisty winding maps leave a LOT to the imagination- which is a good thing.  Imagination is a form of thought that games have been slowly eliminating through our advances in detail.  That's not to say I wouldn't want this game to be remade in beautiful stunning detail- I'm all for it!  It would be like reading a book -then watching the movie and saying, "Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ they cast Ender PERFECTLY!!"  -rather than skipping the book, watching the movie and thinking it had some cool concepts~The real beauty in the game is a combination of the writer's inspiration and what they had to work with.  The writers poured their hearts into making this game- they had no idea it would be such a hit.  All they had were crummy PS1 graphics to work with, but they did what they could hoping people would like it.  Nowadays, game devs have more than enough money and the writers are getting less and less passionate because of it.  The Final Fantasy franchise has been going pretty strong and can still give me a good cry sometimes.  But why was 7 such a hit?  I'm thinking it was sincerity.Something else that comes to mind is how the mini games weave into the standard gameplay like they ARE the standard gameplay.  A player is expected to adapt on the fly~  One moment you're fighting in a turn based system, then suddenly you're on a motorcycle swatting baddies on either side!  Don't forget snowboarding, chocobo races, and other golden saucer attractions!  -----------------------SPOILER ALERT - personal feelingsFirst time through (I'm talking 12 years old), I put all my time into Aeris.  Her limit ability heals your entire party, so naturally she was my 'white mage'!  I thought she'd be there forever- we dated and everything!  I cried so many tears of sadness because of it.  *sobs-----------------------If you haven't played the game, I recommend it.  The story is stellar; each character shares a bit of the spotlight.  Some develop more than others, but they do ALL develop in some way.  Read everything and explore everything.  When you finish, go watch Advent Children and tell me what you think!

												This game rocks, sort of.   This is a great game that I would normally recommend to anybody, but this is a very poorly optimized port. First and foremost, the graphics. The graphical limitations from 1997 would typically be a hindrance, that I understand, but this version of the game looks worse than the original version for the PSX. Secondly, the fact that you have to create a Square Enix account just to play an eighteen year old game is ridiculous. I have also had several experiences with my save data disappearing. Frankly, this game is usually amazing, but I would recommend picking up the original Playstation version or the re-release off of the PSN for the PS4.             Not to mention, at the beginning of the game, the first song in the NO. 1 reactor is a                                 few seconds off beat from the original.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												A classic game, but the PC port/update is...less than exemplary. There's the cloud saving system, for instance, but it uses your Square Enix account, not Steam's built-in Steam Cloud, and has gone down for significant periods a few times already. There's also the character booster, which is kind of a neat extra, though it depends on the cloud saving system. There are also achievements. Aside from these small value adds though, nothing seems to have been changed since the original PC port, including the inferior MIDI soundtrack from the PC version. The game can be modded to fix that and other things, but there's a catch; doing so will prevent you from using cloud saves (the system rejects any save made in a format it doesn't expect), character booster (which depends on the cloud saves), or achievements. So if you intend to mod the game to make it look better or to bring back the original soundtrack or whatever, you lose everything that Square Enix added and may as well look up the original PC port.The game is good (of course, it's FFVII), but it sucks that Square Enix made such little effort on this new version and made it impossible to update yourself without losing the only things they did add. Another problem is that it doesn't allow you to map the D-pad on your controller to movement keys. It supports the analog stick, but it's almost unusable. I had to download Xpadder and map the D-pad to arrow keys for the controller to be a functional control scheme.tl;dr: good game, bad port

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												I am going to get so ridiculed for this because of the huge cult following for this game, but I must be absolutely honest here as I am not bound by the nostalgia of rose-coloredglasses. Yes, I only played 4.9 hours on steam. I played more of the PSN version on PS3/PS4 because my computer was in a "mood". My PC however will have no major bearing on this review other than to say that I did try this game heavily modded on Steam before my computer decided to hate life.So here is my honest assessment. I would give the game a 6/10 and I only rate it that high because I liked the combat and music. If the combat and music werent so good, I would have given it alot less. I also got the game through a steam sale, (paid $3) though it is normally priced decently for what you get, either way. So that's another reason I rated it a little better than I would have.Here's a breakdown of how I felt about the game. DATED - This is a slightly more beefed up version of the original PS1 game and as such, its dated for this generation of computers and consoles. This isnt a deal breaker, just an observation. You can however heavily mod the beejeebus out of the game on PC, though to me it was more effort than it was worth and my computer decided shortly after starting that it wasnt having any of it. At that point I switched to PS4 to continue playing.STORY - The story would be great if it were fleshed out more to make more sense. As this was my first real play through, I actually had to look up summaries, synopsis and other videos to get the whole picture after I played. IGN's 7 min recap video of the FF7 world was very useful after I'd played through the game and included some information that was added in from Crisis Core, etc.The dialogue and story itself in FF7 felt incredibly rushed and left me slightly confused at times as to what was going on... Though I will admit a good chunk of the confusion here likely stemmed from poor or mistranslations, as I am assuming Square didnt change/fix the dialogue from the PS1 version.I am a huge fan of story-driven games, but this just felt muddled to me. COMBAT - Okay this is where the game shined for me. The turn-based ATB style combat is exactly what I love about old Final Fantasy titles and its just as good here as when I played FF6, FF8, and FF9. So I give a big plus to it for the combat. That was fun. VISUALS - Okay, this is where I have to give a huge MINUS to this game. The background graphics made it severely difficult for me to play this for lengthy periods of time. The game (especially unmodded) would literally give me headaches andI'dhave to stop playing. I had this problem back when I tried to play the original on PS1. I ended up giving my original PS1 game to a friend back in the day because I just couldnt deal with the eye strain and headaches from the visuals at the time. I was hoping that had changed, but not as much as I would have liked. I stillhad to take frequent "recovery" breaks. This is something to think about if your like me and had eye strain from the original.Also, Trying to find my way around a given section of map was often unclear because the flat 2D graphics made it hard to determine what was actually traversible area or what was just background. I literally got stuck so many times where I had to load up a video walkthrough to figure out where I was supposed to go, and then I'd facepalm because I had missed a path that was right in front of me because it didnt seem like it was traversable because of the way the backgrounds are designed/rendered. SOUNDTRACK - Okay another huge plus! The music in this game is epic. But then of course it is. It's Final Fantasy! :)I loved FF7's music for years, even though I had never managed to get through the game before. You don't really need to play the game to enjoy its music though. I mean, who hasnt heard One Winged Angel and loved it :)----So that's my honest assessment. Headaches and Eyestrain aside, Immersive Story is a HUGE deal for me, and its what I come to expect from Final Fantasy titles but it just didnt do it for me, so I sadly am rating this a no-go.That being said, I am probably the only person who never got to play this as a kid, and so my lack of nostalgia for this game has no factor in my review.Take my words with a grain of salt. If you loved this game as a kid, you'll probably love it now. But if you've never played FF7 at all, ever in your life, I'll give you a simple and fair advice:  Be wary that it may disappoint due to its age and the translation of the story, but If you can pick it up on steam sale like I did, it's worth deciding for yourself if you love it or hate it :)PS. FF7 lovers. Please don't hate me for the negative review. I reserve judgement on the FF7 world as a whole until after I play the new remake. I just cant like this version ^^;

Posted: November 8, 2014
												Technical bits:This is the first PC version with some fixes hacked in i.e they didn't rebuild the game cause they've lost the source code or couldn't be bothered to spend the effort doing so.Also updated to require registration with Square Enix. DRM a clear priority; actual function not even a consideration. No native controller support etc.Actual game:My first RPG game ever, I really enjoyed playing through this when it came out on PS1.  If you like old school RPG's with random battles I'd give this ago if you can over look the technical failures and now dated graphics - but the asking price is high for such an old game. Get in cheap on sale if you're on the fence. Overall:Not recommended due to not being updated to support controllers properly, fix bugs, and mainly because of added DRM. Play on PS1 if you still have it instead.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												What's there to say about a PC port of a PS1 game that steamtrained the charge into the 5th generation of gaming? It works and feels about as close as you can get without the original non-analog controller in yours hands. Despite it being what i presume is a direct port, the graphics stand the test of time very well, although there is a hefty graphical mod to be found elsewhere. Hopefully a quick summary will suffice:Pros:Ease of controlImmersive universeLengthy (Originally ran on 3 CD's with the PS1 release)Combat system, storyline & characters are unforgettable.Justifiable price (Bought it full price £10 a week into steam release, got pushed down to £5 the week after; No Regrets)Cons:Graphics are still great to look at, but may not cater to some people expecting a full refurb.Not sure if they replaced the horrible MIDI version of the soundtrack with the steam release, but original PS1 tracks can replace.Growing up with this game since 95', I can safely say that if you don't come to love this game, then RPG's aren't your genre :)

												To resurrect Aeris, you'll need 99 Tissues, 1 mastered Revive materia, and an Underwater materia. Cry at Aeris's bed 99 times. Head over to Tifa's piano and play Aeris's theme. Cloud will use the Revive materia and Aeris will come back to life!

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												A lot of people say FF7 is the most overrated FF game/RPG game and guess what? I disagree with that. If you wanted to play a game that best defines the RPG genre, there's so many titles like SMT Nocturne, Persona 3 FES/4, Dark Soul, Deus Ex etc. to choose from but I think FF7 is the best starter if you're looking to try to get into RPG games.From what I've played, this is the only good FF game with an interesting cast of characters, story and setting. There's something special about this game that puts it above the others really. It feels like the rest just haven't quite captured that same magic FF7 did.  It's no wonder that this has been the most popular FF game to begin with and the most demanded for a remake (and we finally got it thankfully). The gameplay itself is turn based combat which requires good strategy and decision making, with battles happening randomly on the field or getting triggered by specific points along the story. Although the characters look like miniature polygon block versions of themselves when not fighting, the character models are more realistic and proportioned correctly in combat. For its time it was a big step forward because FF7 was the first game in the series to have character models with fully rendered polygons, rather than 2D sprites. Therefore battles take place using a 3D representation of the characters, enemies and the area itself. Moreover, there are 9 playable characters: You have Cloud- an blue eyed blonde haired big lad wielding a bigass greatsword. Tifa- a kind and strong willed tiddy fighter who applies her martial arts skills in combat. Barret- a very burly, built and all around cool Mr.T who uses guns ( think). Yuffie, who acts as a nimble ninja and many more. With a diverse set of characters like I've just described, it's easy to see why something like Final Fantasy 7 was such a huge hit amongst many. It's just a shame that not everyone gets as much development you'd like them to have, which is something I hope the remake really fleshes out considering it's going to be episodic. Fingers crossed that the remake surpasses the huge waves FF7 made in its time and that the devs won't reduce Tifa's bust size to please non-players who complain about petty things.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												Final Fantasy 7... we both know why you're here... the remake is coming out soon and you want to buy it...+ Good Story+ Good Character Development+/- Dated Graphics+/- Timed Turn Based- Random Enemy Encounters- Long Cut Scenes- Unable to skip dialogue 7/10Honestly, this game was okay, but it wasn't mind blowing. I'm sure when it released it certainly was the greatest game for its time, but if you're playing a game like this for the first time, you'll notice how dated it is. The story and environment are a little weird, but it does have its charm. It can be pretty annoying if you die, you have to click your way through the dialogue and be forced to watch any cutscenes. But the worst feature has to be the random encounters. It can be frustrating when you just want to walk across a platform, but you're constantly interrupted by a monster.Overall, it's an alright game. You'll probably play it if you enjoy RPGs, and you probably should play it because it's historical.

												So; everyone knows how good this game is, then why did I not recomend this title?  you can get about 60 hours out of this game when your burning through it, that being said my SAVE DATA was LOST about 40 hours in [mostly offline] and I was doing a lot of stuff not just burning.  Later; I found that many others have had this same problem so I looked into it and it was for sure my SAVE DATA was GONE, but how?  I then downloaded some save files online to play around with and I noticed the SAVE DATA DISAPEARING on startup.  so i came to the conclusion that when their program suspects you of cheating it DELETES YOUR DATA.  So.. by all means buy this title if you want to backup your save file everytime you save because it could be you that puts 40 hours into it without cheating and still gets punished... your better off finding the ROM in my opinion though.

It doesn't support D-pads for some reason and the thumbstick is far too sensitive, but whatever. There are slightly tedious ways to overcome this, I've heard. The most annoying aspect of it is that EVERY NPC has a permanent O-face. Something happened somewhere in the process and all the NPCs you run into either look like they're in perptual shock or some kind of zombie. They can also look rather glitchy when they blink.If you can comfortably play this game ANYWHERE else, do that instead. Otherwise... I mean... Essentially it's still FF7. Just Derpier.

												*deep breath* Ah, smell that nostalgia. Man, I remember playing this when I was just a kid. This story became a part of me as i sat in front of that T.V. on the edge of my bed, probably the first game that really made me care. I followed cloud through an epic journey across the world to confront a relic of his past and tried to find his purpose. It still holds up today, for me at least. To go back through this game was not a chore, but an encore. Theres a reason it's a classic referenced everywhere. If you can enjoy a game for something other than graphics I highly recommend it. content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												If you've never played the game before and have heard about this game from other people, then this review will help you.I've never played FF7 before, so I decided to buy the steam version to see all the hype!And honestly, this game does not live up to all the hype people say it does. It's not a bad game, IT'S NOT BAD, it's good, but after hearing all the amazing things about this game, I was disappointed.What the game does well:The gameplay is tight, you control 3 characters in your turned based style, each weapon has slots for items called materia. Materia give you access to spells and abillities, so you're gonna be hunting down a lot of these! The world itself is vast and there's A LOT to do. Once you get an airship the game becomes less linear and you're free to go where you wish. Before that, you'll be following the story mainly. The combat can get repetitive though, but it's an RPG so it's not surprising. There's a wide variety of characters to play as, but you have to keep Cloud in the party. The limit breaks look good too. Also, the music in this game is beautiful.What the game doesn't do well:Some of the main cast are mediocre characters, very mediocre. HOWEVER, Vincent, Cid, Aeris, Yuffie and Tifa are awesome. On the other hand, you have Cloud-who is shallow, boring and just nothing like he's hyped up by fans of this game to be. He never takes charge of anything, his dialogue is usually just a generic response to someone else. His character development is kind of lame too. Cait Sith is hands down one of the worst, most annoying characters I've ever seen in a game. I don't know why Square decided to make Vincent optional, but have Cait Sith be in the main cast. The story itself is a wild goose chase to stop Sephiroth from destroying the world, but he's just a lame villain. Honestly, he has mommy issues, all he does is yammer on about her. His motivations are poorly explained too. The backstories for some of the main cast are lame too, I couldn't care for Cait, Barret or Red at all.The animations for summons in this game take a fairly long time, which is frustrating. The idea of Sephiroth being an all power soldier goes down the drain at the end of the game too. I don't want to spoil too much.I don't recommend this game tbh, it's really underwhelming.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												I never played this game when I was a kid, so I don't have all the nostalgia hype going for me. Even so, this game has aged very well. Obviously the graphics are mediocre at best, but this game just does so many things right. The main gripe I have with this game (and this may change. I'm not too far into it yet) is that there's no variety in the scenary. You start off in a steam-punkish, giant, urban city, and as far as I can tell so far, there is basically nothign outside of it. You will stay in this steam-punkish, giant, urban city forever.However, like I said that is my only major gripe. The story so far is compelling, I cant wait to see what happens next, the characters are all interesting with real three-dimensional personalities, and despite the low quality of the graphics, I'm even enjoying the visuals that this game offers.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												If you're going for the nostalagia, the controls don't quite feel right; unless you're using something similar to the playstion one controller-for those in the N.American region. Still not a deterrent.An excellent game with an intruiging story line. Looking for a way to impress some super nerd? Play this game and enjoy it. It's worth your time. P.S.-This is Final Fantasy closest to its peak universe creation. Since this one, the world building has slightly slid downhill. It's got dysfunctional main character immersion. Love interests. Excellent score. One of the best villans of all time. It's before Japanese companies said f-u to their major market, white young males, and snuck asian features into all the characters. I hate to say that, but it's true; and I'm glad Final Fantasy went in that direction, because it means they're making games for whom they want to, and that will lead to better games and better people. Better for you, better for me. I just happen to be in the young white male category that sells real well over here in the N. American circuit. Thank you for this wonderful game. I'm confident people in the company know exactly what I'm talking about. This is them at their best writing, though. They have always been a promising company, where one looks forward to what comes next.  I'm waiting to see what tops this game for me. And btw, they're are many titles that are just behind this one.I feel like since I wrote this far, I'd be doing an injustice to anyone that has hung with this to not make a list of my top FF games. (Some have different numbers in Japan)*Final Fantasy 7 *Final Fantasy 8*Final Fantasy 3*Final Fantasy Tactics*Final Fantasy 12 (Long, beware)*Final Fantasy 9Lightning's journey was left out-too linear, so was Bhakka ball and that such. Fun and nodful, but lack luster. The MMO's are ok, great communities, but feel unrelateable, repetitive, for kids. That's fine and great, but this company has traditionally been moving in that direction and wants to stay there it seems. Good for them, I'm sure it makes them money. But they should raise the stakes. It might even be fun for them.Point is, I grew up, and am interested in different things. Interesting things. Look at what sells well in N.America Final Fantasy. Are we really not buying that much anymore? Sad, but think if you Grand Theft Autoed your Black and White wizards? What if we darkened up Cecil from the Red Wings, think young Daniel Day Lewis, think Game of Thrones. Unless it's like an ettiquette thing, or I'm missing something, like promoting sex and violence to a very dangerous and threatening culture? One that's had an, let's be polite, interesting past, with one another. I've never visited Japan, I'd like too! so I can't say for sure what the answer is. I don't think I'd come right out and ask, or should I? I'd definitely need about a Donald Trump level foreign negotiator interpreter. I'm sure that guy/girl will have their hands full if he wins. If that happens, I'd just say keep making games for kids and hope they turn out better.Point is, there's a market for it. I grew up. This is what sells. I buy things. I'm interested in this company. And that's it.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Final Fantasy VII. Is there anybody who doesn't know it yet? Unless you have been living under a rock for more than 16 years, you have at least heard of this, one of the most famous games of all time, loved by many and hated by others, with almost no one remaining indifferent. But what matters is, is this port worth the time? It's basically the same as the game that was released on Playstation 1 and PC years ago. The only thing that is new to this re-release is achievements, which in my opinion are a stupid thing to put in any game whatsoever; the character booster feature, which basically makes battles easier and allows you to buy lots of items and equipment without worrying about grinding for gils; And the music, which uses the Playstation 1 tracks rather than the old and low-quality PC tracks. PC users may find it worthy for the updated music, but those who played it on Playstation 1 are not missing much here. That said, if you have never played Final Fantasy VII, you should at least consider buying it here. All gamers should play this game at least once and cement an opinion about it from their experiences.Get this if you are a hardcore fan who wants to play Final Fantasy VII on the PCs of today, or a newcomer who wants to experience it for the first time. Make sure you grab it on a sale.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												This is a grand daddy jRPG game. It changed the face of story telling in a game. Graphically it is dated, gameplay....Well it is odd how the average gamer or at least the industry has shifted away from turn based gameplay. I loved it and still enjoy it. Leveling was one of the gameplay defining elements in this game by excluding magic from the system and making magic & skills a seperate leveling system. You define what characters skills and spells they have and how to use them. In addition you can change what they have after each battle which allows you to better deal with a diffcult fight that requires specific spells for example.What actually makes this game special is the story. The story in the game changed gaming for years to come with it's mature approach. *****POSSIBLE BUT VERY VAGUE SPOILER******Unlike any game of it's time you have to deal with death. Death of party members, death of friends, and death of personalities. Something we all deal with with, friends changing their ways or a more permit lose. The main character battles with this constantly and faces questions with himself that are addressed in what I can only compare to Shakespear in a unique a intresting sci-fi fantasy world.******END OF POSSIBLE SPOILER******If only for the story I can not recommened this game enough. It is alot more focused and less open ended then previous Final Fantasy games but it's story is better for it.Unfortunetly I never got to enjoy it when it came out as I was a N64 guy and only played it at my friends. But years later I got it for PC and it will forever remain on of my top games of all time.Thumbs way up even with the dated graphics.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												If you don't know what Final Fantasy VII is about by now you're better off checking real reviews. So let's just focus on the port and how it holds up to today:The port is pretty great now that they replaced the midi music with the PS1 music. (Though truth be told I wish you could choose because MIDI music has its charm to some) Also since it's PS1 music it sounds a bit muffled and still synthesized. The polygon models look great, nice and sharp. Sound effects are fairly sparse by today's standards but they get the job done.There's not a lot of configuration options, though. You can increase resolution, use a bad blurring filter, stretch or keep aspect ratio, or use original graphic mode (pixelated, unfiltered polygons) and then configure keyboard/joystick controls.Xbox 360 controllers integrate well (better if you use a mod from Steam community guides)There's Cloud Saves and Achievements but both are poorly implemented:Achievements are rather incredibly lazy which is a shame because this game natively tracks A LOT of information so why they didn't put more effort into the Achievements is beyond me. 17 out of 36 are just limit break related and that's just using each character's first and last one, and the odd number is because they don't care about you using Yuffie's first limit. So almost half of the achievements are limit break related. Fun.Cloud saving can be annoying because you can't load or save until Square's servers sync. And when it takes less than a second to click through and save or load, being told to wait can be annoying. So far I've never had to wait more than 10 seconds and that was a rare late time, but it's still something worth mentioning because, well, many question why it matters to have Cloud saves. Which brings us to the special trainer called the Character Booster from Square-Enix and it's why we deal with Square's servers for cloud saves in the first place. Here's what the trainer will do: Max HP/MP and give you I think half of the max Gil (so you can't totally cheat for the gil achievement I guess) That's it. So, yeah... Oh, and to use the trainer you have to sign up at Square-Enix's site, if you haven't already, and login there to alter your saves. And that can be unreliable for loading. So if you're going to cheat, do it right and use a fan made trainer instead.It's just another very lazy effort by them considering how much info is actually saved in a FFVII game save. Oh well. The nice thing is you can take it or leave these features.You also can't load saves in game (have to close the game), which can be incredibly annoying but I don't think you could on the PS1 either. It just would have been nice to add that feature on PCAnother annoying thing is that if you don't turn on or plug in your controller before running the game it won't be recognized. A lot of games work this way but a lot also don't care when you do it. So it's worth mentioning.The only other minor issue is if you alt tab for too long you'll make the game error out and there's no borderless fullscreen window mode natively to combat that. (And Steam's web browser integration is the devil on resource leaks) So definitely don't multi-task with this game if you can avoid it.Gameplay-wise this is still a pretty great game. The materia system is still fun and worthwhile. There's a ton of sidequests and items to gather but instead of doing today's method of just plastering them everywhere VII's quests and items are well integrated and hidden and they often involve fun mini-games or mini quests to gain, quests that often ADD to the story rather than detract. Battles can also be fairly fun and challenging if you don't go too crazy with over leveling too soon.The story doesn't hold up very well, I think, if viewed objectively. It would be considered amatuer by today's standards and poorly developed at that. It still has a certain something something to it but it's rough during a lot of spots. But the saving grace is that most of characters are actually interesting and dynamic. Unlike recent Final Fantasy offerings. And there's no annoying in your face narration always getting in the way. But, still, it could have been done a lot better. I will concede, though, that this is probably the last well written Final Fantasy story so far. It's cohesive and well plotted out for that standard.Ultimately, this game is still a lot of fun and for its time it was incredibly well designed and incredibly ambitious. This game did a lot of "firsts" on the PS1 from a technical perspective and Squaresoft at the time pioneered A LOT of techniques that would be later used in other games. There's a reason why this game is cherished and respected and why most of it still holds firm today, and young whipper snappers would do well to study why that is rather than be hip and mindlessly hate on the game.A note about the pixelated backgrounds: If you play at anything above the 640x480 resolution you're going to notice major pixelation of the backgrounds. You'll also notice pixelation if you stretch 640x480 to full screen. This is because Squaresoft was so intelligent, like most companies back then, that they didn't feel compelled to make multiple backups of their source material or even back it up in the first place before reducing everything for the PS1 to handle. So, we get this mess. A damn shame. Spend MILLIONS, unheard at that time, and you don't even flipping cherish your hard earned source material.Ok, rant aside you can either deal with the pixelation (which will be noticed even if played on PS1 or emulators on HDTVs) or you can take into consideration what all game designers did back then: These weren't played on HDTVs. They were played on low resolution TVs with scanlines. So, how can you achieve that on PC now? With this SweetFX enchancement: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=162106660. It'll add proper looking scanlines with RGB dot-like lines. It's really awesome and well worth it. It "blends" the pixelated backgrounds as far as your eyes are concerned and it'll look like a great TV from back in the day. If you play at a distance, more than 3 feet, it really works well. And even close it looks better than having huge, unblended pixels and it's how we all played it "back in the day". So if you want the true nostalgia effect, short of digging out a 200 pound CRT TV, this is the best way to deal with the low resolution backgrounds if you don't want to mod them (which I think look pretty bad anyway). And be aware that certain mods for VII will break achievements and cloud saving, if you cared about that.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												I hated this game for almost two decades. This game, hailed as the best Final Fantasy game by many, didn't feel like a Final Fantasy at all to me. It felt like a betrayal of the spirit of the series. I'd made many attempts at playing it over the years, but each time just couldn't get through it.Gone was the beautiful fantasy setting of past FF games I knew and loved, replaced now by a grungy, ugly technologically-advanced city setting. Gone were the gorgeous Amano character designs, replaced now by generic-looking anime characters. Gone was a quick and prompt introduction to a massive overworld, replaced by a ridiculously long introduction section full of corridor after corridor. Gone was the gorgeous spritework of past games, replaced by a seemingly premature move to horribly-aged 3D models and people with blocks for hands.All of this made me find the endless praise for this game utterly baffling.Now, after playing Final Fantasy VII in its entirety (instead of only the first few hours of the game like in my past attempts), I get it. I see why people love this game now.Despite its flaws, Final Fantasy VII is very much still deserving of the Final Fantasy name. It has just as much charm and soul as its predecessors in the series.The game's first few hours are honestly very misleading, as I eventually found out once I got to the overworld. There are towns in the game that look like they could easily have been in FF1-6, for example. The grungy setting of Midgar is not at all representative of what the rest of the game is like. Anyone who is put off by the beginning Midgar portion should seriously continue playing the game so they don't make the same mistake I did for almost 2 decades. It really does get better and opens up after a while - you just have to stick to it.The story is not only engrossing, it even attempts things that its predecessors hadn't. The story of FF VII has a very powerful pro-environmental theme at its core, and the game is totally unapologetic and blatant about it the entire way through, something I really loved about it. It's an incredible shame that modern-day Square is too incompetent to ever remake this game properly (or at all), because its environmental message is even more relevant today than when the game was released, and this will only become the case more and more in the years to come.Despite my premature perception of them, I eventually found FF VII's cast of characters to be really endearing, memorable, and likeable. Not to mention, diverse. I liked that Square was brave enough to introduce the first black playable character in the series, Barrett. (quick rant: FFXV's boyband party is such a step back for the FF series compared to FFVII, how much more dull can you get than a bunch of dudebros in a car - but I digress). With regard to the main lead character, I used to think Cloud was an unlikeable protagonist. In the first few hours of the game (which for a long time were all I had experienced), he was selfish, cold, and rude to everyone around him, even his friends, and to me this is usually a dealbreaker when it comes to the games I play. I need to be able to relate to the character, otherwise how am I supposed to motivate myself to complete their 40+ hour adventure? If the character is a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ why on earth would I want to fight for them to succeed? Well, it turns out (surprise surprise) that Cloud actually gets a fair amount of character development later on in the game, and all of the attributes I disliked about him completely fade away. By the end of the game he's become a more humble, respectable hero figure who actually appreciates his friends and their sacrifices. This was great to see unfold.Another strength of the game is the soundtrack. Like all of the previous FF entries, the soundtrack is full of grade-A Uematsu masterpieces. By the end of Part II I was already looking to add the soundtrack and many fan remixes to my music collection, and I'm even listening to the Piano Collections album as I type this. It's just so good. I already know I'm going to be humming tunes from the game for years to come. Even though I only JUST beat the game for the first time in 2015, I already feel a strong wave of emotion when I happen to hear the overworld theme. The game and its soundtrack are just that memorable.Now with regard to gameplay, when I first played the game many years ago, I hated the Materia system. I couldn't believe every character could equip the same Materia, removing any element of uniqueness from the different characters you could add to your party. It seemed juvenile and basic, removing any need to thoughtfully plan out your character's job or skill development. "Baby's First RPG" was my first thought. However, by the end of Part II, I was in love with the Materia system. I now realize just how much interesting customization to your party it allows. I spent an enormous chunk of time just trying out different combinations of linked Materia. I'm honestly surprised this system never returned in a later Square game, because it's really versatile and fun to work with once you get deep into it and have acquired enough Materia in the game.So, now that you see me praising the game, do I take back every negative thing I've said about the game in the past? Not everything. I still disagree with people who call it the best Final Fantasy - it's frankly not even close.I still think it's the ugliest Final Fantasy, by far. Square honestly tried going 3D one game too early. Final Fantasy VII would have aged so much more gracefully if they had stuck with 2D sprites for just one more game, while refining their 3D modeling team and engine in the meantime for the next game. Blocks for hands? I get that it's the first 3D entry, but even the first 3D Zelda game managed to do much better than that.However, visuals alone do not make a game, and Final Fantasy VII is a great example of this. Taken as a whole, the game more than makes up for its glaring flaws through an awesome story, characters, music, and gameplay. This is still Final Fantasy at its core. It may look different to someone who grew up with SNES-era FF, but it's still absolutely worth a playthrough for a fan of the previous games.Now, thanks to this game, I feel like my eyes have been opened. If I was so wrong about this game, then I've probably been wrong about the games that came after it too. I now look forward to playing the next several games I've skipped out on, with a completely new perspective. Instead of being resistant to change, I'm going to give it a proper chance. Change can, in fact, be a good thing, as Final Fantasy VII proves.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												Final Fantasy 7 is ~17 years old and still one of the best games out there.  Graphics suck, but it was an early "3D game", easy to overlook for anyone who has a relatively decent attention span.  The game from Steam seems to have the soundtrack from the PS1 copy (although missing a few things, like the 'escape' sound) and not that POS one from the old windows box.  It's pretty much a jack of all trades game, pioneering a lot of fields, etc.  I've read about people crying for it to be remade for years; honestly I'm hoping they don't touch it.  I can't see this game scoring less than a M rating if they do nothing other than bringing the graphics up to "PS3/X360" era - so they'll definitely be taking liberties with several things..  Enjoy the game for what it is, bad graphics or not; it's still an absolute masterpiece.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Final Fantasy VII is the greatest role playing game achievement of my generation.  Combining elements of previous installments in the franchise, FF7 marries the fantastic materia system with a combat system that to this day is still unrivled (only Final Fantasy VIII and X can even compare), and tells one of the greatest tales in video game history.  But, everyone reading this already knows that.  There's not a person in the world that's living under that deep of a rock that hasn't played or heard of Final Fantasy 7, so let's not go there.  Instead, you should be interested in this Steam version of the game. As someone who has grown up on the original Playstation release, playing through it twice on that console, and once as a digital psn download on a psp, this would be my fourth time going through the journey.  Perhaps the most impressive aspect of this re-release is the 1920x1080p resolution, which is the first time it has ever been supported.  For this release, it looks fantastic, being as close to an "HD" re-release we will probably ever get.   The steam acheivements help too, and throw in the excellent controller support and you have a real winner.  Final Fantasy is a joy playing again, and I do hope that if you are one of those few that are living under a rock, please take a look at quite possibly the greatest RPG of all time.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												Well, I just beat it, at 83 hours in I beat this game. Now I can say at the very least 10 was on over grinding for the last boss and about 30 was because of me doing something stupid and reloading my last save, so over all my playtime for game completion was 43 hours. Now for the $12 they are asking for I would say give it a shot. If you are like me though, you hated this series for one reason or another, try this game. You may have tried it when you were younger or maybe you tried another one like I did, but trust in me this game is great. There are some problems that must be brought up, like the insane grinding you have to do. My first time going to fight the final boss I was about Level 56 or so and I spent 10 hours grinding and got to level 76. The master materia is a joke, for me at least. Beating the Ruby Weapon is unrewarding. Not all moves that you get from the enemy skill materia can be obtained at any (once you can travel freely) time. Part 1 feels like the longest part 2 felt like it was done way too quickly. If you level your character to 99 the game becomes 4x harder. At the begining the story moves at such a slow draging pace that felt like a road trip alone. Some materia is just do bad you cant use it. And after seeing Some things from other Final Fantasy 7 game's (particularly how someone dies) made the game feel like it did not prefore to duty but the good has out wieghed the bad. I strongly recomend it.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												A classic turn based RPG that has aged incredibly well.  Take this from somebody who first played this game in 2009 and not when it originally released when I say that it has aged very well.  The combat is fun and rewarding thanks to the materia system which basically lets you build characters anyway you want.  The story isn't the freshest story out there but what it does it does well.  The graphics are okay for the time but some younger players might be turned off by everybody having dumbells for arms, but there is a mod to upgrade the graphics so all is well.  Music is phenominal which is expected from a Final Fantasy game.  The only downsides to this game is Square's DRM for a single player game and a "Win Button" which makes characters level 99 for lazy ♥♥♥♥s.  I say buy it though especially if you have never played it, it is the perfect opportunity to enjoy a bit of RPG history.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Amazingly well transported to PC (finally!) and I've been really quite impressed. The default settings work really pretty well with only two or three things I've encountered so far being really, really awkward - playing Tifa's piano to get her final limit break, doing the marching directions as a soldier to impress Shinra in Junon and fighting off the bikers as you escape the Shinra HQ building on your bike - but to be honest, two of those were fairly difficult on the PS originally anyway.You need to fix the save system by making sure that you're saving to local files through configuration (otherwise you can be very frustrated losing data when you first start, as I was once).You need to register through the Square Enix site, which annoyed me at first, but once set up hasn't bothered me since.Everything else has been exceptional, bugless, glitchless and the same old school gaming experience that I loved as a child, dodgy graphic models and all!

content:
Posted: November 8, 2013
												One of the greatest RPGs of all time. Whether you liked it or not, it was revolutionary for its time.  This is based on the 1998 PC version produced by Eidos, but is inferior in quality due to SE "losing" the MIDI files from the original version (This is supposed to have been since fixed).  The music is atrocious and most of the glitches are still in place from the original PC release.  Furthermore the additions of a SE account and other things make it a hassle.  However, since this has been around since 1998 on the PC there is rather large mod community around the game here http://forums.qhimm.com/Check it out, they have mods and very easy to follow instructions on how to play this game with enhanced soundtrack, graphics, and even gameplay.  Stand alone, I would rate this a 2/10 and would say to try and find an actual PC disc version online somewhere (or better yet the actual PS1 version), however with the mods, I'd rate this an 8/10 with point suffering for the still possible glitches you may face with the mods.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												Where do I even start with this game...It's just a classic.No matter how bad the graphics are (and they're really not that bad), the story, characters, and gameplay all but make up for it. Each character has an amazing backstory, as well as deep character development. Even the secret characters Yuffie and Vincent have an extreme amount of depth to them. There are many sidequests, for example: Chocobo Breeding & Racing, Limit Break levelling, Ultimate Weapon hunts, minigames, etc., that will keep you occupied when you don't feel like moving on with the story yet, or you want them to use in the story. This is by far my favourite game of all time. 10/10 buy it at all costs.

Dont get me wrong there are tons of games that have the same amount of open world experiences mixed with customization, but I havent played a game yet with this many characters that all work so well together.  You fall in love with every single character... ALL OF THEM bad or good (besides President Shinra of course .... screw that fat A hole!). The story that is sooooooo good and the message is powerful! Buy this game and buy it now!!!

Posted: December 26, 2016
												For all you nostalgia seekers out there, this is your ticket to them good old glory days. Anyways.FF-VII is by far one of the best experiences you can get from a JRPG. Excellent story with a great underlying narrative, rich characters and a deep world to exlpore. Tons of mini-games can be found throughout and many can be revisited. Though I would say some can be time consuming, such as the Chocobo breeding and racing, they have their own rewards for those who really want to invest themselves to get every last drop wrung out of this title. Though the graphics are very dated, the pc port has been lightly polished and performs great. All in all, FF-VII is more than worth the price.Pros:-Classic jrpg active time battle system-Rich story-Great and memorable characters-Tons of things to explore and find throughout the world-Cutscenes still look superb-Nostalgia highCons:-Graphically, this game has aged horribly, even with the polished character models and higher resolution-For a jrpg, combat is fairly easy through most of the game with no major learning curve-Some areas early in the game still have imbalanced amounts of xp earned, leading to easily being levels ahead of your intended level-Some bugs which existed in original still persist in the pc port, but all are rare and hardly gamebreaking-Needs to support higher resolutionsAs said, you'll get a perfect jrpg experience here and not feel a single penny is wasted if this is your kind of bag.
